reviewText:
I'll start off by saying that it is extremely addicting and worth the money.

The game begins by giving you a 30 second tutorial then literally thrusting you into the game, expecting you to use trial and error to succeed. As you play the game you will get more efficient each play through as you learn more about how the game works and what strategies are good in the early mid and late game.

Pros:
+ Sound Track is on Point
+ Visual Style is appealing
+ Proggression is strong
+ Extremely Difficult, forcing you to adapt
+ Money is your health and you can't hold an infinite amount of money

Cons:
- Lack of story
- Horse Stamina (When your kingdom gets massive it's extremely annoying to stop and recover stamina)
- Lack of Late game monsters (There are essentially 3 monster types)

Questionable Design Decisions:
= Extremely Fast Day and NIght Cycles
= Only One Wave of monsters per Night. Becomes kind of exploitable
= Limited to building 4 knights (2 per side) Allowing more knights could have enabled more difficult attacks from the
monsters and more preperations by the player.

= The only way to get new people to your Kingdom is to hire them at camps. The system limits expansion speed but  causes the player to constantly run back and forth accross the map to recruit new people.

OVERVIEW:
Simplistic game that is worth the money.

One word of advice. Don't stand too close to your catapults.

*EDIT*
TL/DR
Worker AI and Archer Accuracy is intentional and well balanced (In my opinion)
Read About what I have to say about it below

A lot of people with negative reviews are complaining about bad AI of workers and bad aim of archers. I'm not sure what the devs planned for the game but I see the bad" AI as intentional. Basically if you give a worker or workers a job they will mindlessly try to complete the job. People complain that this is stupid because workers will go out in the middle of the night to their deaths until the project is complete. I see this as a positive thing. Say you desperately need to repair a torn down wall right as the day turns to night. Would you rather your workers stand in the safety of your kingdom or go and repair the wall as you told them to. If you plan out the jobs you give to your workers you shouldn't have a problem with all your workers going out at night to their doom to chop down a tree.

Wow that was a lot of stuff. But I'm not done yet.

On to the topic of Archers and their terrible aim.
I think Archers are meant to be inaccurate so that when they hunt during the day they don't bring in so much gold as to break the early game. A lone Archer is not very powerful
date: but as you recruit more people
recommended: the relentless volleys of arrows released by 15+ archers is hard to beat. Sure one archer can miss an enemy 5 times in a row but 10 archers will easily dispatch exponentially more enemies then a small group can. What I'm trying to say is that the game is balanced around recruiting. Expanding and not destroying ecampments so that you can recruit constantly. The more archers you have the more powerful your kingdom is. Rapid and early Recruitment is better than expansion because people are power. There is a good saying in Kingdom. "If your not recruiting your losing"\n\nI just want to say that by no means is this game perfect but I just think it is necessary to call attention to down votes based on things that aren't really negatives. But after all the beauty of the review system is people can post their opinions and no one is right or wrong."

reviewText:
So, after over 40 hours spent playing the game I felt it's time to finally write a review.

First of all, I really enjoy this game tremendously, but I'd say it's not for everyone. If you read other reviews, you probably have a good idea what the good part of the game is, nice art, awesome soundtrack (first time I ever bought a game OST, and not regretting it one bit). These are the two things I think everyone can agree about.

Then it gets more tricky. The gameplay isn't for everyone. It's literally discover everything for yourself. including how your own guys behave, even how your own horse behaves.
The real problem can come from when you don't figure some things out (like how to keep your horse running or how to make your dudes not suicide themselves constantly) and then give up thinking the devs didn't think of that and write review claiming the game is unfinished or lacking.

On the other hand, simply reading a guide after 5 hours of play, is basically ruining the discovery experience, so in my opinion if you want to enjoy the game try to not look up too many things (or maybe just ask a simple singe question in the forums instead).

Now, that being said, another big deterrent can be the lack of endgame content. (It needs to be said though, that the devs are working on adding more stuff (for free), so that might not be true anyore in a few months.)
For me, it took me over 10 hours to beat the game the first time I think, and after that, there where achievements for doing it quick and for enduring long. The speedrunning aspect I really liked, but the endurance aspect (trying to survive as long as you can) is really lacking atm. Once you're set up there's not much to do for 30-50 days, cause you're defenses are just that good.
So if you really enjoy building up a large empire and surviving a long time, this game is in it's current stage definitely not for you (imo).
Me personally, I really enjoy the speedrunning aspect of the game, so trying over and over to finish the game quicker and quicker is really fun for me and is mostly what kept me going for the last 25 hours or so. (Especially since people keep getting quicker and quicker :D)
It also means that one has to learn more and more details about the game mechanics, which I really like too. I've played over 40 hours and still learn new stuff.

But even without doing speedruns, I think the game offers enough content to be worth the money, unless you basically spoiler yourself with guides before you even start (at which point it's getting a bit boring and mechanical, as the normal playthrough isn't that dificult once you understand most mechanics).
A big fun aspect of the game is losing horribly a lot and then learning more and more how stuff works and then at some point you just easily beat it using all your hard gained knowledge and it feels really good. But if you just look up everything, that sense of achievement will never happen and the game will probably feel a bit bland.

Two last negative points I want to mention, one is a bug the other a framerate problem. There is still a bug that can break the game a little. Like it can happen that you win, but you don't get the victory and all your dudes stop working. If you don't know that this is a bug it can get quite frustrating. The first time I actually beat the game this happened and I didn't realize it was not supposed to happen, so I spent another 20 days trying to figure out how to win until someone in the forums exaplined to me that this is a bug. (If that happens to you, just exit and start again, and it should put you before the bug happens and you should be fine from there on).
The framerate issues luckily" only happen later on (say day 60 and upwards and usually only during blood moon nights where a lot of monsters appear)
date: so if there wasn't an achievement for surviving 100 days most people would probably never experience it. But there is. And they do. Regardless of how good your computer rig is it seems.\n\nI want to end with saying I had a quite magical time with this game. I bought it right when it came out and a lot of people were streaming it at that point. Since there weren't any guides available at this time it created a very unqie atmosphere
recommended: where I would hop from stream to stream watching a bit

voteText: sharing some small tips here and there myself. It really reminded me of the earlier days of gaming
helpfulPercent: when you couldn't just look up everything online but went to friends places shared and small discoveries with each others. That's something I haven't experienced in over a decade and I probably won't in quite a while. So I just want to end by shouting a big "thank you" to the devs for creating this marvelous experience with their game and I stay curious to see where they take it from here.\n\nTL;DR : If you enjoy being a scientist

reviewText:
>Horde of faceless peasants to make money for you
>Disproportionately massive military spending
>Build giant walls to keep enemies out

Donald Trump Simulator 2015
voteText: 974 of 1,243 people (78%) found this review helpful 1,838 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Introduction
Kingdom is a 2D, side-scrolling strategy game where you take on the role of king or queen of a kingdom (I’ll just refer to your character as king from now on for simplicity). As king it’s your job to help your kingdom grow as well as protect said kingdom from the evil forces lurking deep in the forest. All you have is your crown and an empty coin sack. Collect coins throughout the world and spend them on upgrades for you kingdom, don’t be afraid to use them all but be aware, the loss of your crown means the loss of everything.

Presentation
Kingdom has a truly beautiful pixel art style throughout. There’s really not much to say here other than it really does look fantastic. The only UI elements in the game is the coin sack (visible when collecting or spending coins) and the empty coin slots that appear when you’re next to something that can be purchased to show you how much it costs.

Gameplay
I’d just briefly like to say I won’t cover much past what you discover in the first half an hour or so in this section of my review. One of Kingdom’s main ‘selling-points’ is that you’re given next to no information about the game and so it’s very much about discovering how to do different things by yourself.

You walk through your kingdom while mounted on a horse, collecting coins from your people and then using those coins to bring more workers to your kingdom or to build/upgrade structures. You then have to defend your kingdom from attacking enemies. That is, effectively, the entire game. Of course it’s not quite so straightforward.

In the early days of a game there’s very little threat to your kingdom from what I like to call the dark forces lurking in the forest (we’ll call them monsters from now on). Without much threat from the monsters this really is the best time to get a solid foundation for your kingdom laid down. While you won’t have the resources to build the more advanced structures you’ll be able to build basic guard towers and basic wooden walls to keep the monstrous onslaught at bay. But what good are defences if you have no one to build them or man them? Well I’m glad you asked! To the left and right of your kingdom’s main building you’ll find many things including small encampments with people. These people will come work for you in your kingdom for the small fee of one gold coin. Returning to your kingdom you’ll want to buy the necessary tools for them to do the job you desire. Need more builders? Buy some hammers from the vendor in your village. Need more archers? Buy some bows from the vendor in your village! You get the idea.

Now things aren’t going to be this easy forever. The game gets progressively more difficult with the passing of each day and after just a couple of days you’ll be facing monsters looking to steal whatever they can get their horrible little hands on!

As I eluded to, there is a fair bit more in the game but I wouldn’t want to spoil it for prospective players but fear not, there is more to the game than I’ve already mentioned.

You can probably guess from how I’ve written about the gameplay that I’ve enjoyed playing the game, and I have. However, Kingdom did start to feel quite monotonous to me later in the game. Sure the difficulty is ramped up so there’s more pressure on you to build a village capable of fighting off the monsters and protecting the kingdom as a whole but Kingdom effectively descends into you doing the exact same thing each and every day. Perhaps I’m expecting too much from a game with a pretty simple premised and I imagine a lot of people will disagree with me on this but I don’t want to spend each in game day doing the same route to collect money from my people and then spending that money in the exact same way.

Audio
Kingdom’s audio department is truly fantastic. The sound effects throughout the game are all fantastic but what really makes this game’s audio shine is the fantastic soundtrack, some of which can be found on ToyTree Music’s YouTube channel. They really nailed the soundtrack for this one.

Miscellaneous There is a win condition in the game though I’m not 100% sure what it is since the devs are very secretive about it and only three people have actually managed to beat the game.
As far as I can tell your character is completely random, I was told on the forums by someone (not a dev) that you can change your banner/character at the beginning of the game but I couldn’t figure out how to actually do that.
The game world is randomly-generated each time you play.
At the beginning of each game you’re not able to fully explore your kingdom but as you expand your village to cover more land how far you can explore increases.
There is a free flash version of the game available, as far as I know this is just a much simpler version of the Steam game so even if you play the flash game the Steam version is still worth picking up.
You have no control over the positioning of your workers, this really only effects the archers as you'll often end up with one side being defensively stronger than the other.
Verdict
Worth Purchasing.

Kingdom is a great 2D, side-scrolling strategy game with a fantastic pixel art style, fun gameplay and lots to discover. While I don’t think it has bucket-loads of replayability it’s certainly enjoyable for several hours and is well worth your time and money.

Review Copy Provided.

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
It really pains me to give this game a negative review. This game is so beautiful, it has an original central mechanic and it's so full of promise. But, as it is, it's just a frustrating mess to actually play- which was the chief problem of the original free online version, as well. The friendly AI is not quite as stone stupid as in the original, but with the more complicated mechanics of the new version the outcome is about the same- your greatest enemy in this game is your allies.

For example, there are now catapults in the game, operated by the new builders. Catapults are very strong weapons, but they attack slowly and need a builder to reset them in-between attacks. Once a catapult is constructed, your builders will move it to your outermost walls, and move it again further out if new outermost walls are erected. So, hey, let's say you have a strong inner citadel with palisades on the outskirts. Guess where your builders will put your catapults? Where they are most vulnerable! What if your outermost walls are destroyed? No, the builders will not then move the catapult back inside the walls, it's just stuck out there in the open forever. There is no way you can control any of this. Guess you have to give up layered defenses if you want to use catapults!

So, you give up having perimeter palisades so you can have your catapult behind your strong inner wall, and the horde is coming. Does the catapult wait until the mass of demons is in range for a strong crowd control shot? Nope! It fires the moment the first little lead peon touches its range, and almost always then misses hitting anything at all as its shot drops behind the front runner and ahead of the main assault. Well, that's okay really, the catapult can just fire again, right? Ah, but it's not so easy, now you have to wait for the catapult to be reset. And funny thing, while your archers are now finally smart enough to stand by your walls at night in order to defend them, your builders... not so much. So, seeing as they wander aimlessly even in the middle of a siege, it's anybody's guess how long it will take for a builder to reach your catapult and begin actually operating it for the rest of the battle.

On top of all this there appears to be an outright bug where your character is vulnerable to your own catapult's fire even on the way up, and standing next to the catapult when it fires can cause your character to fumble their crown, flinging it forward into the mob of demons on the other side of the fully-intact wall, instantly costing you the game. This has happened to me more than once.

These catapult issues are not at all isolated, but if I try and list every stupid thing the friendly AI does then this review will become a very boring novel. The friendly AI is simply totally incompetent. Furthermore, the several entirely new mechanics added to the game have no explanation associated with them at all, despite the game having a simple, straightforward, and enjoyable tutorial for the central mechanic, taken from the original game. The new mechanics are simply unexplained, and some of them are apparently vital. There are cryptic features I am still utterly stumped by, like the shield on the menu, the banner in your camp, or the statue in the forest. These aspects of the game do not feel so much poorly designed as simply unfinished, as if it was shipped in a rush before there was time to put instructions on how to play into the game.

In summation, at this time this new version of Kingdom remains, as it was before, a beautiful, creative, unique, incredibly mind-numbingly frustrating game in which you want to bang your head against the screen displaying all the pretty pretty pictures because your little men have no common sense. It is definitely fixable with some work, if the developer chooses to fix it. Here's hoping they do.

reviewText:
It's an enjoyable game with a simple but satisfying gameplay experience, beautiful pixel art, and generally fun mechanics which blend Tower Defense and Base Building. It's worth 10 dollars to kill some time and see how long you can stave off your inevitable doom. However, the game is in desperate need of a patch to fix some of its glaring problems; and believe me, it has a load of gameplay shortcomings which become painfully obvious after an hour or two.

- The AI is abysmal. I mean painfully and blitheringly horrible. I found myself dying not because of the enemies, but because my workers would charge mindlessly into oncoming hordes of ogres to do something stupid that I didn't want them to do. I lost my best run around day 35-ish because all 6 of my workers charged into a golem as they attempted to repair a crappy tier-1 wall. Another time I died because a troll snuck around a wall somehow and the AI was too stupid to turn around to shoot it, so it walked almost completely unopposed into my base and wrecked everything.

- Further, you have no control over anything your units do, or even over the type of units they become. All of your archers dead? Sucks to be you, the game thinks you want farmers. Don't want your workers charging into an enemy horde to load a catapault or fix a wall? Meh, oh well. Don't want your farmers wondering into the wilderness to farm and then getting picked off like sleeping hens when the enemy shows up? Nope, can't stop that.

- The above two issues wouldn't even be issues if there was a way to grow your population on your own, but you can't do that. To get villagers you have to find camps and pay the campers to come live in your village. The problem with this system is that villagers are an extremely finite rescource and, as I said above, they kill themselves like lemmings and there is nothing you can do to stop this.

It's a fun game, it really is, but it feels like a mobile game in that it is hampered by bizzare shortcomings which cripple the gameplay once your past day 20-ish. If a fan would make a mod, or the dev would make a patch, this game could be amazing. As it is though, you may find it to be worth the 10 dollar price tag, but I can't really recommend the game in its current state.

reviewText:
After playing this game for 121 hours, I finally found a strategy to beat this game and at last finish it. My KINGDOM is now safe from harm and as an accomplished Warrior-Queen I can rule valiantly, knowing that my subjects can now retire and tell tall tales of their adventures while the war was still going on. All of the enemy is definite never to return, and my crown is secure, may be now I can think of a family instead of battles and defenses. It is settled, finding a gallant consort is next!

This game is absolutely amazing! It is time confusingly-repetitive, but in all honesty, the soundtrack alone, is such a beautiful creation, THAT YOU JUST DO NOT WANT TO STOP. Yes, the game crashes a lot, so save often! And I mean it. Even when you end up defeated, which with me happened way to often, you learn and enjoy the game play way to much.

I will most definitely re-visit this great piece of art of a game later, probably in the all new 2016.

reviewText:
Kingdom is a great game, and a very challenging one at that. Infact, one of my favourite moments is when you finally get past that day 20 blood moon for the first time. It is great value for money and my hours in game isnt a fair representation of the time i have on this game because i play it on other accounts too.

It has a very small tutorial and then lets you explore the world however you want, so much freedom and choice! The game will punish you for even the smallest mistakes and you will quickly learn, i reset countless times on the first day of playing.

Pros:

Amazing sound

Beautiful visual design, I love how well 2D looks in this game

Days and Nights are just long enough to get what you set out to do done :)

Each day has a new challenge, literally...

Your asthmatic horse adds a real challenge

The steam achievements are really something to aim for and you will find it hard getting them all

Cons:

Very laggy at end game gameplay (due to so many archers probably)

(Some people may question this) - There is a lot of freedom ingame as the tutorial doesn't hold you back but some people argue that only being able to place towers in specific points is lack of freedom? Well i agree to a certain extent (thats why it is a con) but that is a challenge in the game! The first 2 towers are always near your castle and the others have to be planned ahead of time, you cant decide to build a wall 200 yards out the night before a blood moon! You have to THINK AHEAD.

The AI is poor. You can literally run rings around those massive ogre things and they can't hit you and just wait until daylight. Your archers venture so freaking far out at day that they don't even make it back in time at night... I'm not sure why but that needs a fix. It is frustrating.

Lack of late game challenges. I am at the point, well i was long ago, where i could win the game in the click of a button but i want to see how far my castle gets me. I could easily send my knights out to the portals and win but i want to see what the game has instore very late. At night 30+ you have probably learned how to manage your money and will be constantly overflowed in cash. This is a problem as i really can't lose past day 30, it is too easy for late game. (Maybe the monsters could be stronger and have more hp late game? instead of just trying too flood my walls and my catapult can 1-shot them all?) that is just a suggestion.

The game will crash a lot! Especially when you have lots of archers, so save every day because it has happened, when you crash and load back 8 nights ago!

Why did i buy the game?

We have all been there, watching your favourite youtuber play a brand new series and get destroyed on the first episode. Then we all think, Ha! I could do better than that!" Well I couldn't. This game is very hard early game and as i have said
hoursPlayed: i absolutely love games where you can build massive armies and feel "powerfull". I certainly do now! If you like construction games or strategy or something like this in any way

As i have mentioned there is no tutorial but that doesn't mean go and search "how to beat kingdom" on google or youtube. The fun in this game is the fact that YOU make the mistakes and you have too complete it on your own!

reviewText: Sure there are things that make the game hard, but I like the idea behind it. Your job is to maintain the kingdom, the people in it are (mostly) autonomous which you'll have to find ways to make them do what you want other than just being able to command them. I personally love the gameplay and the aesthetic. The right amount of challenge and simplicity for someone who doesn't have hours to invest in learning a million hotkeys and unit types. 10/10 it's pretty good, worth what they're asking.

reviewText:
I was initially lured in by the game's cute premise and aesthetic, but unfortunately, its bag of tricks was exhausted rapidly, and after unlocking the limited amount of content available, the late-game turned out to be highly tedious. Once your kingdom stretches across the map, it takes very long to get anything done. Your units need an entire in-game day to get to near the edge of the map from your base in the middle - which might not be a problem in itself, if their AI weren't so dumb.

Your builders, for instance, have no survival instinct whatsoever and will march blindly into death's maw so long as there's a construction job queued up on the other side of it, so once you have a big kingdom, you'll assuredly lose those builders if you don't queue up the job at just the right time of day. Once they're gone, a new set of builders will notice there's an unclaimed build job available and head in to get mowed down, until you have no more builders left.

In a similar vein, if you upgrade a farm to a farmhouse, your farmers will congregate there at night regardless of whether it's actually safe to do so or not, instead of seeking shelter at your main base, and will consequently get slaughtered there every night if you don't have defenses built. The game does not feature the ability to cancel build jobs or demolish or deactivate buildings, and the issues are further compounded since manpower is a scarce, slowly-renewable resource in the game.

The poor AI is not the only issue that can lead to frustration in the late-game. As you expand your kingdom, the wilderness camps that function as your source of manpower in the game disappear, leaving you less able to recover from setbacks and potentially leading to a slow, yet inevitable and tedious loss by attrition. As the distances within your kingdom increase, you can end up spending a lot of time running back and forth around the map without a lot of progress to show for it. You can't send parties of more than 8 units to attack enemy portals - it seems peculiar that the strength of the enemy defenses scales up over time, but the amount of troops you can use when launching an attack is fixed at such a low amount.

Ultimately, Kingdom possesses an interesting initial premise and a charming aesthetic, and could become a good game if more content is added and its more egregious issues get fixed, but I find it hard to recommend it in its current state.

reviewText:
This game is simple, but addicting. I wasn't sure it will last me for more than few hours, and I usually don't approach games thinking that I'll stay up all night playing, but I got lucky here. This game is all about management and choices. It'll start innocent, but quickly becomes pure evil the more you hold on.
Gameplay
You control most of the things indirectly. You'll start small, and you'll make a lot of mistakes while trying to get bigger. I can't promise you that you'll get hooked the same way I did, but after having few tries on my own, I've started seeing the game differently. It is based around trying it over and over, and I didn't get sick of it. Despite what I've heard, every part, even the beginning, becomes an endurance run. Since you have to control everything, you can't stop.

I've played it at least 15 times and every time I've just tried better. This game isn't mainly about discovering new things, but about mastering the logic it's based on. Sure, sometimes I damn the developers to hell, but I think the fundamental gameplay is good for what it is.

Controversy
There are some people that are divided about some choices, or more precisely, the lack of them. They have usually played the game for few hours and then stopped, complaining about basics, like AI, or inability to control some things. While they raise some good points, I don't think they apply here. Because the game is so simple, it is essentially based around what they don't like. And that's fine. I think what they're asking for is a more complex game overall, because this is like asking for having advanced control over Lemmings. Also, I would love more complex version of Kingdom, so I'm hoping for sequel or expansion already.

Perhaps it could include an easy mode with some additional choices, because the way I look at it, this game is supposed to be beaten by trying over and over. I can't tell if it'll last 30 hours, but there are many people that have been mesmerized by games like Binding of Isaac, which is also based around playing it over and over. I've found out the hard way, that you can overcome the odds, if you just get prepared. The more you play, the more you plan ahead - that is the way I more forward here.

Don't get me wrong. The game is difficult. But it's difficulty doesn't come from poor design decisions or blatantly unbalanced gameplay. People that drop the towel early might not be into this, but if you just hold on, and give it few more tries, where you learn how to be more efficient, you'll be rewarded with progress. When something limits you, it's made so you can work with it - just like in chess, the more planning you do, the easier your progress will be. And yes, sometimes the random generators can screw you over.

And to be honest, there are problems with the late game, where you're mainly forced to run from one corner of the map to another. Apparently, the longer you wait with destroying the portals (your main objective, after you're comfortable with your defences), the more difficult it becomes to take them down, as you're limited with numbers of your attack party, but enemy defence spawn is infinite and increases over time. This is still being discovered by many invididuals on forums, but so far it seems like you can't take your time, which adds another layer of difficulty. You have to be efficient, and really fast. Once you get past day 30, portals become almost impossible to take down - it's doable, but frustrating and time consuming, not to mention that nothing significant happens at that point and you can play for hours, just running back and forth, without any tactics you had to employ at the beginning of game. I don't recommend trying to complete the game this way.

Presentation
It's pretty damn good. That is something we all agree with. Music is captivating and what more, along with the graphics it creates a great atmosphere, which I rarely see, especially in such simple game. Overall, great presentation helps you push forward as well.

Verdict
This is not a mobile game. It is a PC game, and games like this are rare. The simplicity mixed with indirect influence over your growing settlement is challenging and addicting. I don't mind losing, and I don't mind trying again, until I either succeed or eventually, leave with bruises and broken bones. Either way, I see myself spending way more than 10 hours that I've spend already and every hour was filled with intense planning and resource management.

reviewText:
This game has some of the most emotionally-engaging, postcard-esque ambient environments that I have ever witnessed. The music is literally a perfect match with the absolutely gorgeous pixel art work. When I load it up, it transports me to the fairytale. Few games do that. The attention is in the details, too. The way things move, and shifts from night to day. I cannot stop looking at it. It has a very zen way about it.

The experience alone is worth the ten bucks. Especially with headphones.

---

Now, lets get into the review about the game, and to some of the debatably negative points.

At the outset, this game screams mobile to me, because of the minimal controls. Minimal controls typically limit the amount of complexity you can have (and yeah, there are outliers, but in general thats the case). I argued ad nauseam with the devs about the mobile issue, which can be found on the forums.

The minimalism isn't just in the controls, though. It is also with the interface. The game literally tells you nothing onscreen as far as your clan status (no number of recruits, or a breakdown of any kind - it doesn't even give you a gold count per se).

There is a fine line in roguelite games in regards to hand-holding. If you offer too much, there is little reward for self-discovery that so many of us roguelite/like fans crave. If you offer too little, confusion takes over and we all begin to really question how smart the game is. Are there deeper mechanics here
date: or is it oversimplified?" (ie. Do archers in towers actually have better accuracy? I have no idea. This goes on and on.\n\nThe bottom line here: I wish you had more control over the game. It would violate the idea of minimalism
recommended: but would be a tradeoff for higher complexity
hoursPlayed: and thus strategy.\n\nAnother major gripe is the AI. This is true. I have no idea how to fix this

reviewText:
I was excited for this game for a lot of reasons. I love indie games, pixel art, procedurally generated stuff, and empire-building. This game has all four, but unfortunately, it is disappointing for a lot of other reasons.

Before I get to the bad stuff, let me tell you what's good about this game:

First and foremost, the graphics are beautiful. My god, are they ever! The attention to detail is simply incredible here. Pixel art can sometimes be lackluster, but this game was obviously a labor of love for its developers. From the fireflies flickering in the forest, to the gently trickling creeks and gorgeous gradients of the sunrises and sunsets, this game really pulls out the stops when it comes to visual design. It has weather effects, fog, and things you wouldn't normally see in a pixel art game. The animations of the characters are also quite impressive. Overall, the visual presentation is just wonderful.

Then there's the controls, which are incredibly simple and easy to learn. Literally, you just use the arrow keys to control your king (or queen). You can play the game one handed, if you like! You can also use shift to run, but double tapping left and right does the same thing. That's it.

The game also has nice music. While I'm not sure if it's good enough to be sold as a standalone soundtrack, it is very well composed, quite calming, and fits the theme of the game perfectly.

Now for the bad. Sorry, but there's gonna be a lot of it!

The gameplay, while solid in the early stages of each playthrough, becomes tedious and frustrating as your empire expands. Your soverign takes a while to ride around the map, and this is made worse by the fact that you ride an asthmatic horse who can't seem to run more than fifty meters without running out of breath. Yes, it is possible to eat grass in order to gain a stamina boost, but if the procedurally generated terrain doesn't have many patches of grass (and this is common), you are out of luck, you will have no choice but to plod along at the extremely slow walking pace about half the time. In the late stages of the game, this can become extremely problematic; it can take a full in-game day of riding to get from one end of the map to the other.

On that note, I should clarify that everything in the game is time sensitive; it becomes impossible to win after a certain amount of time has passed. You won't immediately know this, and you may futilely try to continue to build your empire, but you will only be wasting your time. The goal of the game is to destroy all of the enemy spawn portals, but the game only allows you to send eight soldiers out at a time to do this, so if the enemies have become too strong and numerous at that point you literally have no chance. The only reason to continue at that point is to acquire achievements, which may be fun for some, but for me, the slow realization that I was doomed and had to start the entire game over again was not a lot of fun (keeping in mind that there is no way to save multiple save files in order to rewind your progress).

The empire-building is kind of disappointing, too. You don't have any control over where you can place your walls, farms, arrow towers, etc.; this is all pre-determined for you. So, if the randomization is bad, your game will be bad, period. Your only role as soverign is to determine how well you can manage your resources within those limits, and oftentimes those limits will cause you to fail before you've even started. Shrines, for example, provide boosts to your minions and can be crucial for completing the game, but they may be very far away from your starting camp. If that happens, you are probably screwed. The same applies to recruitment camps; they are the only way to acquire new minions, and if you don't have enough camps readily available, you won't be able to replace your soldiers as quickly as you need to.

The worst part of the game, however, is the minion AI. They plod along at a ridiculously slow pace and will act strangely, particularly at times when you need them to come through for you. Archers, for example, will abandon their posts in the morning and walk miles upon miles to hunt rabbits. If your empire is large, I can guarantee you that they will not return to their posts in time for nightfall when the enemies come. This can be really, REALLY frustrating, and is another reason why finishing the game is often impossible. Another example is the workers and farmers, who aren't intelligent enough to know when the perimeter wall of your kingdom has been breached, and therefore refuse to retreat from their farmhouses. Since you lack the ability to give them orders, you have no choice but to watch them be helplessly slaughtered when the enemies come for them. Replacing them can be prohibitively expensive and time-consuming.

Also, efficiently winning the game requires some counter-intuitive thinking on the player's part. There are certain gameplay elements that should be ignored entirely. Arrow towers? They are useless, and consume your archers! Catapults? They provide boulders to the enemies who can use them against you! Both consume lots of gold that can be better spent otherwise. I found that the best strategy was to simply amass archers and leave them on the ground behind the walls. The community tends to agree on this. Since that is the case, it begs the question: Why would the developers include these gameplay features at all if they actively work against the player's chances to win?

The game also has very little replay value. After playing for a few hours, you've pretty much seen everything the game has to offer. The only differences between playthroughs come from the randomly generated terrain, and it's all just different configurations of the same stuff. This game could benefit from different scenarios such as snow, jungle, caves, etc., but right now all you have is the same riverside grassland and forest. Don't get me wrong, it looks great, but it does start to look a bit samey after a while.

The game is also buggy. It likes to crash, especially when you ALT-TAB, but also sometimes just for no reason at all. I also experienced continuous frame hitching despite the fact that my PC exceeded the recommended system requirements by a large margin. It didn't seem to matter if the game was fullscreen or windowed, the same hitching was always present.

If you're interested in this game but you're unsure of whether to spend your money, go play the free version on Newgrounds[www.newgrounds.com]. Its graphics aren't as pretty and some of the gameplay mechanics are different, but it's basically the exact same game overall. If like what you see and want to take the plunge, I would still recommend that you get this game on sale. In my opinion, the price tag for what you get is a little high.

EDIT: This game seems to have minions that know how to run, now. That's good! Unfortunately the game is still kinda boring. I might reinstall it again and replay it sometime soon, but then again I might not.

reviewText: A simple but beautiful little game that is both strategic and surprisingly addicting.  It's not meant to be easy nor will it hold your hand in the beginning stages.  But that's how it's supposed to be given how small it is in scale - you have to build until you figure out a method that is both efficient and long-lasting!\n\nThe only gripe that I have is the AI not balancing between both sides and not knowing when to attack/moving slowly to attack obvious targets.  I'm sure this will be fixed in an upcoming patch and I won't give this game a negative review for it.  It's an indie game made by an indie studio and based on feedback, I'm sure they will fix it in the future.

reviewText:
Man, we love throwing our gold at commoners.

In this game you will learn that a kingdom without a crown is nothing more than dust and whispers. As the monarch we are the bearer of the light that makes everything stand all together.

Let's go gather some future subjects of our kingdom. Oh ! But look at them crawling in their own dirt like unorganized monkeys. They reek like a british boy band.

“Here, you are barely a human life form lurking in the mud. Take my gold and go get some clothes on. Take a hammer and become a carpenter. Take a bow and go hunting and defending my walls at night time. Raise my kingdom as we raised you from your pitiful condition of tall ape. And don't forget : All your money is Ours.”

And when dawn comes, pray that the walls are high enough and that those archers will be able to land some shots.

Because nothing lasts forever, and maybe not tonight.

reviewText:
The game is punishing but fair early on, especially due to the almost completely nonexistent tutorials describing what actions will accomplish what goals. I still see no reason to expand - expanding makes it harder to keep track of everything, since your horse runs out of breath every few seconds, expanding requires exponentially more gold, as you have to build walls and towers every time you expand, in case you run low on money and can't expand again before the next blood moon, and expanding also doesn't seem to unlock anything.

Well, maybe it does! Who knows, without any kind of a tutorial  or indication of what it would net you? All things considered, the game benefits from the sparse introduction in most ways, but there's a difference between being brief but informative, and brief and unhelpful. This game is the latter, so far.

I should mention that it was only worth putting a review of this game up BECAUSE I DID LIKE IT - the idea is compelling, and pretty well done.

My main complaints are with:
- not knowing what actions to take (i.e. when you build your town center into a castle, what do the upgrades on the left and right sides do? Some sort of shield-looking thing? Defense? Attack?). Without knowing what actions to take, there's no way to decide between playstyles, or even if there are different playstyles that are viable. Looking up the answers would work, but cut out about 50% of the enjoyability of the game, which comes from the feeling of exploration.
Some small indicators, even little icons, would help with this problem. As of right now, I can't even tell if the 'farmer' job does anything at all, for example.

- incredibly short days, plus an anemic horse and workers. Running the horse until it's out of breath takes something like 10 seconds. It requires something like 15 seconds to recover. Doing that sequence once leaves you with most of the day gone already. In a game which *seems* to emphasize a little bit of exploration, it'd be nice if that exploration wasn't further punished (it already takes a fair amount of money to activate the interesting monuments). And the scouting/hunting archers often walk so slow that a couple don't even make it back behind the walls at night... even though they start at dawn! Even worse is when one of them is almost behind the wall, then stops to take a horribly inaccurate shot at an enemy that then proceeds to mow him down.
A 'fast' travel system, at least within built-up areas of the player's town, would help a lot. Maybe just make it a simple 'road' building task that costs a couple of coins, and which allows the horse to travel at super-speed within 'settled' areas. Better would be just a straight-up increase in the horse's speed across the board, since you can hardly get 2 screen-lengths over without it turning to night.
Alternatively, making the day-night cycle several times longer might help, though that would probably just make things more tedious.

Anyways... once again, this is a good, fun game with a couple of non-negligible issues that are un-fun. I don't think it's far off from being a game that I'd find highly enjoyable, with some additional content (which I suspect is planned) and some balance updates.

reviewText:
The game has great potential, the game is beautiful and the game mechanic is easy but fun. Yet the problem is that this games stands or falls with it's content. This meaning that at some point they ran out of time to make more content (buildings, upgrades, etc..) This would not be a problem on it's own. But the result is that the game continuesly tries to set you back to lengten the game.

When you conquer a portal they try to let you begin at square one by sending a huge wave of monsters as a respons to your victory. Even though you have coins enough you are unable to climb back up fastly because recruits are sparse on the map.

Some other thing i noticed that needs fixing is that the map is to huge for your horse. At some point you can travel the whole day going from one end to the other (A upgraded horse might do the trick).

They tried to keep the controls simple (1 button game.) but as a result you have zero control over your towers or troops.
This could be fixed by having a smarter AI, Being able to control the troops or destroying buildings.

reviewText:
I love the idea of the game. A progressive night time defense game. Although the graphics and sound track are perfect for the game, it needs a lot of balancing.

The blood moons are WAY to hard for the early game and even late game without the right amount of progression. Being in a watch tower stops the ground enemies from being attacked and provides decent defence. I wish that being placed in a watch tower made them actually land at least 75%+ of their hits to make it actually worth while. Even with higher upgraded towers, they miss about 50% of the time.

The slow movement speed of all of the workers makes recovery extremely difficult especially when you are a bit farther in the game where you are getting 7-8 enemies each night and having to micromanage your builders while you're out trying to recover your men (if you even have the gold to do so).

It would be better for recovery if the watch towers could attack animals as well and the deer didn't run away as much and had a tendency to wander closer/inside of the camp rather than having to run and chase after them and redirect them back towards the camp (the only way i can find to recover from blood moons).

Like i said though, idea of the game is really great, it just needs much much balancing. I would recommend the game if, the blood moons start to get progressively harder rather than right from the start being very difficult, or if the rate of recovery was much quicker. Maybe some sort of out of game upgrade system to spend points on from playing the game? Until then the game is extremely frustrating and needs lots of balancing. Not enjoyable.

reviewText:
A simple, minimalistic and gorgeous looking pixel art game.
Challenging but at the same time relaxing.
Are you the Master of Coin?
Play and find out!
Developer: Noio, Licorice
Publisher: Raw Fury
Release Date: October 21th, 2015

Do you know that feel … when you’re looking across the room and you see this beautiful someone looking right back into your eyes and you just know … I’m in love. Do you know that feel? You’ve really fallen for him or her even though you know that he or she is abusive and random like hell and will make your life miserable in a matter of minutes?

That’s how I feel about Kingdom.
Seriously one of my favorite games and one of the best I’ve played to this date.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=535976618
StoryThere’s not much known about the story besides that you’re a queen or a king struggling to build your kingdom and to help it flourish by spending every coin wisely.

Gameplay (Spoiler free)Why spoiler free you might ask?
Well the thing is that Kingdom is a very simple and minimalistic game. No one, besides a few that might have beaten the game so far, know what the win condition is. Sadly I’m not one of those. Scratch that. I’m actually happy about it! Does that seem weird?

If I had to describe Kingdom in one sentence it’d be: Easy to learn but hard to master.
Let’s start with the basics.
You start the game with nothing besides your crown, I mean you’re a king or queen after all, and your amazing horse.
There’s a small tutorial awaiting which will tell you, after you’ve picked up all of the coins, how and what to build with your coin.
But that’s all the help you’ll get. There’s not one ounce of any information inside the game that’ll help you. Nothing. Not even a single hint.

And that Ladies and Gentlemen is the beauty of Kingdom.
It’s up to you to find out all of the secrets this game holds. It’s up to you and your trusty horse to explore your surroundings, recruit people for your kingdom and to expand and defend your realm!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536106418
While exploring you’ll encounter two kinds of statues which will aid you in your quest to defend your Kingdom and another structure which will help you build it.

If you’re lucky enough you might even encounter a merchant or find a chest hidden in the depths of the forest.

In order to progress you have to upgrade your camp and help it prosper into a castle at some point.
There’s even a reliable source of income. In the morning of a new day, you’ll hear it trust me, you’ll find a chest inside your camp with some coins in it.
But that’s not the only way to get rich!
If you’re paying close attention you’ll see your archers, literally, murdering all those cute lil’ rabbits. That’s okay though because … COIN! That’s a hint for you that you can get coin from animals and rabbits are not the ones in the game.
Besides hunting there’s also another option to get some money.
If you upgrade your camp you’ll come to a point where you find a new merchant inside your camp.
If you buy the tool which he’s selling you will be able to farm.
You’ll just need a place with some water to get one.

This is as much help as I’m giving you about the gameplay. The charm of Kingdom is embracing every death and to learn from it.
Don’t be afraid to set out and explore and die. At the end of the day you’ll only be a wiser King or Queen and you’ll be able to build a bigger Kingdom in your next run.

So to sum it up.
You’ll have to earn and spend coin in order to recruit new people and expand your kingdom while defending it from enemies.

NightThe game features a day and night cycle.
Let’s talk about the night cycle briefly since the day one should be self explanatory.
When the night comes it’s time to stand your ground together with your people and to defend them and your Kingdom. That’s your duty as the King or Queen because  the night is dark and full of terrors.

Let’s make this short. When you’ll see that the moon’s about to rise it’s best to get back to your camp asap since the night is the time for the monsters to attack you.

There are different kind of enemies … Let’s just say that you’ll have to find the right strategy for every type of enemy.

If you pay close attention you’ll see a blood moon rising … if you’ve played Terraria you know that dangerous times are upon you and your people!
And if you haven’t played it well … be prepared. Truly prepared.

Master of CoinNot one of the Lannisters or Littlefinger you silly goose! It’s you! You are, well you have to become the Master of Coin!
By that I mean that you’ll have to figure out the best or rather your preferred way of earning money and how to spend it.
Do you need more archers? What about builders? Should you rather build a new watch tower or upgrade the wall?
Or should you set out into the wild to find out what those statues are there for?
Spending money is the easy part. Earning it and spending it wisely is the hard part.

VisualsIf you’ve read any of my reviews before you know that I love pixel art. So much.
But Kingdom … Kingdom is a true piece of art. It’s incredibly beautiful and gorgeous looking. There’s so much detail in the game. What I especially love about the game is the reflection of you and your surroundings in the water. Not only that. The atmosphere in the game is just beyond amazing. The game doesn’t look dull since there’s always something new to see. One day it’s raining and the other it’s a beautiful day with a clear sky and another day there’s a mysterious mist.
Just beautiful. The enemies look good and detailed and so does your Kingdom.
Overall I’m amazed by how good the game’s looking.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536106622
AudioSo good. Oh just so so good.
The music in the game is random just like everything else. That means that you might not hear all of the tracks for several hours.
After seven hours game time i’ve heard one track for the first time and loved it immediately.
The sound effects are amazing as well.
Your horse sounds awesome and the whole atmosphere.

The art style and the music combined make one beautiful looking and sounding game and turn it into a true master piece.

What else can I say?I have been lucky enough to get a Review Key for Kingdom in order to write a blunt and honest to God Review. Just as usual.

It’s amazing. Just one amazing game. It’s simple and minimalistic beauty.
There’s so much detail in the game. Also I feel like this is truly a game that everybody can play and probably will play unless you’re put off by the art style. If you are shame on you! You don’t have to love pixel art but be honest with me right now … It does look ♥♥♥♥ing amazing doesn’t it?
I can safely recommend this game for everyone who’s looking for a challenge and just needs a game to relax. I know that it does help me to relax.
To be completely honest I even believe that Kingdom might turn into a game that I’ll be playing for months if not years without getting bored. Unless I find the best strategy but I hope that the devs will crank up the difficulty by then and add more stuff for me and you, yes you!, and just for all of us to enjoy.
Seriously folks do yourself a favor and buy it.

reviewText:
Great indie masterpiece.

- Great pixel art / music
It manages to create the atmosphere that suck me into thinking that I am managing a kingdom under constant threat

- Great gameplay
This game has learning curve and strategies involved. Although I suspect that strategy that 'breaks' the game exists. I have spent nearly 30 hours and haven't figure this strategy yet (some player claimed to have done so). This  means this game does have some depth in it, although replayability might suffer IF you manage to find such strategy.

To get the most out of this game, I suggest that you follow these three steps
0) Try not to read guide (they are spoilers of your fun hour!)
1) Prepare to fail and learn from it
2) Repeat 2)
3) Once you have beaten the game, repeat 2) and optimize your gameplay

About the negative comments, I find most of them are unjustif. Perhaps the haters want a mobile-like tutorial that hand hold you on every single monster, or spent real $ to buy hint . If you set out an attitude to 'learn' this game, you will enjoy this hidden gem!


- About the negatives, let me give a more neutral view on each on them:

1) Horse too slow, get tired too easily
This is part of the game. You need to manage which area to sprint and which area to walk. And (spoiler), you XXX the horse, and it will run fast without tired. There is actually some 'game' for the otherwise boring movement, kudos for that!

2) AI too dumb
Not unexpected for rogue-like type of game. When player lose, they blame something, the AI is the major one. THE AI IS MEANT TO BE SIMPLE. It is so simple, so that you can expect what each of NPC does. This is learnable and

3) Arrow keep missing
This is part of the game, randomness is involved. This is basic statistic, you pit 1 archer VS 1 monster, you will see widely varying result (from monter win to archer win). But if you pit 5 archers VS 5 monster, you are almost guarantee the 5 archer wins.

4) Town people too slow
Again, this is part of the game, managing your subject and your empire. Deciding what to build at each day, realizing that you can't do everything at once is the fun part.

reviewText:
I feel conflicted about this game. It's great to look at and easy to learn, but its also very difficult to actually win and usually leaves you watching helplessly as your kingdom falls down all around you. I still enjoy playing it, but I do so somewhat grudgingly.
On the one hand, as many others have noted, the game's first impression is very good. The atmosphere it creates for you as you first jump into its world, from the supurb music to its wonderfully done 2D graphical style, is excellent. It's unique, and very immersive. You really do get the feeling of building a settlement from scratch in a mysterious and dangerous fantasy world, etching your kingdom and its people to victory.
As you start playing for a while though, Kingdom's problems become increasingly apparent. And they are not small problems. As a result of some seriously flawed design decisions, you come to realize that the game does almost everything it can to make you fail in incredibly irritating ways. It lets you hire citizens, but not control them, meaning they'll make incredibly stupid decisions like abandoning their posts at the worst possible times or let themselves die helplessly outside your walls. It lets you move around on your horse, but makes the world so big that it takes a huge portion of your day just to get from one spot to another on the map, all while your horse is constantly slowing down because it's too tired. It lets you send out raiding parties, but they too will walk so painfully slow that it will usually take an entire day or more for them to get to their destination. This means that unless you set them loose immediately after a Blood Moon, they will all die in transit, and you will then inevitably lose.
In general, this is a game that can only be beaten if you know how to exploit all of its inadvertant weaknesses, and do everything perfectly the same way every time. Its simplicity, charming at first. works against it in the end.

reviewText:
Disclousure: Review code supplied.

Before I begin, it's technically a spoiler to read anything about Kingdom.  The game is obtuse and slow on purpose.  It's designed this way so that the fun of the game is in the exploration.  And even though I really dislike games that pad game length with nonsense filler, Kingdom uses the speed of the game as a mechanic.  It took me 21~ hours to beat the game.  If you'd like to see some non-spoilery gameplay, I've attached a Quick Look at the end of the review which was a playthrough at the 5~ hour mark for me.

Kingdom is a real-time strategy game (with permadeath) where the playable character cannot attack or direct his troops.  Instead you can only recruit more people and upgrade your fortress.  After recruiting people from remote camps, you have to assign them jobs.

There are four jobs.  Five if you consider the different states of the archers.  Again, this info is spoilery.

Workers - The only class that can build or repair structures.  The only weapon they can fire is the trebuchet.
Farmers -  Can only generate money and will not attack.
Archers - In Defensive mode, they are able to Hunt and Gather" which is the only resource (gold coins) you need to collect.
Archers - In Offensive Mode
date: can only be toggled by creating knights.  Every Knight that is created will convert three of your defensive archers to offensive archers.  Offensive archers will not Hunt and Gather.\nKnights - The last class to unlock.  They can only be sent to do battle once you have a flag raised on either end of your fortress.  They are primarily used as a wall to protect your offensive archers
recommended: but they can attack anything directly in front of them.\n\nThe game has no story
hoursPlayed: but it's presentation is stellar.  The OST juxtaposed against the chunky yet serene pixel art produces this almost zen-like ensemble.  It is a rare game that can so purposefully 'waste' my time yet pull me in to unravel its mysteries.\n\nAdditionally
voteText: for the people with disabilities or for parents reading this
helpfulPercent: the game can be played one-handed.  So you can hold a child in one arm and use the arrow keys on the keyboard with the other.  This is a killer feature in terms of easy accessibility.\n\nPlease try to limit how much you read into this game if you're interested.  Only look for walkthroughs and other things if you are completely stuck.  Again

learning how to beat the game is the 'fun' of the game.

reviewText:
Saw a youtube video of someone playing this game and it looked right up my alley, I love innovative takes on the resource management genre.  At first, I was really enjoying this game, I enjoyed learning some of its foibles, failing, then starting over and doing a bit better every playthrough.

The game (purposefully?) does not really properly explain its mechanics beyond a very rudimentary tutorial, and you can find yourself in a position where you really can't win.  That's not too bad though, as the game is designed around multiple paythroughs, and failing and starting again using what you've learned can be fun.

Unfortunately, however, the game suffers from a number of game-breaking bugs, which makes it impossible to recommend, despite my early enjoyment.  Random crashes, switches to desktop, sound not turning on, AI and pathing issues of both friendly and enemy units, and, worst of all for me, the game failing to recognize I had beaten it, after a grueling session.  I may return to this Kingdom at a later date, but, for now, I recommend you wait until this one has had more time in the oven.

reviewText:
Fantastic, lovely, scary, calm. This game manages to project calm, beatiful melancholy and contemplative planning while almost simultaneously giving off a sense of rush as you explore, maintain, expand and oversee your titular Kingdom.

Replayability is there to be found: randomized setting for each game requires some variance to your broader strategy and priorities. The gently challenging nature of the game ensures all Kingdoms must come to an end, and even after a long game of struggle and survival it feels like there is still something I could do better on a fresh start. Meanwhile the achievements hint there are still things that can be accomplished in the first ~20 minutes of the game that I did not accomplish during my massive Kingdom that lasted two hours the previous night.

Clear design with minimalist controls (left, right to walk - double tap and hold to run; down (tap or hold) = action), beautiful scenery and effects pegged as modern pixel art" by the dev and the light soundtrack well-suited for the overall feel of the game all add up to a gripping experience."

reviewText:
You can enjoy it for a maximum of 3 hours. And that's stretching it, most people would lose interest after 2 hours and some after 1 hour. So lets say you get 2 hours of enjoyment out of this, is that worth 10 Euro? For me it's not, I compare it to a dinner out with my family at a simple restaurant and I enjoy that more than this. ( And I'm a huge beta nerd playing vidyas all day )

The late game is abyssmal, huge kingdoms that you can spend an entire day running through and there's nothing in them to see, it's all barren as you cut the forests down so no wildlife either. ( And wasting an entire day of just running through your kingdom is horrible as you have ♥♥♥♥ to do before night comes ). As others have said AI is abyssmal, and you need a ton of recruits but the problem is that recruiting people is a finite resource, and to expand your kingdom you have to destroy these camps where you can recruit people.

In huge kingdoms you gain so much gold your pouch can't hold it, and if you try to pick up too much gold the king or queen will throw the coins into the river, so picking up too much money makes you destroy money. In bigger kingdoms you try to avoid picking up money so you won't destroy it.

It's an interesting concept, with beautiful pixel art, but horribly executed. It's a good looking front with nothing in the back.

As you can see I got 7.3 hours in this game, I lost my enjoyment after perhaps 2 hours into the game, after that I simply tried to finish the game, I kept expanding, I tried stuff to see if there was anything I had missed to do to continue to progress my kingdom. But no, that was actually the end, I had done everything I could do except finishing the game. No matter how large I made my kingdom I could not make any more improvements. And improving your kingdom is basically what made the game fun. After 2 hours, I had done everything in the game. The rest of the time was wasted, I was simply confused as I couldn't believe I had already done everything.

I might play this again, to try to finish it, see what the end holds as the developers have been very secretive about it but I won't have any hopes that it will be good from what I've seen of the late game to be like. The worst would be if you win when you have expanded to the end of the world ( a bridge that you can't walk on ) if it's anything like that I will come back and edit this review.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This review was written using a press key supplied for free by the publisher

As an unnamed ruler your task is to take care of your kingdom, expand and survive the nightly raids of dark monsters each day: you do so by collecting coins from different sources (random loot chests, archers hunting animals, farms, etc) and using them to recruit followers, buy them tools and building/ upgrading both your main square and other assets (archer towers, catapults, walls, farms, etc). You can also explore to find mysterious shrines and statues that, when activated with coins, will bestow bonuses or unlock new construction options.
Do not be fooled by Kindgom's charming graphics and relaxing soundtrack, this is a very difficult strategy game with roguelike elements that asks you to try and discover its mechanics as you play, trying to learn from your mistakes and defeats: if you're up for the challenge Kingdom is an experience as demanding as it is rewarding.

PROS:

-gorgeous pixel graphics, the various weather effects are varied and very nice, there's also quite alot of details (dirt comes up when your horse runs, said horse pants when out of stamina, fields slowly grow etc)

-great soundtrack, I appreciated how it dinamically changes depending on time of day/ weather

-really nice sound design, the ambience sounds change depending on where you are and what time is it

-the mix of kingdom building, nightly defence and exploration works well

-decent amount of things to build and upgrade paired with mysterious artifacts to activate through coins

-appropriately difficult, expect to restart quite a few times before you get the hang of how things work, and then some more when some new monster or a particularly difficult raid comes up to ruin a defence you thought was good enough: conversely when you manage to survive longer and expand it feels really good

-considering its difficulty and the lack of hand-holding beating the game will not be a quick affair

NEUTRAL:

-the difficulty and lack of guidance, paired with the need to restart each time, won't be everyone cup of tea

-some design choices in how things work and how the AI reacts will require you to work through the costraints bestowed upon you to be successful (e.g. recruited NPCs will grab the first tool on their path, no way to cancel construction, clear a turret, switch NPCs jobs or assign archers to a certain wall): this will also feel limiting and rather frustrating to some

CONS:

-the lack of hand-holding and information on how certain things work/ change can feel a bit too much at times, bordering on too cryptic

-NPC's speed feels a bit too slow

-basic archers aim is a bit hit ot miss (heh) they'll sometimes try to shoot through solid walls or have problems hitting moving targets: thankfully hiring lots of them and/ or upgrading their firing speed makes things better

-the aforementioned AI gimmicks can make certain actions and nightly defence harder than they'd be

-once you'll finally manage to beat it the replay value is questionable, since there's no difficulty levels, leaderboards or similar stuff

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=536087923

Kingdom has been a good experience for me so far: slowly building, upgrading and expanding while trying to survive raid after raid feels both rewarding and thrilling. You won't have permanent unlocks or similar stuff but each playthrough will give you some knowledge of how things work, how to set up your economy or how to deal with the various monster types. This gives, imho, enough sense of accomplishment to make you want to give it a go again. The truly gorgeous graphics and soundtrack also make Kingdom a very nice thing to look at and listen to.

So what's the drawbacks? Well, the difficulty can feel brutal at times and seeing your Kingdom razed over and over might frustrate you and make a break ncessary. The tutorial explains the very basics and nothing else, after that understanding how things work can be hard at times since certain nuances in AI behaviour or building unlocks can be hard to spot: this means you'll have to be patient and be ready to try things and spend coins on something without knowing the exact result. Last but not least the design choices mentioned in the Neutral/ Cons section will also require you to jump through hoops, lest you fail at what you wanted to do if you forget how the NPCs behaviour works in certain circumstances.

Kingdom is not a game for everyone due to its difficulty,but it's a really good game nonetheless and it truly excels when played by its target audience, that is those looking for a difficult game with little hand-holding that requires you to become really good at it to have a chance of finally beating it. People interested in the game but afraid of its hardcore setup might want to wait a bit to see if anyone writes a few guides to help them: this will probably mar the exploration/ learn-as-you-go aspects but will also help immensely with easing them into Kingdom's gameplay: do note that I think no guide'd make the game a walk in the park though, so be mindful of its roguelike inspiration.

reviewText:
I hate, I mean really really hate, to say I don't recommend this game. I'm sure you've already read that this game has issues, but beleive me it does.

I'll start by saying I love the game. Simple, fun, great time killer. The pixel-art graphics are incredible, the music is enjoyable and the overall feel of the game impresses to no end.

Ultimately, however, too many frustrating elements pull together to ruin an otherwise fantastic experience. Take the AI, for example. Stupid as all hell. You can't control where you place you're citizens, you can't stop them from charging mindlessly into a hoard of enemies, you can't have them do... anything.
The game also starts to feel dull quickly. You either get king or  a queen and their either or black or white. And they're purple. I'm not sure if this is an issue just for me, but the fact that the enviroment and its monarch never really change means that you feel like your replaying the same doomed prophecy over and over. Just a little bit of variation is all I ask. Perhaps a different enviroment, like say a desert or something. Perhaps you could 'choose' a different style of building? I'm not sure exactly.
The difficulty is also far to much. The  'blood-moon' horde attacks are impossible, unless you rush, to defend against even after tonnes of preperation.

So, I'll say it again, I love this game.  I want people to understand that the game is fantastic. It just needs some ironing out.

reviewText:
----****SPOILER FREE REVIEW****----

Great game. I can confirm that the negative reviews that complain about the game being buggy or not managable in some way is either because the person expected this game to be an action defense game instead of the strategy defense game that it is, or because the person dosen't understand some sort of aspect of the game or some part of strategy and instead of trying to learn on thier own by understanding what caused the failure(which is part of the fun of the game) or giving up and looking for information in a wiki or video they instead claimed it as a bug, called the game defective and wrote a negative review(there are many of thoes reviews).

There were a few quality of life issues that could have been addressed in the first version but they would have caused a great unbalance in the game. The developers have since created a great update fixing the quality of life issues and updating the artwork and menu, as well as adding some new content and features, and re-balanced the game.

I didn't pay full price but having beaten it several times, would have and consider it worth it. The only recommendation I would give, as it is one of the things I regeret doing before buying,  is you can get more hours of entertainment if you don't watch any videos of this game or read lots of reviews and check forums and stuff(unless you can't figure something out and just give up and want to know) you will find many things that are spoilers and once you learn them you cannot unlearn them or learn them on your own from understanding why you failed

reviewText:
Such a simple game with such a lot of nice details. As someone who has done pixel by pixel animation I can say don't let the screenshots fool you, the animation is excellent, I hope the tools have improved :).

The gameplay couldn't be easier - left and right to go, well, left and right. Down to feed coins.
The game on the other hand is a little less easy, you have to stay on your toes and pay attention to whats's going on.
The characters remind me of lemmings, vaguely, in that person represented by big dots way, something about the eyes :)
Music is deceptively immersive, very melodic and I cannot imagine any other music being more perfect for this game.

For under a tenner this is a very fun game. I started it to try it out, 2 days later(not solid-6hrs) on day 111 I made a stupid mistake - just fyi if you turn your back on an enemy troll throwing a rock - your crown can fly backwards!

New patch speeding up the horse is a Very welcome addition

Conclusion - it is a very nice game, fun and easy to play(one hand required only) and as for the price - totally worth it, the craftmanship in the game is wonderful.

reviewText:
Sometimes, it's not good to be the King OR Queen for that matter. Why? In Kingdom you have this regal title and everybody will live or die depending on your decisions. Spend your precious gold wastefully and you will be missing your crown in no time. No crown, no Kingdom. On the other hand, if you spend your gold wisely, knights, treasure, and glory, awaits you at the edge of the forests in the form of dark portals, spewing evil every night. Overcoming this evil won't be easy but it will be hell of satisfying. Kingdom takes everything about strategy games and deconstructs it in perfect form. Keeping the complexity and difficulty of the genre but making it so simple that anyone could play it. This is what makes the game so fun and extremely addictive, as you learn from your mistakes in the last Kingdom and improve with your next. However, sometimes the fates are just aligned against you as Kingdom does also feature random events and areas. One Kingdom may be blessed with farms nestled neatly by its side and another barren and dry. If the games mechanics and excellent pixel art didn't entice you enough, Kingdom also has many layers of secrets to it. What lies beyond the dark portals is still a mystery to me and I feel like I was constantly discovering something new and hidden in the forest. It's this mystery and exploration tied with the Kingdom management that will take away hours of my life gleefully. Simply put, Kingdom is a fantastic game and worth your attention!

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/CEUe7KH16R0
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr
