reviewText:
This key was obtained from the developer for the purposes of the review.

Summary:
Kingdom sets its self up to be a game that could have rivaled the kingdoms of Sparta or of Genghis Khan, but immediately falls apart and collapses under its own weight. The game has a beauty to it that's not necessarily tied to its pixel artstyle, but more due to its animation quality and the little touches such as dirt kicking up as you gallop along. And it's a bit different with elements of tower defense, strategy, and base building games all rolled into one. And the game will keep you interest in its first hour or two. But then the signs of the games lack of content start to rear its head. The game shows its interest in the IOS platform because of its lack of controls and mechanics that it presents: the game's simple gameplay becomes repetitive rather quickly. Despite it being designed to be replayable, after two or three attempts: the game has really shown you pretty much its bag of tricks, and that's a major problem in the design area. Your lack of the control of your units will get you frustrated as they wander off doing what you don't want them to do, and you'll feel disconnected from everything that's going on around you. In the end, it won't be enough, and I have to say skip even at the game's lower price.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://youtu.be/QzbCfJy4pEg

Lists:
+:
Well put together soundtrack that's definitely worth repeated listens. Good sound design all around.
Game's aesthetic hits the little touches better then most other games, with dirt coming off the ground while galloping around, or the detail on tents that you look at. Very well done design wise.
The game is unique with its elements of tower defense, strategy, and base building. Interesting ideas at the core of the game.
For the first hour or two, you'll have some fun. But then....
-:
It won't last. Too little variety despite the procedurally generated levels creates a bit of a problem in a game designed to be repeatedly replayed. You'll see all the game has to show in 2 hours, or at least at its basic level.
Lack of control over units means that you're a passenger rather then a direct manipulator, and you'll feel the frustration of that when attacks that might have been able to prepare for if you had a bit more behind you can't be done. You can't prepare at all in any reasonable way.
No ways to see what's really going on in the majority of the field which sucks considering the view angle. Some will say that adds to the challenge, but frankly, it doesn't really add much to it, considering  the limited gameplay in question.
I think with the combinations of other points on this list: the game attempted to go too realistic in its portrayal. Which is a problem, because what it does is hurt the game's fun factor.
The game plays slow, and I'm really unsure of why you'd add the stamina mechanic in the game that slows down gameplay even more.
It shows its IOS aspirations with the limited controls and frankly lack of options.

reviewText:
An awesome little indie game with a great pixel art style and simplistic controls where you build a little kingdom and protect it from swarms of enemies.  Pretty simple in its design and very well done.  Easy to get the hang of after a while.

My only gripe with this game is the fairly terrible AI of your archers, knights, and builders.  They seem to just throw themselves into harms way.  Especially if a wall is flagged to be built but does not yet exist.  Little things like this can easily be fixed with the AI paying attention to the existing states of objects (for protection).

Other than that, the game is pretty challenging and, while repetitive after a while, a lot of fun to play.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a gem. A small little RTS game were you can only go left right and drop a coin, but with an incredible attention to detail. Every thing has a purpose - the sun rises, rain, grass patches forest clearings. The fun of this game is figuring out how all the systems work together to win. It is the first game I have played that feels like leaving it all and taking a camping trip. From experiance, I could write down a list of tactics that will insure victory, but the fun of this game is feeling like a pioneer - going into a strange new world, learning how nature works and then taking advantage of it. I recomend playing this game without any idea how it works and discovering it for youself.

Some people say certain parts of game are frustating, but I don't think they have really master it. Some of their complaints I see as feature, like balancing your expansion to get resources but not making yourself too big (don't be afraid to make very small kingdoms.) My record is beating the game on day 19. Just know when you are playing, you don't just have to survive, you have to take the offensive. And getting the day 1, 2, 3, ect achievements will teach you features of the game.

I've played this for about 40hrs and have not gotten tired of it. This is totally worth it, buy it!

It also has a subcontext of capitalism as warfare. You can't attack, only pay money, and when your villagers are hurt, they drop their coin you hired them with, they don't die. To be sucessful, you have to manage your money. The monsters don't want to kill you, only get your gold. If you are hit with no coins, you drop your crown, and you lose if the monsters get it. When you are playing, you feel attached to your villiage, becuase you need them and they need you to rule them.

My only complaint is it starts running slow if you want to make it till day 100 which requires a huge army. Also when the view is scrolling, the paralax isn't in sync, trying to keep it authentic retro I guess. I wish it scrolled smoothly to make it easier on your eye.

5/5

reviewText:
First off, let me say that I like the concept and the graphic design of this game, the soundtrack is amazing and it really immerse you if let yourself sink into it.
BUT
Even though I only played 2 hours up until now, I dont know if I'll be playing more.
Let me explain, the AI of the characters you recruit makes it extremely frustrating to progress through the game.
Mainly because some the characters (that are not suited for combat) seems to be fearless! They will try to go out of the walls (If there is a job to do, doesn't need to be one you commanded it could be just to recharge the balista) even if there are monsters knocking on the walls and you cannot do anything about it. You cant tell them to stay inside you cant really control their mouvement, they are just gonna go and do whatever they want basically.
The archers... they will miss their shot about 50% of the time AND will not attack wildlife ( Wich gives gold, your primary and only ressource as far as I seen) if they are on a turret. It is extremely frustrating to see the monsters and wildlife going around not being killed or simply missed 2-3 shot in a row.

The balista...It will shoot at the sight of a single red-eyed monster. Soo if there is like 10 or more behind it wont hit them cause the balista was fired for only 1  (The balista does ALOT of damage and could greatly help on red moon if only it shot the whole pack) and then it needs to be reloaded by builders wich could be all over the place and by the time they get there the wall might be destroyed making it impossible for the builders to get through basically meaning you'll loose their tools and their services to you.
Also I forgot to mention that the archers seems to have no understanding of proper positioning within the camp, unless you build a tower, they could (and most likely will) gather up all on 1 side leaving the other side with 1 or 2 guy to defend and their is no obvious way to tell them to go somewhere, they just do as they please.
When they loose their tool and wont follow you it means you then have to hire them AGAIN and purchase all their tool AGAIN.
Making really frustrating to progress through.

Depending if any fixs are made to those issues (if they are issues, if those are intended then I suspect the whole game is just you learning the management and then getting lucky on where your NPCS decides to go, wich is not to great)
I migth change my opinion but until then I dont recommend it.

reviewText: They would have to fix some things before I try this again.  The bowman are walking every direction but the last wall.  I have so many coins and bowman, the game lags, but are the bowman standing anywhere near where I need them?  No.  One more wall close to the portal maybe?  Only if we cut down a tree that brings the entire band of baddies out the portal during the day.  Oh, and that marked tree brings a neverending stream of hammer brothers from the most distant parts of the kingdom so they can all march to their doom, since I can't cancel the request.  Meanwhile I have to ride my trusty exhausted steed for 2 moons to get back home to make 4 bows at a time for the 30 jobless minions marching possibly 4 moons to get a tool and another 4 moons to reach their doom again.  Why do I have to walk my horse for 2 moons to make my own bows and hammers?  In one try, the knights stood right on top of a farmer's field, so every time I tried to pay them to attack, I accidentally upgraded the farm, thus leaving farmers there to draw out a constant stream of baddies to destroy my knights who must be pumped out 50 miles away.  Arg.  This game was released too soon and needs a whole new version to make it playable.  I'm on day 80 with 3 portals down and the last unwinnable.  Don't waste your time on this game until they fix it.

reviewText:
I really wish that I could give a positive review to this game, but I can't. It has all the ingredients for a great game, but it has too many issues that are game breaking.

The good: the art is amazing and the animations are really impressive. The controls are simple and the gameplay is very intuitive and fun.

The bad: it has game breaking bugs (not crashes, but bugs) and performance issues.

The worst bug I've seen so far are shields not working properly. You need shields to assign knights that can attack portals. For some reasons the shields get stuck up high and no one picks them up, thus it's too hard to attack the portals directly.

The performance is really bad when nearing the game's end. When a giant throws a rock and a bunch of arches drop their bows the game gets stuck for several seconds, even a minute can pass where the game is stuck like that.

A gameplay annoyance is that your kingdom gets too big for you. When a red night comes and you are on one side of the map and need to travel to the other it takes forever! That's kind of ok, that means you need to prepare better, but there's no way to tell which side the horde will come (not that I'm aware of), just that the sun looks red before a red moon. And then you gallop from one end to the other and everyone is throwing money at you and it gets laggy and annoying.

The game is too short as well, but I hope the developer fixes this by adding more content over time (I really hope that's the case, but they are in no obligation to do this).

All in all, I really enjoyed the game, but I can't recommend it until these issues are fixed, specially performances and bugs.

reviewText:
This game has a great atmosphere that sucks you in. Dont be turned away by bad reviews from people with many gameplay hours(they loved the atmosphere and game too!) The day night cycles and weather effects really make this game. It gives you the survival feeling that you want.  There is something fantastic about waiting in your camp late at night wondering which side of your camp will get attacked or a foggy morning when you cant tell what time it is and you feel even more rushed to get everything done before night.

I will say the weakness of this game is the towers.  when you first play this game you will put upgrading towers as top priority but the truth is towers actually dont help you overall.  The first game I played knowing that I shouldnt waste money on towers, was the first play through that I felt like I was really ahead. If I could change something about this game I would say make towers more useful. My ideas for this would be make them come with archers or make them really good at killing the flying enemies. New players dont know that they are wasting money on something that isnt helping them. I have also read that there should be another way of getting citizens besides camps and I agree with this as well.  Running around gathering citizens contantly isnt everyones favorite type of gameplay.

I think alot of the negative reviews are because people love this game soo much it bothers them tremendously when the difficulty gets too hard for them, especially when you've put hours into building your defenses and economy.

Part of me knows that everyone has an opinion about how to make this game better.  I think that if there was a side sandbox mode where people could customize there gameplay settings , difficulty, people etc.  that these same people wouldnt have a reason to give this a bad review.

reviewText: KINGDOM is a Castle Defender with a unique GAMEPLAY element, you have no direct control over your kingdom and it's subjects. Instead, you are a lone monarch riding(sidescrolling) on horseback across your land populated by animals, people and monsters. So it is up to you to grow, expand and defend. That's all the info I want to give on this subject because half of the fun is learning how to play. I've read reviews complaining about the AI of the NPC's in the game, but I think that is a great design flaw"
date: because it requires the player to actually think about their choices and plan ahead before deciding what is the most optimal strategy. (I beat the game on my second playthrough so it really isn't that hard.) As for things I would like to see in the future. I wouldn't mind a little more variety to keep me interested all the way until the end because once I had come up with the winning strategy it because a game of repetition. I'm sure that the developers know though and are already cooking something up.\n\nThe GRAPHICS are not cutting edge but thats okay
recommended: they are very stylistic and although the characters and environment are essentially blocky
hoursPlayed:
pixilated blobs it's done beautifully. The way everything reflects in the water and the ever changing sky keeps you immersed in the experience. Kingdom is a sidescroller that feels oddly expansive. I hope for seasonal changes and different environments in future patches and expansions.

The MUSIC is one of the best features of this side scrolling defender and they offer an option to purchase the game with the soundtrack. Which may be a good idea because it has many a stellar compositions that add to the games mystique and environment. I have nothing bad to say about the sound design and music.

For a more challenging experience I suggest playing it without looking up and walkthroughs. You will find the experience much more rewarding when you eventually do figure things out.

I would give this game a 7.5/10 which may change depending on what they have planned for the future."

reviewText:
TL:DR

The game is… worth 10 dollars, but ultimately tries to be more, and fails on delivering a satisfying experience at either the 10 dollar price point or above.  There was some satisfying early game, dull mid game and downright tedious end game pre-patch.  Post patch is nearly identical, except the end game has been completely broken.

Complete Review (possible spoilers)

Couple of things to get out of the way.  Just because you put RNG (or RMG as one review called it) or whatever you want to call it in the game, does not mean it adds anything.  If RNG is not adding replay to the game, then why is it there?   What’s random and how does the RNG impact your gameplay:
- There are 2 shrines which buff your towers/walls or archers.  They can either be close to you, or behind gates.  Generally if they are both behind gates you might as well restart your map.  If one is behind gates you can work to free it before killing gates becomes a lost cause.  This adds no replay and in fact ruins some starts causing the RNG to essentially ruin a gameplay without adding anything quirky or fun.
- 1 upgrade building, which really doesn’t matter where it spawns.  Just run to it quick and you will never need it again.  Doesn’t matter if it is far or close, as long as you get it out of the way quick.  No replay here either.
- Wall and tower placement, fields with rabbits, peasant camps and mill spots.  These add some variety to layout, but largely will never impact your gameplay what-so-ever.  They seem to be less random as well, in that your start is pretty set with tower/wall after your initial castle area.  Peasant camps seem to be more accessible on the east, less on the west (adding to an already tedious ride across the kingdom mechanic).
- Maybe some chests… which offer a minor boost in the form of gold and aren’t worth going out of your way for.  Most I have seen is 1 on either side, sometimes so far past gates you really could care less about them.

None of these being random adds to the excitement of a future play.  Rogue, Dwarf Fortress and other well done RNGs get narrative out of adding in random elements because they have deep gameplay.  This game is so simple it just feels like getting a 2 when you needed a 4 to hit on a D6.  Arbitrary and characterless.

Gameplay is nice at first.  Unlike many reviews, I found not knowing what I was doing to start refreshing, and avoided looking up let’s plays and “how to” guides.  I felt, pre- the first patch, that the gameplay was right on early game.  There were things to do while your kingdom was small (recruit peasants and herd deer towards your archers), and later you could run around upgrading, finding merchants and setting up an economy of farmers.

Once your kingdom starts to grow, however, some interesting mechanics start to fight against you.  If you fully upgrade the castle your taxes get nerfed (mitigatable by having a healthy economy, but really adds nothing).  Expanding, especially to the east, can remove your source of peasants (again, mitigatable, but really not enjoyable).  Expanding your kingdom large enough and it takes nearly a day to get across the whole thing, which is brutally tedious.

Knights are far too few and attack parties far too weak post day 40 pre-patch.  You can destroy gates, but it requires a strange mechanic of tanking for your attack parties and throwing wave after wave at the gates.  Peasants move so slowly back to your castle to get equipped, that you can really only attack once every 5 days, which added to the tedium.  Post patch you will never have this much time, so you will simply lose if you haven’t killed off 3/4ths of the gates early enough.  Also clearing a side doesn’t mean that side is safe (though it may post patch)

Pre-patch, the game felt manageable in the long term, but boring and tedious.  Post patch you just get frustratingly eaten away with no re-course, as every night spawns way to many, what I will call wraiths and trolls, killing off your peasants and chewing up buildings faster than your peasants can actually walk to construct them.

The patch dropped mid-game for me, and totally destroyed my longest run.  I had one half of the map cleared, but can now do nothing to stop the waves of wraiths and trolls that come every night.  Pre-patch I felt I could probably win if I stuck to the boring tedious mechanic of attacking once every 5 days, now I am just waiting to lose.  The game hints that you need to win quicker with its achievements for wins within 25-40 days.  But now the surviving to day 100 seems impossible (where before the others did).  Prior to writing this no one has those achievements according to the global stats.  Now with the increase in cost to attack, I think both are going to be nearly impossible.

The patch is an extremely confusing answer to the criticism they have got so far.  Ultimately, the game is a nice little diversion, but not a satisfying experience in full.

reviewText:
Really wish I could recommend this game, but I cannot until it is fixed.

You get to a point mid-late game where you have already destroyed all the portals on one side, you have more money than you can carry from farmers, and you have a huge stack of archers and fully upgraded defenses on the one side where there are portals left.

However it's frustratingly difficult to take the third portal down. This is because the seige ogres and waves of enemies will overcome any defense. The catapult is supposed to help with large groups by doing splash damage but it has two problems 1. It is horribly inaccurate and almost never is able to hit things that are right up against your wall and 2. it has to be re-armed by builders, but they don't come running to it from wherever they are loitering at until the first shot is already fired. Oftentime, the catapult will fire one shot at the very first enemy and miss, and by the time the builder gets over to it to re-load it that wall is already decimated.

You also run into a problem where expansion means that you are not able to replace your population. If you expand into a nomad camp they dissapear. The nomad camps are the only way of getting more peasants. You HAVE to expand to get close enough to the portal, But while you are expanding to get your knights close enough you will encounter a blood moon or two and your population will be wiped out. I've tried leaving 3 camps on the side that Ive destroyed to portals but it takes a day and a half just to walk there and back to recruit 6 peasants.

After several playthroughs, my past experiences were too frustrated and boring to play this game again.

Also I had a crash once when running by a bunch of my farmers, I think there was too much gold flying out all over the place at once.

One playthrough I got to day 90 and wasn't able to march my knights the great distance to the 3rd portal before night would fall and spawn all the monsters that would kill my knights and kingsguard before they could get to the portal. Tried to build pas the nomad camps that I was saving and I was able to build up right next to portal...but the blood moons were at the point where they were spawning way too many fliers who would eat all my archers and too many ogre guys to deal with.

Another playthtough I had the two left portals destroyed before day 30 but just got too frustrating at running all the way across the map several times just to get population enough to defend my right side.

I think to beat the game you MUST get a map with the archer shrine. I had the builder one which makes your walls stronger on my 90 day playthrough and no shrine at all on the other one.

reviewText:
This is a good game to the point when it gets so frustrating. first the pros:
-First the positives good simple builder survival game.

-Wery fun in the begining and wery adictive.
-Good soundrack
-good chalenging gameplay at the begining of like 30-40 lvls.
-simple and quick to learn mechanics.

Now the cons
-This game has so so few units u have archers(def/atack gate with comm) and comander/soldier(atacks gate when activated) that u can recruit. Enemys have basicly 3 types flyer walker(with masks) and heavy.

-U can build only defences, farms and towers. U can upgrade them but thats it. Then in forest u have upgrade totem, 2 buffs and camps which provide u with aditional troops(be carefull dont expand to quickly/ some camps u can leave in ur domain if u leave one tree on left and rigth u will still get the units).

-Game will become frustrating when u reach certain turn/day. I was on lvl Lx and i had like 0 problems of survival cause demonic army just vanished on daybreak. They didnt eaven get halphway in one side when there is a red moon. Problem starts when u are replenishing forces. U cant destroy tower or tell ur soldiers to not ocupy them, so u end up refiling ur troops in 10 turns on front line, and have like 10 useless fully manned towers. That would be ok but it takes 1 day till the peasant get to the castle where he grabs tool...

-Game gets that fealing of rouglike. But i played this game for achievements and the camps were at the same positions so idk but it seems to me that it is the same map. I found some buffs and gates in other locations, but the first 4-5 walls around camp were the same mby i just got lucky idk.

-THE DEER oh dear lord its simple... u need to get in front u change direction, and then lure them into ur archer. problem is when it gets bugged and the deer just doesnt lose agro eaven when u run with full stamina to the other screen. the deer just dont stop. but mby its randomized by a chance so its another small thing, that is frustrating or not that transparent.

-Ai of the workers - just so bad

Overall for me it was not a chalenging experience. It took me 3 tries to figure out the best strategy. The achievs hlp also like a guide when u farm 8 archers on turn 1 u will be ok first 5 turns. When u get many deer u will have 0 problems with gold. The game gets long and frustrating the higher days/turns and doesnt offer much of a chalenge when u have farms on both sides and good defences u just keep replenishing troops and thats it.(It takes a long long time).

Its good game but w8 for steam sale not worth full price.

reviewText: I'm going to start off by saying that I really like this game, the concept is great, the gameplay is mostly enjoyable and the music is superb, however, this game could be improved upon quite a bit, the AI for your people is lacking, the options you have as the king is mediocre and overall you just don't have enough control over your people which ends up getting them killed. An example of this *SPOILERS is when a blood moon rises and you know its going to be bad but instead of being able to tell your farmers and builders to go to the town center for saftey they will just meiander outside the saftey of your walls and be killed, well stolen from then unhired which is an odd mechanic. Your archers have no sense of direction, they will bunch into a group on one side leaving the other side nearly un defended. Basicly, this game could be made to be SOOO much better if you just tweak the AI a bit, and give the player some more control over their kingdom. Have a panic horn so your defensless, run into town or all of your archers run to defend the side that is being attacked. But as it stands right now, and despite the multitude of issues I have written here, for 10$ this is an enjoyable experience and I would highly reccomend it, I just hope they come out with a patch sometime soon to fix these tiny little issues that really bug me. Either way, Spend your last gold peices on this game and don't bother with building that wall, there is no way it would be a blood moon tonight..

reviewText:
TL,DR: This game has so much potential, the effectively game breaking problem is the AI seems to have no idea what it is doing means that what could be fun becomes frustraiting and repetitive. A lack of control for the player is fine but only if the game works in predictable ways, your men dont, makes the game annoying as hell. No idea if there will be a patch to fix it but if it remains as it is, I would have opted for a refund/not bought the game.

The game revolves around spending coins to muster a defence against trolls, your coins hire people, buy thier tools, build defences such as walls and catapults. The problem with the game is painfully simple, the things that protect you cost money and end up costing you far more than they should: I was on day 10 and my archers were hunting during the day to produce more coins, when it came to the troll assault in the evening they didnt even attempt to retreat behind a wall i had built, 10 archers cost 30 coins, during the day they made me nothing as it was a rainy day and there was nothing for them to catch, so they cost me 30 coins, you need the archers to defend your kingdom but they're so stupid that it's always a loosing battle, i get thats kind of the theme of the game but this is a ridiculous way to go about it. It's not an exclusive problem for archers, farmers and builders make the same damn mistake and it end up throwing the game into a hopeless and pointless mess. Can't recommend as this 'bug' makes it frustrating to progress and it's through the players lack of control and the AI's poor decision making, one of those things needs to change for me to reccomend it. At the moment the game is pointless but with so much promise. I hope things change with later patches but at the moment it's most certainly not reccomended.
voteText: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Kingdom is a wonderful game, no doubt about it. The concept is simple, you hire builders, archers and farmers to build walls, farms and watch-towers. After watching multiple playthroughs of this game by different people I finally snuffed out how to do well, not a bad thing. However, my experience playing Kingdom was somewhat ruined by the awful archer AI. Surprisingly I'm not actually talking about the aim that the archers have, oh no, I'm actually talking about a game-breaking glitch that leaves me with no other option but to restart the entire game.

For some reason the archers who aren't in watch-towers (including the guard's archers) would suddenly stop moving and not fire any arrows whatsoever. I'd eventually get over-run by the attacking force but I found it too cruel that this glitch ruined an entire Kingdom and a couple of hours work. I haven't had many playthroughs but this glitch has sometimes happened near the start (after the destruction of the first gate or so).

Everything else about the game is pretty good though. It has replayability as it's challenging and every playthrough is different with the upgrades being randomly placed each time. You also have to use your head whilst playing and plan out which gates to destroy, as there are only so many camps you can reach to hire people. I love a lot of things about the game but I feel there just isn't enough as of yet.

I'm really excited to see what goes on after this first small period of the game's release. Personally, I'd love to have more upgrades and maybe even adding multiple main hubs as it is a bit of a pain running from one side of the map all the way to the other just to hire people only for them to get their coin stolen.

It's a bit unfortunate that I've had to click onto the thumbs down button as it's a game I've imagined for a long time and it's finally coming to fruition. Can't wait to see what's in store for the next update.

reviewText:
It's not a bad game but it's a bit shallow,  and has some glaring issues.

Pros

Beautiful pixel graphics
Nice music

Cons

No control over AI - ogres bashing at your gate? Archers miles away
The trebuchet is a joke, seems to always fire over the enemies heads
Archers are blind
Can't station archers where you want them
Not much variety, I was hoping there'd be more levels of upgrade, seems like two is your limit.
Day cycle too short, you just got your ♥♥♥ kicked and need to recruit people (again) you will literally spend a day just getting them back and then...
AI too slow, if you don't get something set to build at first light it won't be done by night, also they can take a day geting back to your base.

Overall I enjoyed the game for the two hours I played it, although I can't see myself going back, nothing new to be done.

I'm aware there is a win state but there's nothing compelling me to bother. When i quit the game it's not becuase I died, it's becuase I was bored.

reviewText:
This game itself is ok, the gameplay is innovative and thought provoking.  The interface is well put though the buttons to push are left a secret, which only showcases the difficulty level of the game.

Day one is pretty easy, you have a short period of time to acclimate yourself to your surroundings, and are forced to balanced defense with exploration and income which is great.

The problem comes two days later when the blood moons start and the demons wipe your town, so you spend a day rebuilding and rehiring, then the next day another blood moon.  Rebuild, rehire, then another blood moon, each one worse than the last.  And soon you die.

Fun to flop in about 30 minutes.

I have read somewhere though an explanation of why this game becomes so hard so fast, the end game acheivment for this game was to survive 10 days.  Only the greatest were even supposed to see day ten, which is why by day three you're screaming at your monitor.  Sure, they've toned it down a bit, but not much.

This isn't a city sim that I was hoping for, it's not a resource sim that i was hoping for, and it's not casual like i was hoping for.  It's a game designed to be too hard to play.  Nintendo aint' got shhh on these guys.

reviewText: If this game would have come out at the heyday of the Atari 2600 - I would have claimed it was the best game on the platform. A dirt simple, yet engagingly strategic title that takes the core concepts of strategy board games and presents it as if it was the latest title from Sierra Online circa 1988. It isn't a game you'll play long term, but it scratches the same itch as trying to beat your friends at the boardgames Agricola or Puerto Rico. You can tell when you've made a critical mistake and you'll resign to restart and learn from it.

reviewText:
Kingdom is an impressively unique game, with some very simplistic controls. While you can only move left or right, what you upgrade and spend gold on will shape the way you play.

The graphics are very nice, having a simple pixel style to them that is oddly attractive. The music is very atmospheric, and immersive when playing the game. The tracks seemlessly change, and are very well performed.

As the game says, Nothing Last, and that is a very good mindset for the game. As you build walls, towers, soldiers, and more; all can be swept away in one night if your unlucky. Yet even losing a single wall can affect the next day, as you try to rebuild and fortify that position. I've started 3 seperate attempts, each one making further than the last. You'll likely lose the first time you play, but everything you learn helps you hit the ground running the next playthrough.

I highly recommend this game, even if it's not on sale. One of the better games that I've bought in the last few months.

reviewText:
So......this game has a very good concept and design along with execution until a point.....and that point seems to be with when you hit mid game or aim for beating it as then you look at what's been done and have to try to find the precise triggers to avoid killing yourself as gold early on is precious but once you get a good supply constantly going on you then need to worry about men, buildings, travel times, armenment and finally battle.....why? Well.....

For starters when you start the game you usually end up with two camps on each side of the kingdom before you hit the first portal and then another two after that but......those camps usually start until you remove the tree closested to them on both of their sides or so. But you  may need to remove it to get access to a stream or building place and you go then meh you got three more to get men from but that can quickly turn to one as you find that you need to get closer to the portals to avoid your attack parties taking a day to get to the portal, more on that later. But you then end up with less and less camps close by to restock your forces if you take a really big hit and that wouldn't be a problem if there was maybe a way to get them inside your walls like maybe...I duunno......have a family back at your home base? Or build a Tavern somewhere or make some sort of unit that can headhunt more people or attract people to your kingdom. There is many ways but none of these were put in and just means that once you build up fully to the last portals and you killed the camps you kill yourself, it hurts to destroy a camp as you are pretty much disabling yourself.

Now that brings me to the buildings where they are okay to a point......as it seems like the game is set in mediveal times some what which where they had walls and towers but....they also had it eventually be that they could have wallls that they stood on and shot down at the enemy while getting some protection and towers gave protection too as they went completely stone made with turrets and being enclosed. Now this is completely forgotten about it seems with the game as you can get those better buildings as they aren't possible to make and so makes your men much less effective and protected since the flying monsters can't then just take guys out of towers like they were picking apples and your men could then hit the enemies hiding right up against the wall which often require the tower men to take them out somewhat. This also could be improved with the siege weapons which you can only build one of for each side and can't make a permement upgrade to the walls or building to have one just be there. It would also be nice to imrpove the already existing shops you get so that the people that pick up their items can take more hits, move faster, do their job better or have a blacksmith being able to be built which can give those bonuses however that isn't the most needed thing with buildings.....as their a bigger dog in that kennel which is having it be possible to make a bow stand or hammer stand be made where you want or need it to be made as it can take forever for people to get from their camp to your stands and then head all the way back they came to the wall and so being able to make that shorter by moving or making stands closer would just be a blessing and takes me to the traveling times....

Ah travelling something that you do every day  usually as you got to your bed to the kitchen to get your breakfast......it usually takes time right? And you know about how long it can take right? Well you have to sorta learn how long it will take for you to travel to one side of the map to the other to recuit men and have it so that they can get inside your walls before darkness comes and usually it ends up being that for the far off camps you need to get going for them right at dawn and sometimes they will make it before night time arrives depending on how big you've expanded your kingdom...but that's ridiculous travel time.....as they are always shuffling along....so slowly when they could be exicited to work for you and run back before semi running to their post so that then they make the entire trip to your base before a day is done. Because why not a run mode for them when something urgent needs to be done that you can just blow a horn or something and they go double the speed for some time with whatever they are doing because you get a run button for you going around the place and it takes forever still to get from one side of the map to the other so for those guys just shuffling away it's really painful and hurts you....like why not have a horse carraige or something come along and pick them up or something like a unit which just goes out and gets those new recuits safe within the walls and once they are he takes them to where they need to go or be....as you can't do that only follow them back while wondering what they are thinking with seeing you behind them on a horse which can race to safety. But your horse even isn't enough as well.....if you expand out too far you can spend a day getting from one front to another so it would be nice to have some sort of faster way to move around inside your base like.....maybe putting down tile paths or something which improve move speed and reduce then travel times overall? Because it just seems like your going around always in the dirt or mud in your base while the forest is covered in grass and moss which I guess would be easier to go along than just dirt or mud  but upgrading that terrain of where you've deforrested to increase movement speed would be and excellent addition to the game and improve it so much more and may remove the need of some things for a while or somewhat at least.

Okay now armrment.....which I did touch on a little already but....there's more problems with it....like with knowning how many people are what so you can then plan according as to what you want and how much from the stands as I find that having four builders is the most you need for you small size while archers you just need a lot of and farmers you need a constant level of them to avoid having money troubles so......if your able to set a sorta limit on how many of each unit you want would be nice along with a auto resupply mechanic too.....as then you can tell when your losing troops too suddenly as at night you don't know where they enemy is attacking until they attack and you hear it or find it, both of which have a very short range...and so middle game you can struggle to know when your getting attacked and where...anyway it would be nice to have more siege weapons too as well since you get this building area for them and...you  can only build one weapon for each side and that's it...which also has bad aim too as well as it can't hit enemies at all really that are against the wall licking it. Also...with what I said about the upgrading of your people it would be nice of where you can give them coins so that they can lose those first before their tools and finally their recruitment coin or just those extra coins means that they can take more hits after losing their tools and so can retreat better too. This would also be nice for getting new weapons too for dealing with those flying creatures as the bows don't start firing at them until they are right up and close which then you need a ton of archers to dps them down. I also struggle to see the point of knights in a defensive role too as they don't try to rush out and attack the enemy...they just hold up their shield and hit their sword against it while bouncing hits..like..why do they have the swords if they aren't going to simply try and attack with them?? Like is there no melee attacks in the game for your units at all? Since like they could try to defend themselves if they are going to not run from the enemy.

Anyway I would write more but I've run out of characters so I'll just say this the game is good at the start but annoying after that.

reviewText:
Simple but engrossing, Kingdom is a throwback to a time when computer games were easy to jump right into and be instantly engaging. A time when wiki's and tutorial videos didn't exist and you just lost hours playing the game and discovering its mysteries and defeating its challenges on your own. A time when each new playthrough offered another opportunity to use your earned experience and get a bit farther along than the last session! Until, one day, you finally WIN!

reviewText:
It's a good start but it's lacking in quite a few areas.

-The friendly/team AI is awful. You're basically in control of a bunch of lemmings with no sense of self preservation or urge to actually work.

-There's no indication of how many villagers/workers you actually control and how they are allocated. It'd be nice to see something on the UI that tells you how many unassgined workers you have, how many archers, builders etc.

-The balance is way off as far as getting coin is concerned. The game is so randomised that if you get one area that doesn't have enough animals for your archers to kill you can struggle to get enough coin. Sadly, you get nothing for killing attackers, and that I think is a shame. You really ought to get something...even if it's like one coin for every five attackers or something. It would bring some kind of regularity to the game and aid in the balance.

-You King/Queen has no way of defending themselves. It'd be nice if there was some way to defend. Without it, what you are playing is essentially a tower defence game and that's going to put some people off.

All of the above means that this feels more like a pre-release game than a full game, which is NOT okay. A game like this needs to be play tested for balance, I don't feel like this one has, it's way too randomised. A little more work and a few minor additions and it'd be really cracking.

The game is a neat concept, one that I actually think works. It's just the basics are a bit weak & shaky at the moment. I really hope that the developer actually puts a bit more work in and keeps working on this rather than seeing this as final product.

I don't recommend it YET, but may do if improvements are made to the game.

reviewText:
Kingdom is a somewhat complex strategy game wherein your main goal is to build, well, a kingdom. You begin the game with no knowledge of how to play, and a brief tutorial fills you in on the starting basics; such as how to light your campfire, recruit beggars, and turn those beggars into builders and archers. In fact, Kingdom is really just a newer, harder version of Lemmings with hoards of enemies that will come for you in the night. Every fifth night, a flock of foes will overrun your quaint campsite, tear down your walls, pick up your people and fly off with them, and leave you in ruins. Yes, as the tagline suggests... nothing lasts indeed.

After picking your desired horse/gender/clothing color all in one go on the very first screen, and having the brief tutorial, the game thrusts you into its realm with no further knowledge of how to get by. It's trial and error from here on out, but it really doesn't take too much to figure it out. You build walls and archer outposts to keep the monsters out, gather hoards of beggars that you then turn into archers to kill said enemies, and then upgrade your walls and base camp; which, by the way, ends up becoming your castle. The trick here is that it costs gold coins to do all of these things, and at the beginning gold can be hard to come by. During the day, archers will hunt rabbits and deer, if you run out of rabbits you will then need to herd deer closer to your camp; this is much easier said than done, as they run much faster than you and you can only turn them around if you happen to get in front of them, even then they'll run back most of the time.

As you expand your kingdom, you will be able to recruit two more classes; the farmer, who will provide you with abundances of gold, and knights that will march toward the enemy gates at your command. Once these classes are unlocked, Kingdom basically becomes easy mode so long as you keep a plethora of archers around. There are four enemy gates, two on either side of your camp, that must be destroyed. Once every gate is destroyed, and every monster that has spawned from them is slain, you will have won the game. Beware, for if a monster attacks you directly, you will lose gold; when you run all out of gold, they will knock your crown off, take it, and it's game over.

The pixel artwork is beautiful, and the landscape has a variety of randomized weather throughout each day and night cycle; rain, heavy fog, bright sun, and sometimes a combination thereof. The atmosphere brought on by these sudden changes truly adds a depth of mystery to Kingdom, and the folk inspired soundtrack is the polish that adds a shine to the game overall. However, the title is not without its flaws and it comes as no surprise to me that the game is made in Unity; though it is 5 and not the personal edition, thankfully. If you have enough beggars/farmers/knights/archers/builders in your community, the framerate starts dipping ever lower. My FPS was 60 (the cap) for the large part of my play time, but once I neared the end and had a huge gathering of commoners in my community, my FPS dipped into the low 40s and hung there consistently; especially when adding any dropped gold or incoming monsters into the mix. This is simply unacceptable for a pixel based game that really doesn't have any complexity to it in terms of mechanics, ambiance, or graphics.

Unfortunately, I just cannot bring myself to recommend Kingdom; even for the small on-sale price of $5.49 CAD I feel rather ripped off. The area that you have to expand within the game is limited and small, and once you get the gist of how to manage your resources and faux-Lemmings, the game is incredibly easy. The trailers made the game seem a great deal larger, there are also a very small number of different enemies, nearly every beggar looks identical, and most of the walls/archer outposts look the same even after you've upgraded your castle. Kingdom is a game that has fell victim to over-hype, it's okay... but not nearly as godly as other gamers make it out to be.

Rating: 2.5/5.0 - It's not awful, but it's not great.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)

reviewText:
Nothing Lasts.
Remember that.

Your want to linger in an area for more than 2minutes will be overshadowed by a fear of whats happening off screen. So you'll canter or trot over and through the expanse of your kingdom - only to find survivors of another night.

My first 90 minutes of this game died proudly to a wonderful learning curve. You'll grow to understand how the horde night works, how long it takes to ride through fields and brush and when to break into a soft walk, when its best to stay a keep before a castle, AND why its fearful fantastic to see waves of gold dance across the landscape as your ride through your people.

Nothing lasts.
Never forget to take a break every 30 to 40 minutes while playing this game.
Otherwise you'd risk running through the night to see daybreak across a landscape of broken down walls, empty towers and a field of bewildered peasants.

Down/8 Gold to play again.

Previously, First 90minutes Review.

On Day 11, I found the Masons Temple. Time to get Stoned.
On Day 12, I discovered banks or strip-clubs are nonexistent & start to drop gold pieces everywhere with no satisfaction.
On Day 14, I found a Three Tiered Archer Shrine. Barely survived the experience.
On Day 15, I lost half my Kingdom to poor builder Union Scheduling.
On Day 16, I assembled my Avengers.
On Day 17, My Iron Man failed to close the portal.

On the morning of Day 19, I sent my New Avengers - only to fail.

By the afternoon of the 20th day, after a horde of body-snatching bugs and the fall of the Behemoth - all I had left was a single farmer and a Builder and three coin pieces. GG game.

It took 90minutes of my day - but it was an epic 90minutes.

reviewText:
I don't know how to describe this game.
It's different from anything that I've played so far. Completely.

You have to create your Kingdom, get people to work for you, defend your Kingdom from evil Monsters that want your crown and money.
That's pretty much everything you have to achieve in this game.
Survive as long as you can

- The Gameplay
The gameplay is pretty interesting. It's somewhat challenging yet simple.

- Controls
Arrow keys. Left, Right and Down. That's all you ever use. That's all you ever need in this.

- The music
I don't know what to say. The Soundtrack of this game is simply beautiful, reason why I bought it too!

- The design
Pixel Graphics is one of the tags for this game. It's true, it's yet another pixelated game.
Yet it's different. Each sprite is beautifully crafted, and the effects are just amazing.

TL;DR
Buy it when it's on sale. It's definitely worth it!

reviewText:
Kingdom! Man oh man.

My eye fell on it while browsing the store and I felt the urge to buy it. I've been gaming since I was young, and always played games that were made way before I was even born, because my computers were always old as balls and ran on potatoes. My point is: I learnt not to judge games on graphics, however pixelly they may be.

Anyhow! On to Kingdom. Wrapped in beautiful pixel art. Seriously, this is one of the most beautiful pixel games I have ever seen. It also has a very peaceful (or creepy, depending on what's happening) soundtrack. It's not the beep boop noises you would expect from a game with those graphics. Still, very atmospheric and nice.

It's a resource management game, but with only one resource. Gold!
Only 3 buttons to play. Very easy to control, but quite hard to manage.

You start, and barely get any explanation, just the very basics. This pretty much leaves a lot up to trial and error. It is part of the fun though! So, as you ride through the forest with nothing else than your trusted horse, golden crown and waving cape, you soon find 10 gleaming coins, which you pick up as you pass them. With those coins you can upgrade your campfire and recruit the 2 beggars next to it, by tossing them a coin as the noble king that you are. When your fire is upgraded, you can outfit your citizens with a hammer or a bow, which turns them into workers or bowmen. As you keep upgrading, more tools become available.

When you start exploring the woods, you will find more beggars to recruit. Some rabbits to hunt for your bowmen to yield money. You can scare some deer off to your hunters, which gives even more precious gold. You will find some shrines which aids your workers or your bowmen, or a chappel that let's you build stronger structures. You can find a new, stronger horse, which grants you considerable more speed. A kind merchant who supplies you with cheaper tools, which however you cannot choose but are randomized. You can chop trees to expand your Kingdom, create farms and let your farmers grow crops to earn you more profits. And you will find eerie buzzing portals, which at night, spawn trolls who will try to destroy everything you have worked so hard for. Eventually, if your Kingdom is flourishing, you will have a chance to strike back...

Recruit loyal people. Equip them wisely. Expand thy borders. Defend with care! And drive the trolls back.

Basically, in a nutshell, you run around a lot, toss coins at people or upgrades you need, and let them do the work for you.
You can help by pushing deer to your hunters, or dropping coins, which trolls will steal and run back to dissapear in their portal. But that is once you get to know the game a lot better.

I managed to finish my first game in 19 hours. I will play this beautiful gem of a game. And I will probably pursue the achievements aswell! Thanks for reading and take care.

reviewText:
I ran it under Ubuntu Linux 14.04 and had no problems. Worked in full screen on the living room TV. No bugs detected not that I looked very hard for them.

I enjoyed this.  It was a new mechanic to me. A 2D sidescroller kinda tower defense/stronghold type thing. I thought the pixel graphics were really nice looking, and I'm not a big fan of pixel art. I played with the sound down as I usually do. I beat it in 15 hours, speedy mcfasteos can probably do it in half that time.

The side scrolling was testing my patience at the end because your kingdom widens out and you're going back and forth from end to end.  Jusr as it was starting to get tedious then I won so it is paced pretty well.

Short game, nice looking, compelling to play, and a new twist. Not much replay value, but it is good for what it is worth.

reviewText:
this game is quite addicting and is worth the money you pay and a great spin on a tower defense.

The game strts with a 30 second tutorial, then leaving you alone to enjoy the game. As you play the game you will get better, as you learn more about how the game works and what strategies are good.

Pros:
+ Visual Style is are quite good
+ Proggression is strong
+ Extremely Difficult, forcing you to adapt
+never lags even on a bad pc (mine)

Cons:
- Lack of story
- Horse Stamina
- There are only a few monster types
-catapults can knock your crown off your head (and at night maybe into the monsters hand which after a long run can be very frustrating)

there is Extremely Fast Day and NIght Cycles.The only way to get new people to your Kingdom is to hire them at camps. which slows down you building your kingdom by having to go back and forth to get new residents which takes alot of time. overall it is a Simplistic game that is worth the money. There is many reviews that talk about the game in  bad way because of the terrible aim of the archers, but this can be fixed. Overall a good game, worth the money

reviewText:
well worth the money!!!
A very good game, albiet simple, extremely engaging, purchased it 24 hours ago and ive already played it ten of those!
although very minimalistic and simplified, it feels almost lacking in some things, a head count for one would be useful, also some more control over your people would be helpful to say the least. maybe having a different command and build structure for male and female? maybe different building opportunities?

Good points.
soundtrack not too intrusive, yet ambient.

graphics although pixelated for an asthetic appeal, nothing is lost.

enemies are ghostly and genuinely worry you when you sight them.

i like the lack of weapons for the main character but the character need much more control over his/her people.

Bad points.
enemies ramp up their strength and numbers sporadically it seems, going from easily defeated grunts to thousand strong behemothes and flying ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s all of a sudden and then back to a few grunts.
a little unbalanced is all im saying.

There isnt enough randomisation, every game you start you can guess where abouts things are going to be.

there needs to be more control over the peolpe.

there isnt enough benefits to going out of your comfort zone of a fort into the wildrness. more chests? more coins available? more traders? maybe another fort?



aside from all this im very pleased with the game and looking forward to future updates. i want to see where this rabbithole ends!

reviewText: Kingdom is an excellent game. Its attractive aesthetic is complimented by interesting, challenging gameplay. The slight variation on the map in each playthrough offers plenty of replayability. There are some cons, unfortunately, as your citizens  can not be directly controlled, which means builders will at times walk from one end of the kingdom to the other and then back again, rather than logicially dividing their work. reviewText: Since hearing about the game on IGN and watching a few Twitch streamers play it, it looked like a very relaxing and charming game, so I was really hyped to get it when it released today.  I love the minimalistic pixelated feel to the game.  The game is strangely addictive and has an air of mystery to it.  So far, I've made it up to day XVI and the game is already starting to lose some of it's excitement.\n\nNow, don't get me wrong, I can definitely see this game growing into something much bigger with additional content down the road and community feedback.  But as it stands, there's really not much to it.  I get the whole figure it out on your own" kinda thing
recommended: along with the mild rogue-like elements (randomization and starting fresh).  But there's only so long and so many times you can navigate either to the left or right side of the village and do the same thing

for sure!

Some suggestions:

Tower archers...shoot the frickin' rabbits!  Don't just stand up there twiddling your thumbs when you're bored.
Builders...could you walk any faster to that next tree?  I'm turning into a skeleton here...
More enemy variety would be nice.  Also add more things to do when waiting for gold to pop up.
Add some some sort of collection/stacking element in between games to reward continued play
Give more actions and choices available to your King/Queen character (such as killing wild rabbits/deer)
Add the option to fast-forward day/night cycles...there are times when gold is sparse and I just want to speed up to the next day."

reviewText: Game is cool and all, but with the AI it makes the game incredibly difficult to beat. Unless there's some way to control and monitor your units I really don't Recommend this game. Some kind of Panic your a** back to safety mode? Not only that but you have no Idea how many times I've had like 10-15 archers, but for some reason they all went to ONE SIDE. The Ai in this game are ridiculously stupid. Either allow the commanding of individual units or make them smarter. Game is needlessly difficult how it is. It's a cool idea but the gameplay is flawed.

reviewText:
A very simple concept with impeccable implementation, and a very intresting deeper meaning. Graphics and Music are beautiful and very fitting. The game has an amazing amount of complexity for a game that uses only three buttons and there are heaps of small things to learn that will make you smile when you pick up on them.

Amazing game, I have had hours of enjoyment from it and still enjoy it.

I don't like the way the game scales against you when you attack portals, its easier to kill a portal while you have low population and almost imposible to kill a portal if you have high population.

reviewText:
My first game that I do not recommend. Lets me start off by saying that the game has potential. However for me it seems kind of dumb. You start out on a horse you ride until you find your camp, you get money and pay ♥♥♥♥♥es to work for you. They build up your kingdom and defend it. Thats the game right there. You have no wave bosses, you have no end goal than to just survive. Which can be great but after a while it just gets really boring doing the same thing over and over.

Additionally you can have fun with this game, but as I said before as it currently is you will have spent what 10 bucks for this game and at the very least become bored with it in a couple hours. Never really getting your money worth.

I might change this review if they add a few things but right now it seems like the game took about a week to make. It has no content.

There  are a few things in game that could be added that might change my review.

- A menu that lets you see where you have progressed as far as the ages go in what you can build.
- Would have been nice to be able to see an expanded view of your Kingdom so that you can see whats going on everywhere like maybe a minimap or a normal map.
- Would be great if you had objectives to complete each day that earned you a small amount of gold.
- Would be great if new players knew the overall goal of the game. For example like the portals can be destroyed.

reviewText: This game is incredibly frustrating. If you don't beat the game quickly (which requires playing pretty much perfectly) then you enter into an unwinnable stalemate. reviewText:
This game is ♥♥♥♥, spent 16 hours trying to complete this ♥♥♥♥. The horse dies on you at every turn (even if you eat grass) I SWEAR THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ HAS ASTHMA. I can't even make it from one wall on the side of my base to the next without it exhausting itself. The day/night cycle is completely ♥♥♥♥ing stupid, not the mechanic of it, but how fast the days are and how slow the nights are. You barely have time to recover and if you are in lategame it will take you an entire two cycles to get from one side of your base to the next. Also, you have a bag size for gold again, YOU HAVE A ♥♥♥♥ING BAG SIZE FOR YOUR GOLD. Lategame it is so annoying when every time you go past your villagers with a full bag it just empties into the river. Offerings to the gods to make the game better? Not to mention if you have a lot of villagers and they lose their weapons you can buy weapons at the center of your base for them to use. However the weapon rack only has a maximum size of 4 bows. 4 ♥♥♥♥ING BOWS. Do you know how annoying it is when you have a town of 100+ who constantly lose their weapons to stand next to the weapon rack and constanly pour your gold into it waiting for them to pick up their weapon!@!@! I felt like a ♥♥♥♥ing weapons merchant rather than a king. Overall, not a pleasant experience  1/10. Wish I had my money and time back.


TLDR: If you want to play 8bit simulator of an asthmatic horse running around all game while coins fly out your a$$ because you cant hold them this game is for you.

reviewText:
If you don't want to read you can watch the video review which basically says the same.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dLS_Oy7TzIo&nohtml5=False

Kingdom is a 2D side scrolling/strategy game this concept might sound farfetched however after starting to play you are able to see how it makes sense and how well it works together.

In this game you are a King or a Queen that just established a Kingdom and of course your objective is to make it prosper while protecting your crown from the enemies.
The game starts by holding your hand for a 30 seconds tutorial just to immediately after leave you to fend for yourself, In my opinion this is pretty cool since it's awesome to be able to try stuff while being amazed by the results.

Now onto the mechanics you have that pouch on the top left corner that you can fill with gold, gold that you can use to build and improve structures, to recruit citizens, to get buffs, and to get tools.

Now this next part might sound confusing, every time you recruit a citizen they'll walk to the center of your kingdom, while doing this journey the first tool they touch will become assigned to them, this might be hard to grasp at first, since it can give you a hard time to manage every villager job, I don't know if this was really intended by the game devs, or if it happened during development but it looks sloppy, but, just as much as it makes for a better game mechanic.

Every night your land will be attacked by the enemy, and every five nights the red moon arises and the enemy wave is even more deadly, the enemies can go from simple Greeds, called like that cause their objective is to steal as much as they can, to Floaters and Giants that are even more deadly.

Your main objective has to be to protect your crown since if you lose it, it's game over.

However you have offensive responsibilities just as much as you have defensive ones, since the end game objective is to destroy the 4 enemy portals, which might sound like fun but it's really not, since it makes the game dull and boring, the same steps every single time, attack, recruit more villagers, attack, recruit, and so on.

As you might have noticed by now the game aesthetics are just gorgeous, from the beautiful and fitting pixel art, to the water reflection that is just amazing, to the soundtrack that just makes for a great atmosphere, overall everything fits really well together.

Even after failing a couple of times before completing this game my total game time was 6 hours, which for a game with no replay value isn't that good, which makes the price of 10 bucks a little steeper since you can have games that will last you much longer with that same pricetag.

Summing it up:

+ Fresh Concept
+ Art
+ Fun first couple hours

- Repetitive
- No replay value for such short game
- Overpriced

70% Cool Game!

Join my Steam Group page for more reviews: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/jereviews

reviewText:
Peace of Art.

Are you a big fun of survival but the 3D generes got you tired? Then this is the next big survival game and just for a change it is 2D.

Craft, build your defenses and your strenghts, deciding where to put walls and to what give priority. You are the king\queen  and you will command your men with the power of the coin.

Unfortunately you can not decide how to build, but this is part of the fun, everything is automatic. you will only use 3 button on the game, 3 arrow key, left, right and down. This is all you need.

Umbelievable how much you will be able to do in this game with just 3 buttons. As said before the main target is expanding your empire and defending it, or better, defend your crown, as that is the only thing that matters. No crown, no king.

These are words from the game, which has a parfumed poetry behind it, that only after being played is understandable.

Fantastic Pixel Art, where you can really talk about Pixel Art as everything is simply amazing, stunning and the landscape is a pleasure to admire, even more than in some triple A 3D games.

reviewText:
I sat down to play this game today for about two hours straight after watching the video on Steam. I can so for certain that this game is a blast. Very simple, minimal controls, beautiful graphics, catchy soundtrack and surprisingly deep gameplay and strategy. The game is very tough, though. I reached about day 37 before losing every one of my recruits. I highly recommend this game if you're interested in simple games, casual gameplay, and strategy.

A tip is to recruit as many archers as possible and explore to get the stone towers quickly! I got pretty lucky in my playthrough. Also take note that you can herd deer and it's viable to do so for the first few days, even though it's difficult. Very good game but there ARE some cons.

It doesn't hold your hand, which I like but others might not. There isn't much diversity past a certain point, you end up doing the same things over and over again, and although it may be calming it doesn't truly hold up in the grand scheme of things. The knight system seems a bit weird to me, you pay to buy knights then you pay to send them in a direction (I assume to the dark portals in the forest on either side) but I'm not sure what they do after that. They either die or just....well mine kept dying. It might be that I didn't expand to the certain point, which is another tip. Don't expand right away and the more you upgrade your fort the less morning gold you get!

A nice fun game overall, though!

reviewText:
Kingdom is a 2D side scrolling RPG/Base builder/Resource manager game where you start with a simple camp fire and 2 peasants who you soon arm with a bow and a hammer so they can start building up your base/town and defend the peasants you bring in later on.
Your archers are also hunters by day and bring in even more gold.

By day you can go around and explore the woods to the left and right while at night it's best to stay inside your walls and wait for the early morning or at least the end of the enemy attacks.

I found it most effective to start slow and just build up your force slowly and expanding when you have enough gold to upgrade the new towers and walls as soon as you build them.
Another good investment are the archery and builder shrines that you find in the woods while exploring.
The archer shrine costs 5 gold to get the buff, while the builder shrine costs 6 gold.
The archer shrine as the name says buffs your archers so they have increased accuracy and damage, while the builder shrine buffs your workers who in turn reinforce all existing walls as long as the buff lasts.
The buffs last for 1 day and can be re-aplied or extended if you have enough gold.

All in all a solid game and easy worth the asking price.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Review - KINGDOM

A greatly expected game that is actually awesome from RawFury,
though released with little information of actual gameplay dynamics it surpasses need to explain as the player learns and counters their own failure, with each playthrough being unique and rewarding despite constant defeat, I found that I live as the hero during each and every minute.

You play as a person on riding on a horse, with crown on your head and pouch full of coin, now you must raise a kingdom from the wilds. Though beware horse riding hero, for there are threats and idles that stand within the fog of the wild. Give coin for followers, buildings and defenses. For with nightfall come those that steal and plunder.

Raise coin by clearing trees in the East only for the fields to become barren and ill treated. Construct water mills and watchtowers to protect the village and then find attack comes three nights later and that those spent are those invested.
Do you explore during the day and then build while exposed later that evening with those others batter the walls.

Overall the game is a pitfalls and judgement, you juggle coin and expensure in the hope of being better prepared for the threat. What the threat is and if it exists isn't given, however the beautiful way that the game starts with that ominous presence from just sound and visual design. And i mean actual design, trees with twisted foliage and those slow but, small movements being in the fore/back ground setting the mood as one of tension and foreboding.



45mins Friday on Youtube - https://youtu.be/SV1pRoYMq6A

Google Doc - https://docs.google.com/document/d/1UpVkMdveN-HvK-vGsNw1l4OiEWzsmC1ea1s5KWRsbds/edit?usp=sharing

reviewText:
A fantastic game for $10. I love the art style and gameplay. There are a few things I wish were a bit different though.

1) I wish there was a gamemode where dying didn't mean needing to restart. You would respawn and maybe lose part or all of your gold. This would make it easier for first-time players to understand the gameplay concepts without such harsh punishments.

2) More customability in your kingdom. While the maps are procedurally generated, there are set places for walls, guard towers, etc. The ability to place an object anywhere you want might detract from the simplicity of the controls, but I'd love to see it as an option in the settings.

3) A tutorial would be really nice. I've had to read through the few guides currently on the Community Hub to understand a lot of what's going on (e.g. the function of Knights and how to establish stone walls). This is another feature that could be turned on/off from the settings.

Other than these three items, the game is pretty much perfect. It's a lot of fun with tons of replayability. I really suggest it for you Indie game lovers out there :)

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was provided a key from the publisher to check out the game.

As a variety streamer who doesnt specialise in strategy or simulations I really didnt expect this game to grab me. However the the pixel style artwork is great and the beautiful soundtrack by Toytree is sublime and I got so totally and utterly lost inside Kingdom.

Being English I of course wanted to try out being King. :)

Remember to go into the game knowing that it is meant to be hard and the game does no handholding at all. You are intended to lose and learn from every failure. I think it took me about 9/10 attempts to actually beat the game with the winning playthrough taking 5 hours.

The game can change from a soothing laid back experience to incredibly intense moments that can so easily end in total failure and death. I am sure there is so much I havent learned already in this game and really look forward to what the developers do in future updates.

reviewText:
At first the game is Incredibly charming, it still actually holds alot of that charm for me, the sounds and art style are pretty great. I can't help but get a Studio Ghibli feel from this game, specifically Princess Mononoke and Spirited Away (the Greed), type vibes.

reviewText:
i love the game,  had lots of fun playing it and beating it, reached a 100 days and made sure the crown was safe, however the last 70-60 days were a bit  boring because i was doing the same over and over, which isnt neccecairly bad but it was painfull because walking from 1 side of my kingdom to another took a full day, most of my coins dropped in the river because the money bag is too small, i didnt need guards cause i could just pay the enemies to leave, the exploring became dull pretty fast because its the same everywere,  4 camps to each side, 2 gates to each side and some towers, walls and farmland. thats all there is!

further more the game is too easy and lacking in content, id like to see thunderstorms, hurricanes etc, a bigger castle and more things in my kingdom then just farms more units, knights on horses maybe even on dragons, more knights at my disposal harder to beat enemies maybe something that can just jump over a wall and will run straight at you and ONLY go for the crown

a better way to recruit new people once you expand to the border there are NO MORE encampment to hire people from meaning that if the flying things eat your people or you just dont have enough you are screwed, why not add houses that you can build? were you can hire 1 person a day

more restock points, when my arches lose thier bow they spend a whole day walking back to the shop which can only hold 4 bows meaning i have to manually give them a bow why not make multiple bow shops and other shops? make them expand with your kingdom

lagg issues with coins i wish my people didnt lag the game by dropped hundereds of coins on me every time i walk by with a FULL pouch meaning they all just drop on the ground sitting there often causing frame drops

a last thing id like to get a stats screen at the end of a game too see how much gold i have earned or how many people my kingdom , the amount of enemies killed a simple score screen at the end would be nice

conclusion, the games estatic is great, music is amazing but the content and the random map generation are lacking it worth the 10 bucks but it definitly needs more cotent.
