reviewText:
Let me start off by saying I like the premise of this game, I like it alot and I think it will be a brilliant game once all the bugs are ironed out. Unfortunately, right now it is a bit let down by the buggy mechanics which can make you suffer heavy losses, often either unrecoverable or just recoverable enough to last until the next time time it happens. There are a couple of things that need to be altered so that they work a little better. The also diminish a big part of the fun of the game, as you are left at the mercy of uncontrollable NPC's just doing completely random things.

1st. The deers. Right now they are utterly pointless in the game. To make it even remotely worth your while chasing them down, you have to travel pretty far out to get 3 or 4 of them together. Then you have to sprint for WAY too long before you can get ahead of them to turn them around back towards your settlement. This means by the time you have rounded say 3 of them up, you are pretty far away from your camp, this wouldn't be too much of an issue if it wasn't for buggy mechanic number 1. Basically, when herding them back to your camp, the deer will one at a time randomly turn direction every say 6-8 seconds, and run back away from your camp. You CANNOT stop them from doing this, trust me I have tried walking them back, I have tried sprinting them back and keeping the same distance all the time, I have tried a mixture of both, nothing works. So basically no matter what you do, because you are so far away from your camp, by the time you get there you are left with one deer, 2 if you are very lucky. BUT, thats no the end of your woes, the deer have to be shot twice, soon as they are shot once then run off again meaning you have to try round them up again ALL before the sun goes down, at which point your bowmen will no longer even shoot at them and the whole debacle becomes an utter and complete waste of your time. Until they fix this i recommend you do not even both with the deer if you value your sanity.

2nd. Your NPC's everynow and again, just doing whatever the ♥♥♥♥ they feel like doing. For instance, I often see my bowmen just wandering off into the forest, not just a little way, like a long long long way away, so far away in fact that when it becomes night time and the demons come out, they are so far away they can't possibly make it back to camp in time before getting killed. They also take it one step further and randomly walk around the village, sometimes just before nightfall which is where the buggy mechanics result in heavy losses part comes in. I'm not sure if they are trying to do, maybe switch sides from left to right or vice versa, I'm really not sure, but the end result is they are all spread out when night comes, instead of being all together huddled up by a wall so they can kill the demons before they break it down. This leaves the wall relatively unguarded and once the wall is down you cannot prevent them demons from just running riot, stealing all your NPC's bows, hammers etc and coins. Once this happens, you may as well just restart as if you dont, by the time you have scraped enough gold together to get back on your feet again it happens again at which point its game over. I got to level 38 a little while ago and I felt like I was virtually unkillable, I had loads of archers and a fully upgraded wall with catapult next too it so I should have had no issues killing the Demons before they over came the wall but when night fell, none of my archers were in place on the left side and the Demons just took the wall out uninpeded and then it was game over, all completely out of my control which is the worst part.

I hope they hotfix the game as I enjoy playing it.

reviewText:
I'm on a horse!
... you know, just riding around, literally throwing money at people making them join my Kingdom! Why? To build defenses strong enough to withstand an army of body-slamming trolls from stealing my precious crown! And good grief what are those flying things eating up all of my archers?!

So is this brilliant little Indie game worth the money? Absolutely! 100%

It manages this super simple controls but at the same time, some very deep choices on what to spend your money on. And in this beautiful pixel art environment as well! It makes me want to play a version of it where I can just stroll around and enjoy it, not having to worry about trolls and those flying fu- no seriously, what are these, I'm having nightmares about those!

And it's hard, but in a nice way. It takes a while to get to know what exactly you're doing, and then you get body-slammed into the ground and your crown stolen from you from obnoxious trolls. But I still just want to play more, This time I'll do it better!" ... "This time I won't make that stupid mistake again!" .. seriously

reviewText:
For the price, I recommend the game, it's a fun, pretty and rather enjoyable filler game. The artwork and graphics are pretty and it's enjoyable to build up your own little settlement from scratch.

However, it has to be noted that while all of the above is great the game does not swing well for the player. You have no control of the AI. Sure, you can make them tools and in turn they will pick them up, but other than that you've got no way to control them and tell them where to go. The AI will however balance itself between both sides of your camp so you do not end up with all your resources at one side, which is helpful.

Furthermore, the attacking AI is very overpowered and has little remorse for it's actions! Day 4 and you've got a red moon? Well, I do feel sorry for you because the defences you would have been able to build on this day will be weak and they will break through, steal your items and then probably want your crown too! Your town AI is useless and can't aim where they're shooting so if you have a big invasion your only option is to kite the AI around your archer towers and hope for the best.

The AI needs work, that is easily said, but I think for filler game like this, the enjoyment is still there.

TL;DR - It's fun and pretty, but don't smash your computer because of the AI!

reviewText:
At first I thought this was just going to be one of those pixel indie adventure type deals. Short with a preachy message at the end.

BOY was I wrong, going into this blind was the best, the feeling of discovery was great, music amazing with fantastic atmosphere.

I don’t want to say too much on exactly how it plays out in case you want to play it yourself but I will say its a strategy game similar to an old but also awesome game called, Majesty. Your actions work indirectly with the games environment in some sense.

I know this review reads very subdued and vague but its game I believe is best experienced as blind as possible. If there is anything about the games description, screenshots or even title that interests you even remotely then definitely give it a try.

I don’t like scores as I don’t think a game that is worthy of merit shouldn’t be boiled down to a summary but I’ll give it:

one good afternoon out of the day / 10

Thanks and go ♥♥♥♥ yourself!

reviewText: The brutal difficulty defeated me about 10 times before I eventually put together the proper strategies and was able to beat the game. Although the game trusts you to discover these things for yourself, which I like, it ended up being a bit much for me (probably because each game plays out largely the same way), and I ended up searching for tips to accelerate my progress. Some features seems unnecessary, like the inability to build what you want *where* you want. I imagine this would unbalance the game, but that's no excuse to not address the issue; people want more freedom in building their kingdom, even if it means needing to add more difficulty to keep things challenging, i.e. more monster types and/or more varied attack methods from existing ones. I agree with other reviews that suggest the current difficulty would be a lot easier to accept if each game played out differently. If I lose a game of, say, Civilization, I don't really care because I actually LOOK FORWARD to a fresh start, thats one of the best moments of the game. Adding a pinch of that feeling (somehow) would make this game far more enjoyable.

reviewText:
9/10

I have spent 20 hours in this game and unlocked every steam achievement. Though I don't really like playing pixel graphic games, 'Kingdom' gives me a totally different experience. With not much introduction, this game lets yourself discover your own best way of defending your kingdom and attacking enemies. Many tricks can be discovered after a few plays which may help you a lot, eg, teleport using the destroyed enemy portals, horse gets better stamina after eating grass...  With the beautiful BGM and visual design, this game is quite addictive. I did not really expect such great gaming experience when I first decided to purchase this game (for a half price, I think it is worth a full price though).

However, there are a few aspects that are not so satisfactory.
1. The game is not of great replay value after you have got every achievement. Basically, it is not difficult enough after you have mastered the concept and all the tricks of this game.
2. The processing power is not enough. After recruiting more than one hundred soldiers, the gameplay is not fluent any more. And when the enemies attacks with rocks, my computer will freeze for more than 10 seconds as about 30 archers need to pick up their bows. (Maybe this is caused by my computer but I think it is the game codes that lead to this problem.)

reviewText:
The full review can be found on Start 2 Continue[start2continue.com].

Excerpt:

Being a monarch is hard work, especially when you’re without any loyal subjects. Armed with merely a torch, your trusty stead, and a few gold coins to your name, you seek out new lands to call home. In Kingdom, a new pixelated 2D sidescroller strategy game from Noio, Licorice, and publisher Raw Fury, you bring civilization to the unruly masses inhabiting the countryside, glory to your name, and defense against the creatures of the night who would delight in seeing it all stripped from you.

While this isn’t Noio‘s (or, by his real name, Thomas van den Berg) first game, it was the first time I stumbled across something he made. Having just heard about it the day of its launch on Steam a few days ago, I was pleasantly surprised by the game’s minimalist aesthetic. From the gameplay concepts (build and expand your kingdom while protecting your gold and, ultimately, your crown; if you’re attacked and lose your crown, you also lose your right to rule–after all, those with the fanciest hats wield the most power) to the pixel art and UI, Kingdom is seamless in its execution, blending modern flourishes and technique with old-school visuals and simplicity.

reviewText: Definitely worth $10 to play a few times. Play it more? Not without a stats panel. Some people may be good at picking up on hints and interpreting them, but it may as well be a horoscope for all I can make out of it. eg. why are the rocks sparkling? It's possible to find user-made hints. Apparently it constitutes cheating to seek out an oracle AKA youtube tutorial to explain the baffling bits. So maybe other people have the mind for such puzzles. That's the odd thing. It gives off a vague sense of insult, that you can't decipher the schizophrenic's rapid blinking and strange honking noises. It takes someone special to really get the most out of this game. Nevertheless, recommended for the atmosphere.

reviewText:
See the small video below to understand how the game handles itself.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GDHZdiC0yXU

A 2D sidescroller about surviving monsters and closing gates. Sounds obliviony right? You recruit citizens from camps around watersources and buy weapons and buildings with gold generated either from hunting, daily survival rewards or farming. Lovely game and highly recommended but there needs to be few more things. Had to play for several hours before understanding the whole logic. You then find out you have to do the exact same things each time to win.

İssues:
1. Can't cancel an order. Builder and all others after him will go to their doom by your misclick.
2. Can't call/order troops anywhere except to attack the gate. You may know the east wing has fallen but your citizens certainly do not.
3. If attack order is given when the group has not assembled you may have partial attacking groups.
4. Theres no point in attacking at any other time then a specific time period which you have to understand yourself.
5. A bug prevents game completion (See the despair at the end of video)
6. If you happen to build a forward wall just before night, your dumbizens will assemble at the previous wall first then move to the outer wall (and get slaughtered)
7. Hunters dont generally go too far in to the tree line, but they will go miles to hunt (hence die at night), if there are no trees. Once they went all the way to a gate and in a large group no less. They of course all died (Around 20).
8. I cant really tell if powerups do anything.
9. Why do multiple farm spots exist. One is supremely enough

reviewText:
This game is beautiful, the strategy is clean and fun, and the music is great. Seems like the type of game I'd love, if not for the one huge flaw: There's no progress to be made, except beating the game! You're literally back to square one, as if you had just bought the game, whether you die on day 6 or day 37, leaving you to rebuild your kingdom from scratch with minor tweaks in an attempt to make it further. This is obviously a conscious design choice, but it's ruining the game for me.

The idea must be that the progress is all in my head, that I'll play better and make it further next time. That's not very motivating, especially after dying on a slightly earlier wave than last time. This is why games like this always give you some waypoints to shoot for (as in Binding of Isaac) or at least some amount of progress towards unlockables depending on days survived (as in Don't Starve), so that you'll have an overarching sense of progress even as you keep dying.

I find myself restarting whenever I figure out a game mechanic I wasn't aware of or spot a small mistake on my part, figuring that even if I recover, my run might not be strong enough now to make it to the end. That's a sign that my motivation is only going to keep dropping.

reviewText:
Kingdom has me hooked.

For a game thatis inherently quite simple, the pleasure of building a Kingdom is so satisfying. Taking what strategy does best, and mixing it into a side-scrolling, pixel art world is what Kingdom does best.

Building your kingdom, and ultimately worrying about the upcoming blood moon" is a great cycle. Figuring out what works best is probably where I've found the most replayability thus far
date: and I'm still just scratching the surface in my journey.\n\nFully reccomend buying!"

reviewText:
This game is great for what it is now, and I really do hope they work on it until it's the best it can ever be.
However... There are a lot of bugs right now, so anyone who wants to play a perfect game is not going to get that at the moment, and should expect something to happen.

Just now I had a game where I sent two armies to destroy portals on both sides, they both succeeded, and waves of enemies came crashing into my walls, On one side, I was able to defend well, the other side, they got into the inner camp, (right side walls all down).
When they were in my camp I was next to my main fire, a Giant enemy knocked my crown off and it went on top of the fire, I couldn't pick it up and they couldn't hit it into the water, and nothing could pick it up.
So I defeated those enemies with my archers and I still couldn't pick up the crown, so I had to save and exit and restart the game.
when I restarted I could pick up my crown, I found this a bit cheaty but I carried on anyway, this all happened on day 12.

On day 16 (after the blood moon) I sent out the next set of armies, since I was able to recover so easily.
it took longer to get to the portals than the last time I had attacked them, so I destroyed both of them on the same day at day 18, I had placed gold in front of them as well to stop any huge waves from completely wrecking me.
However, I could not defend well enough, and they knocked down every wall in my kingdom, and the flying enemies went somewhere when they could no longer get anymore people, I had no more people to fight anything.
There were no small enemies anymore either, they had gone somewhere or had died in the fight, but there were still Giant enemies.

To my surprise, they never melted, and day never came, I waited until day 25 at this point to hope day might come, I could not save due to this, so I could not exit the game and come back to see if I had won.

At day 20 the blood moon never came, so I knew there was no more enemies going to spawn, and they never did, there was just 6 Giant enemies trying to knock my crown off.
So I just gave up and said I won basically, I had no way of making any gold to recruit anyone due to no day, and I couldn't win in any way.
Day was basically gone entirely, although the sun always came up and down.
It was the first game I was even close to winning, and so I was very disappointed that something like this happened.

Though this happened I would still give the game a 5/5 for where it's at, if this was a finished and entirely ready game I wouldn't recommened it, but I know how much it would mean to the devs if you did buy it at it's current state. :)

I hope you do in fact read this review and gain some insight as to what can happen, and are not steered away by what I've said, because that would ruin your chances at playing a great game.
I will continue to play, and I hope you all have fun.

reviewText:
What a brilliant little game at an appropriate price. Kingdom is ideal for those who enjoy a bit of resource management with a dash of tower defence. The almost too simple controls and interface do feel a tad underdeveloped, but it works with the overall game. You nudge your little Kingdom along and need to make the right decision at the right time. It took me 15 or so hours to beat this game, and it was extremely satisfying to achieve this.

Many reviews focus on poor AI, insufficient ability to micromanage your people, and general inability to 'tell this to do that', with the sole interface being 'purchase item', 'recruit new peasant' and 'build/upgrade this'. I just want to highlight the fact that, according to the credits, this game was made by two people. Two. The game costs $10, not $100. I feel the AI, control scheme, and amount of interactivity is sufficient for the price. Moreover, it adds to the charm. No, you can't micromanage every single aspect of your kingdom, some of your poor choices will lead to your defeat (and restart). That is part of the challenge of the game. Remember Mario? One life, zero f**ks given. Hugely popular spanning multiple generations.

Harden up and get ready for Kingdom, this game is a winner.

reviewText: I felt the urge to write a positive review after seeing so many negative reviews and requests for changes to make the game smarter" or easier.  There is no point in playing a game that is not challenging or a game that plays itself with the player as just the spectator.  This a game that reminds me of the days of gaming where exploration
recommended: and repetition was how you conquered a game.  It is refreshing to have a game that takes time and effort to survive let alone complete.  That requires the player to plan ahead and is penalized for making a bad decision.  This type of game play may not be for everyone but for those seeking the excitement of risk and reward from strategy mixed in with a little good luck then this is definitely a game worth trying out."

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lw1X0HDQOMM

Check out this 1 hour gameplay video to see the game for yourself.

The developers describe it as a two-dimensional Dark Souls. How is it like that game? Well, it randomizes every time you play the game. So you can hit day five with an I'll be fine style of attitude
date:
and suddenly a wave of enemies will descend upon your base and kill everyone you hired and take your crown.

Kingdom is heavily enjoyable and has a steep learning curve. It drops you into the world without much beyond a simple tutorial and tons of evil bad guys. You could watch some tutorial on the internet, but that would ruin most of what Kingdom brings to the table. The challenge of trying to stay alive.

I recommend this game for those who are into strategy games and don't mind dying constantly in video games.

reviewText: This game is very difficult for the first few times that you play it. My first run, I survived to around day 30-40. I failed because I bought too many knights, and they used up most of my archers. I would venture to furthest walls of the kingdom to find only a few archers remainning. I ended up dying from a blood moon. My next 5 runs or so I was not as lucky, and I only made it to around day 20. Then there is my current run. I am at around day 80 and have so many archers that my computer slows down every blood moon. Getting to this point in the game is not easy. That is what is fun about the game. You die often at first, but after each death you learn from your mistakes, and you slowly do better each run. The main downside to the game is there is not very much to do in the later days. The first 25 days are very interesting, but as you go on further, it gets repeative.

reviewText:
I don't know either to give a positive review or negative.
I loved the art style and the game idea on the first sight, and i also loved to play it for few hours.
That is until the game started showing it's difficulty and making it a nightmare to play.
Soon the earlier fun and joy was gone and replaces by swears and multiple restarts.
I don't want to judge it due to it still being a fresh release, but i seriously hope that some fixes/changes will be done.

It could be easier if there would be a CO-OP mode, because on short days and cruel nights, things get out of hands very quickly.

The catapults almost always miss the first shot when the enemies jump out of the way.

Not enough men to hire, and too many blood moon nights which always brought down my defences, leaving the peniless king with a dozen of bums in a ruined castle.

I don't know about other, but the game leaves me sad and angry after destroying everything that i spend the last two hours for.

It would be handy if the player would be given something else than archers and two catapults to even out growing masses of the enemies. Especially when the game brings in the special enemies.

What i would also love to see, is completely game changing randomized maps. Now the only randomized bits are the shrines, camps and portals, but what if the whole land layout could randomize. Instead of two direction defence lines, there would be maps where you build your kindom against a mountain wall, so that only thing you have to do is to procceed forwards.

reviewText:
This is by far the most beautiful pixel-art game I've ever played.
The content towards the beginning is challenging and fun to play, but later on it becomes monotonous and strung out. Travelling from one end of your kingdom to another end to manage it and send people out can take an entire day. Late game content doesn't bring much and is the same as the early-game content, just with more money and more people. Map generation can sometimes be unfair.
If the game was shorter or had some better content towards the end of the game, I would want to play it more.
As far as play-time to price efficiency, it's not good. 10 dollars for a game I spent ten hours on, some spent more, most spent as much as I did or less, is too much. Could easily be priced at a 5 dollar game or a 2 dollar game.
What needs to be remembered however is that this game is a flash game, nothing more. It looks damn good for a flash game, but like many other flash games, it is severely limited.

Tl;Dr Good game but not worth the 10 dollars. Buy it if it's on sale for at least 50%. If you really want it, go for 25%.

reviewText:
Atmospheric, sidescrolling Tower-defense and City-builder with timelessly beautiful pixel-grapic!

You expand your kingdom during the day and defend against the nameless demon-horde at night. It's quite enjoyable but gets frustrating after some time, since you constantly have to run your character from one end of your kingdom to the other. What's really missing is basic feedback as to how your defenses are doing, since you are only sseing what is right next to your king/queen. You can't even tell how many of your subjects just got crushed in the latest attack. Also, the placements for upgrade shrines, recruitement camps and even the bases for your towers are randomly distributed every game. This makes the game a little too much luck-based to be honest.

So it is not a prefect game, but nonetheless still highly recommendable. It's just an awesome idea and georgeous to play!

reviewText:
Hey you! Yes You, the reader and wallet user!

Buy this game!
Here why :

Demonic evil monsters, build a 2D town / kingdom, beautiful sprites, actually engaging gameplay, addictive, complete and utter shear panic on every fifth day.

Heres some advice to get started :

* Defend 1 side, expand on the other, not both at same time.
* If you find a neutral camp near base, dont destroy 1 tree between you and that camp (all other trees between you are fine)
* Don't rush portals! My greatest mistake was destroying a portal turn 6, only for a massive army that would make might and magic weep eat my whole left side and steal my crown (not joking they do that, you lose)
* build farms behind walls, these workers are dedicated to death and service.
* don't buy everything, you need a plan
* deer give nice gold, but need you to lead them to your archers 90% of the time, they run in the opposite to you.
* tall grass + your horse stationary = more sprinting

reviewText: A pretty fun game of discovery and resource management, well worth the small price point, with good pixel art and a nice moody soundtrack.  There's also a free demo of sorts in the form of the original prototype ( http://www.noio.nl/2013/10/kingdom/ ).  The full version adds a fair bit of extra content, though I wish there was more.  For me the primary draw was discovery, which also meant that eventually I would find all there is to find (though then again is this not true of a book or film).  That said the layout is randomized a little each time, so while the final push and the opening days tend to go the same every time the second act varies from session to session.  Overall, I'm glad I picked this up and I'll probably even get it again when it comes to Xbone.  Good fun whether you have a few minutes or a few hours.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Kingdom is Great!

Kingdom is a game about creating something out of nothing. Exploring a new land, claiming it, hiring workers, and building it up to your specifications. You have the freedom to take whatever path you want, upgrading the things you feel deserve it. It's rare that such a simplistic game can provide so much entertainement. Not to mention, such a depth of strategy.

The graphics are extremely pretty and the music is very atmospheric. It's the kind of game you can play to relax after a long day. That doesn't mean it's not difficult, though. Enemies can be brutal and it is key that you use your coins wisely. Every choice you make could completely change the future of your kingdom. This game will provide tons of fun for anyone who likes management type games where you develop and expand. It's pretty fun to watch your kingdom grow.

reviewText:
Ok, so this review is both a recommendation and a warning, ok, so this game is pretty, it is unique, the soundtrack is neat, and it is a challenging game. However, there is one major problem (which may be fixed in future updates) and that is, there is really no choice, there are 3 combat units in the game, one of which has a cap of 2 units, another has a cap of 4, so it's really spam archers, make sure you have 4 knights, 2 catapults, and build up for each blood moon or an attack on a portal. Once you have your knights, catapults, defences, whatever, all you really do is prepare spare men for when you finally send off an attack party to suicide, and it gets really boring just preparing to attack over and over. Another issue i have is one enemy in particular, most people call it the 'Ufo' enemy, and it swoops down, grabs your men and flies off, it can do this to any of your men, including knights that cost so much, and on top of this, your archers on the ground cannot target them (they can still target other enemies and if the arrow hits the flying ♥♥♥♥er and kills it you've won the lottery.

TL:DR Great game, get it on sale, gets a bit repetitive, not for people who dislike a challenge

reviewText:
I love this game. It's simplicity is amazing and I have spent hours playing it (on somone else's account). I have yet to beat the game, as it seems very difficult. I never feel like on of my lost runs was a waste of time, thought. Every time I lose I figure out something new. A new strategy, something I did wrong, something I didn't do right, a way to speed something up, etc. As weird as it sounds, this makes a decent party game if none of the people at the party know how to play the game. My friend, my brother, and I had a several hours long session of this game where we all gave our input and strategized together. I've done this a lot and it's fun every time. It's also the reason that most of my hours are on someone else's account.

Now for the bad. Well, when I say bad, I mean I haven't figured out a way around these problems. The world is randomly generated, and sometimes it is MUCH more in your favour. I'm not sure if it's always winnable. It probably is, as I don't have all the strategies down, but the point is that you are to some extent, at the game's mercy. Another issue is that there really isn't much to the game. You can get all of your buildings fully upgraded to their final form very early on if you're quick and if the game gives you a good layout, and then after that you can only expand, not upgrade. That said, the game is still being updated, so who knows how much they're still going to add.

Anyways, I can definitely recommend this game. It looks great. It sounds great. It's fun. ect.

reviewText:
Fun game, definitely worth the sale price. A rogue-like tower defense/town management game where the only controls are the four directional keys.

Cons
-Gets repetitive after a while
-Buildings can only be built on pre-determined locations randomized at game start, which can sometimes screw you, or sometimes make a game too easy
-Little replay value

reviewText:
I have yet to beat this game, though I believe I have gotten very close once or twice.

I say I believe I have gotten close because for the life of me I don't really know, and that's what makes this experience so interesting. Kingdom tells you almost nothing, You'll die a lot and have to start over quite a bit, but once you figure out exactly how the systems work you will start progressing, and that progress feels amazing.

Here's the problem. Once you have an understanding of how to progress, and once you have reached the upper tier of progression, Kingdom kind of loses the mystery which is what makes it so special. Then the worst thing that could happen will happen: you'll lose. You'll die and have to start over but already know exactly what you need to do and how far you can go.

You'll be infuriated because you know why you died, you were randomly given a night that was way tougher than any of the previous nights, or your stupid guards and knights will all be on one side of you defenses and not on the other, and when they start to migrate your kingdom is so big that they won't make it in time to stop things from falling apart.

Then you'll be done, because at the point the mystery is gone and the lack of direct control over your Kingdom will stand as a more glaring fault in the game's design rather than a oh
date: now why did that happen?" magical

gameplay experience.

But I happily played this game for 8 hours. I really fell into uncovering the mystery behind the systems and just trying to see how far I could get and how long I could last. I paid $10 for this game and at 8 hours of play time I would easily have spent another $10. Highly recommended for those wonderful hours of figuring things out then trying again and again.

reviewText: An extremely minimalistic 'city' building / survival game.  It's gameplay design is streamlined to such an extreme there's only left and right movement and one button - drop/assign gold.  It's rare to see a game which is so simplistic while still achieving a respectable amount of depth.  On the flipside, to enjoy the game you have to be able to put up a lot of simplicity, most notably, silly follower AI that is guaranteed to initally not do what you hope they do.  Eventually you learn strategies to help manipulate them - but unfortunately nothing will help their terrible aim.\n\nI enjoyed the game and would fully recommend it.

reviewText:
This game's graphics remind me of Echo of the Wilds, which is a good thing.

It's part tower defense, management sim, and exploration. Here is how I break it down:

Sound: Fantastic soundtrack that adds to the immersion, even if it's not too varied.

Graphics: Far as pixel art games go, I can't complain much. The characters themselves could have been better, but the buildings and scenery is spot on.

Gameplay: Fun, challenging, and simplistic. Plays just fine on a controller or on the keyboard.

Originality: There are other games out there that feel like this game on the surface, however the mechanics are what stand out. They are so simple that a 1 min tutorial does the trick, but as you progress you feel like you're in a more complex situation even whilst using the same mechanics. That to me felt very original.

LAST THOUGHTS: I greatly enjoy the game, though a tad bit of customization, back story, and variety would be nice. I do give the game a thumbs up, because up against a $9.99 price point I simply feel like it's worth the money. It will be enough to distract me for a day or so, and when I'm tired of it I'm sure to dust it back off and play months down the road.

reviewText:
A brilliant little game, which will get you at least the dollars worth out of it.

The pros are in the simplicity of the game form, which make it easy to pick up and run with.

Wherein also the cons lie, in that the simplicity seems to also simplify the AI, such that you may wast emany hours getting to a point at which the AI locks you into a struggle of attrition, slowly supplying the wrong side of your kingdom with troops - now safe from attack - while you are under heavy threat from the other.

Although mostly pleasant, this is the side that will madden you. From archers wandering out of your walls in the dead of night for no apparent reason, directly into the mouth of the marauding enemy. To your own catapults deciding that even though the enemy is out of range, they'll happily fire a boulder into your own troops and take out 30 of them just as the monsters arrive at the wall.

Further, you may find that you need a single engineer to further advance but they keep wandering out to get killed because some time ago you asked one to build a wall just beyond your current one. You can't undo this...you can't undo anything. So you may string along a continuous stream of engineers that never make it, and find yourself restarting.

What this could have used was a lot of inspiration from King Arthur's World back in the SNES days. That you build exactly the troop type you want at that moment, and that you could have a modicum of control over their actions.

All-in-all, it's interesting enough and very fun if you coax out the quirks of the game and try to work around them.

reviewText:
Kingdom: Nothing Lasts... Except your Kingdom, it'll last forever with enough archers!

This game needs a lot of work. It is fairly fun in the early game as you scramble to build a decent fort against the demons, but once you have enough archers and your base in stonebased, it becomes trivial. By around day 30 I had enough archers that nothing would even dent my walls, I thought that the ogres would up the challenge, but they did not.

The game begins to stutter once you have too many units on the map; the archers being the main issue for this problem as everytime they shot at something the game would have an FPS drop. I collected villagers from both sides of the map daily so around day 50 I had about 150 guys running around and by day 60 when I had broken 3 demon portals I was zipping around the map collecting ALL the fresh villagers. At one point I thought the game was going to crash because I had like 175 archers alone.

There is a lack of variety in monster types and villager types, which I found disappointing, after you've seen a late stage bloodmoon, you've seen em all. On top of that the game pretty much nudges you at making nothing but archers to win the game. You dont need that many farmers and about 5-10 engineers are enough for your base in the end game. The game became very boring and I had to force myself to finish it after I broke the 3rd demon portal.

The music and graphics are the high points of the game, it is very pretty and relaxing. I loved that everything was reflected in the water. The sky was very pretty as well as the background. I don't have anything bad to say about the aesthetics of the game. Also, I thought the control scheme of the game was interesting, I somewhat enjoyed that.

I bought this game when it was on sale this week so I believe it was somewhat worth the price, but it is not worth full price. The game is too short, too repetitive after a certain amount of time, and too easy to be worth 10 dollars. You could probably slap this game on the Android or Iphone and it would be perfect on that format.

5/10 Game. Although I see that they're still updating it, maybe they will add new content and make it more challenging? Only time will tell.

reviewText:
I love this game. But it gets frustrating (and sometimes not possible to win) unless several of the game mechanics are in your favour (especially placement of portals/structures/farms), which all seem to be based on luck. It's a game that I play knowing I'll never beat it. Many reviews that I've read, however, blame the mechanics that are interesting and fine as they are, so long as you know how to use them (i.e. if it takes you so long to travel from one end of your kingdom to another, rest your horse better or limit expansion of your kingdom; if your workers get killed chopping down trees at night, learn to send them out in the morning; don't get mad blame the game! learn something!) If you don't understand the game, that's entirely your own fault.

A few things that do bother me:
1. The AI is...... nonexistent? You can't cancel orders, so you quickly learn to time your commands according to when your workers won't get killed. Then, occasionally, one will decide to wander outside of the existing walls, without you ordering them to, in the middle of a siege, just because they figure it's the perfect time to repair a broken outside wall. And then they get hit, lose their hammer, pick it back up, and repeat. And repeat.

2. Everything is based on luck, which both makes a simple game like this fun to play again, but sometimes far too frustrating. But because multiple things rely on chance, there is potential for everything to go to hell, despite your efforts. The first patch really did seem to help with that.

3. The game at first didn't seem balanced, as no matter your efforts the enemies exponentially grew and swarmed to proportions that no amount of preparation or people could stop them, but that has since been fixed. Thank you, devs, for listening!

A few things, however, that I would not change (based on negative reviews that seem to complain about the game not meeting their personal preferences, rather than objective problems with the game):

1. Keep the horse's lack of endurance. It inevitably sets a limit on how much you can accomplish in one day, but it adds interest if you're stuck in the woods at night, and means that you can't always outrun your evenmies.

2. I like that this game doesn't hold your hand. How things are done are made relatively clear, but when to implement these changes and why are left to you to decide, and you'll gain that knowledge from interacting with the community and from your own experience.

reviewText: A pretty fun game of discovery and resource management, well worth the small price point, with good pixel art and a nice moody soundtrack.  There's also a free demo of sorts in the form of the original prototype ( http://www.noio.nl/2013/10/kingdom/ ).  The full version adds a fair bit of extra content, though I wish there was more.  For me the primary draw was discovery, which also meant that eventually I would find all there is to find (though then again is this not true of a book or film).  That said the layout is randomized a little each time, so while the final push and the opening days tend to go the same every time the second act varies from session to session.  Overall, I'm glad I picked this up and I'll probably even get it again when it comes to Xbone.  Good fun whether you have a few minutes or a few hours.

and if you want to get anywhere, ive gathered you need to destroy the portals? ive not yet done it but im guessing. and to do that you need at least one knight and maybe 15+ archers to get it down without them all dying cos the creatures are just way too over powered. theres no way you can do it with the randomly generated coin production from the start.

reviewText: I wish I could give this game a 5/10, and not a modern gaming review 5/10 where it would be one of the worst games ever, but an honest five out of ten.  This game is fun, I dumped an hour into it, and probably will dump a good few more.  But you are...deceptively limited in what you can do.  WIth a game such as this, where you will fail often (and you *will* fail often), an element of randomness, either through RNG, or through how your playstyle effects the world, is appreciated. In this game, your playstyle changes in that you learn not to do one, very specific thing that caused your death, and then do the exact same thing otherwise.  There's an element of RNG in here, but it's extremely limited, and basically means your village will have a *farm* here instead of a bridge

reviewText:
My one BIG tip to new players

First of all -
1 . A great indie game — one of the best ones out there
2. The simplicity and the small variety of possible moves creates a real strategical challenge
3. If you just get frustrated and don't fully understand the game rules, by exploring yourself — read one of the great strategy guides available here

Now to my tip -
Hunting is as profitable as farming. Just keep in mind that hunting gets more productive as you extend the range of your archers by cutting down trees. Don't rush extending and building, BUT - destroy some trees to the left and give the archers some extra space for hunting. The only downside is that they sometimes return too late to the camp (= don't return at all). And keep in mind that destroying the last tree by a human camp" – destroys the camp itself."

reviewText: An extremely minimalistic 'city' building / survival game.  It's gameplay design is streamlined to such an extreme there's only left and right movement and one button - drop/assign gold.  It's rare to see a game which is so simplistic while still achieving a respectable amount of depth.  On the flipside, to enjoy the game you have to be able to put up a lot of simplicity, most notably, silly follower AI that is guaranteed to initally not do what you hope they do.  Eventually you learn strategies to help manipulate them - but unfortunately nothing will help their terrible aim.\n\nI enjoyed the game and would fully recommend it.

reviewText:
First things first:
This game is really, really good.

To play this game you need to understand that your kingdom will NOT always keep your enemies out. In other words: dont count on winning the game on your second or third try. Although you will gradually survive longer, you will eventually have to start again, and again, and again.

Pros:
-Aweosome survival/stratergy game
-Nice pixel art
-Really challenges the player
-Did I mention that it has some beautiful pixel art

Cons:
-Very difficult (There is no difficulty setting which would be nice)
-Day/night cycles are ridiculously short
-Horse stamina takes a really long time to recover
-Workers are very slow
-Archer AI is not very good
-every 5 nights there is a really difficult wave
-Short tutorial

Overall this is a really good game that could benefit from a few more options but other than that its great! Although I bought this game during a sale for half price it is definalty worth the $10 it usually is.


EDIT:
After some of the latet updates the AI's have been improved so much and now archers and builders run back to your base when it gets dark which is nice. Also, now there is no 'blood moon night' every 5 days which gives you more time to prepare, but it seems to be random which makes it hard to predict what to do.

reviewText:
TL;DR It's the only game that actually makes you care about NPC's

You know, I think Kingdom may be the only game that actually made me emotionally invested in anything other than my loot.  When you build up your own Kingdom, you really feel like the people are your responsibility, and you feel awful when any of them die.  It has pretty good progression, and you really feel like you constantly have to be doing something.  It kinda has that Harvest Moon feel, you know.  You feel like you wasted time if you stand still for even a second, since you kinda did.  There are lots of ways to get gold, but they can't really be accomplished purely by yourself.  You depend completely on your archers, builders, farmers, and everyone else.  But in a roundabout way, they also completely depend on you, since you are essentially the strategist.  I mean, it's not too uncommon to be the strategist, case and point Fire Emblem, but rarely do you still have a playable character who can get stuff done on your own.  It creates a really interesting gameplaym style, and really reinforces the whole feeling guilty when your recruits die.  Like, you recruited them, for a measly gold coin, to defend you and do all of your other dirty work, without much choice on their part.  When they die, they die for you, and purely because you recruited them.  Additionally, the graphics and overall feel are really spot on for this kind of game.

Since I'm not a big fan of /10's, I'll just say whether I recommend it or not, and in what circumstances.  Basically, it's not a game for everyone, it's not a game that will give you 100's of hours, and it's not the game with crazy cutscenes and story.  It's a game you play to be fully immersed in and actually give a damn about.  If that interests you, buy it.  If you  refuse to play a game without that stuff.  then don't play it.  But at the end of the day, there's really no reason not to pick it up.  It's really cheap and something that can really be called an experience.

reviewText:
So I've never done a review before, but from reading what others have written and taking into account my own expericence, I have a few things to say about this game.

1. The music in this game is amazing, never has music in a game effected about how I feel about my current situation with said game so much. Whether it was when I realized by the sound that a blood moon was near, or when I had heard the sweet sound of those bells signifying I had made it to another day.

2. The 2D side scrolling element keeps you engaged. It keeps you constantly moving or aware of your surroundings. Your kingdom is literally dependent on you, where you go and what you do in a spot will effect your game heavily. With regards to the mighty steed your given, it's just a horse. Horses can't run forever and to expect so is, isn't reasonable in this game. I know it took me by surprise for a second, but it challenged me to think about if I needed to run or not sometimes. My only complaint is that the walking horse movement is way less awesome than the running horses. Seriously, cape flying in the wind, hugged up against your mighty steedy, seems way cooler than trotting along.

3. A lot of people seem to be complaining about the lack of explanation going on during the game itself. I will admit, the game doesn't offer much help besides a miniscule tutorial and a few simple instructions. But, I think that's the point of it. You are a monarch trying build (or rebuild?) a kingdom and there's no guidebook to doing so. This game won't hold your hand, it'll toss you out of the nest. It's up to you whether you fly or not. It took me three playthroughs to have SOME understanding of this complex and beautiful game. But that's what I loved about it, I found out how I can lose and came back bigger and stronger each subsquent play through. So if you don't like being thrown out into a world without much help, this game isn't for you.

4. The AI of this game is at best, simple minded. Archers=shoot, Builders=build, farmers= farm etc. This is a pro and a con. Pro because it's easy to understand and work with, con because there's no way to change it up once you make the decision to purchase your choice of simpelton. What I appreciated about it though is that it forces you to consider what your future goals and manage your time. Do you need those archers to hold your wooden wall? Or should you focus on reinforcing those walls instead of having more men to guard them? As previously mentioned, it took me a few tries to understand how much my early game truly effected my gameplay later on.

4A. By managing time I meant how you chose to use ithe simpelton AI. It challenges you to decide what to build, when to build, and where to build. Having walls is nice, but if night time comes and they aren't done, well you're gonna have a bad time. This isn't just for walls as well, there's recruiting, exploration and much more. But t I don't want to spoil too muchmore I know I already have given away a lot.

5. The enemies at times are overwhelming, but sometimes you won't even notice they attacked. It's seemingly arbitrary, and I love that. It keeps you on your toes when considering what is to come the next night. But sometimes, no amount of archer or steady wall is good enough to fend off your foes. They break threw, they beat your people, they pillage, they destroy and they leave. You can't do much about that sometimes. What you can do though, is wipe of the blood and dirt and get back up. Is it going to be easy? Most likely not, unless you have a healthy amount of gold or are lucky enough to find a chest or a merchant. But nothing worth having is easy to get. Sure, it would be nice to have an easy way out and recover everything with one simple click or whatever, but it would for sure not feel the same. I was frustrated, horrified and downright vengeful when I saw those monsters breakthrough. But it didn't stop me, it only motivated me to keep going. Sure I lost in the end, but next time I'll be more prepared to face those devilish raiders. This game isn't forgving, it would be way worse if it was. It is very rewarding though, to feel the sense of victory after fending off a wave, or recovering ground after a devastating loss, I haven't gotten that from a game in a long time.

Sorry for the wall of text, didn't really know how else to put it. If there's only one real thing you want to consider before you buy this game, it's whether or not you're ready for a challenge. A very rewarding challenge at that.

reviewText:
This game is utterly fantastic.

Despite it's simple mechanics, it's amazingly rich in strategy and keeps you on your toes the entire time with no chances to rest past the first few days.

Case in point:  I had made it to somewhere around day 30 or so, and destroyed both portals on one side. I had an extensive kingdom, with plentiful citizens in good ratios, making more money then I could ever use, and I was extending towards the other side's portals. I started to get arrogant and impatient, and destroyed the second camp on that side to push forward faster, thinking I had PLENTY of guys to handle the next portal. WRONG. My defenses and citizens started to get slowly picked away at, and the only other camp was on the other side of the map. I limped my way to day 60 or so, trying to recoup my losses night after night, but ultimately failed. I lost because of my hubris, and nothing else.

If you like thoughtful strategy games (with beautiful soundtracks) this is the one for you.

reviewText:
tl;dr:
Wait to see if there is more development made on the game before buying.
There is a lot of potential (and a bit of room for improvement).
Currently 6/10 IMO

What to expect out of this game (as of patch 1.01):
1. Amazing graphics and a superb soundtrack that ties directly into gameplay.
2. Minimalistic design which makes it easy to learn with patience and experimentation.
3. Challenging (to learn and effectively manipulate all mechanics) and unforgiving gameplay.
4. Some conflicting game designs.
5. Fast paced and can easily make you frusterated (but don't give up).
6. Potential for greater depth with a few changes.


1. Amazing graphics and a superb soundtrack that ties directly into gameplay.
This is the first thing anyone who plays the game will notice. The graphics have so much effort and thought put into them. The layering affect is well done and really adds a certain depth you likely won't get from many other sprite games. The music sets the tone very well and you can always tell when danger is coming your way (spoilers: blood moon music).

2. Minimalistic design which makes it easy to learn with patience and experimentation.
There are many smalls design choices which you will likely miss on your first play through. It is important to learn from your mistakes every play through. It is also very important to explore, even waste precious gold (which you will learn isn't too hard to get later on in the game). There is a surprising amount of depth hidden in the minimalistic gameplay. Just as an example, you can herd deer towards hunting bowmen to earn money more easily early on. You can also drop coins to bribe" Terrors to run away. Eventually
date: once I learned enough of the game mechanics
recommended:
I was able to understand most design choices and like them.

3. Challenging (to learn and effectively manipulate all mechanics) and unforgiving gameplay.
Your first playthrough ever is going to end in failure and there is no way around this. This isn't bad though. Most short games that aren't (REALLY) easy usually push you towards a loss if you're a newbie to the game (or force feed an uneccesarily long tutorial down your throat). However
hoursPlayed: it becomes challenging when you first start developing your strategy and dying over random mistakes that aren't necessarily tied with how you built your base. As you progress later

4. Some conflicting game designs.
First
column22: I'd like to mention that the AI is actually pretty solid overall. Often
column23: it is the player's mistake that causes units to do stupid stuff. The biggest thing I think shows me a conflict in design is map size
column24: horse endurance

column27: and expand your kingdom on. However

column29: one of the core/promoted mechanics of expanding becomes an extremely unviable option. Your obese horse (fanart of this please) and the short day/night cycle make it nigh-impossible to cross even a decently sized kingdom
column30: not to mention a base that crosses all the way to the end of one side. If you're trying to recover from a devastating attack
column31: it makes it extremely difficult when your limited wallet means you have to cross your main base to get to farmers to give you gold or reach archers on the edge of your base. This issue gets stacked against your odds even more so when you consider one of the current monsters. The flying tentacle beasts will come en masse to completely eat all of your troops
column33: and workers. If your soldiers are shooting anything but them

column35: let alone the tens that spawn later in the game. The only way to replace/gain more units is to go out to camps and pay them to come back to your kingdom. They then walk at an insanely slow speed
column36: making far camps often unviable. When you start expanding

defend." ends up being something that is used against you.

5. Fast paced and can easily make you frusterated (but don't give up).
If you've gotten this far in my review (I would be surprised considering the blocks of text) and still want to give the game a go right now

you'll only be met with further frustration and time wasted not just restarting and playing a new game.

reviewText: People who give this game a negative review due to it being difficult are ridiculous. Is this game challenging? Yes. Impossible? Absolutely not. There are balacing issues and some standard A.I. issues such as sometimes your archers are off balanced on sides and your builders dont split jobs when they are left and right. All of that can be over come with smart thinking and plenty of recruiting. Taking down gates is simple it just takes alot of build up with alittle bit of luck on your random map placement. This game is really addicting and quite enjoyable yet frustrating at times. For 9.99 id say this game is worth the money. Also the game devs are active with the community so expect alot of quality updates in the future.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: So I'm going to say I recommend this game, but there is def some work that needs to be done. Primarily? The AI. As the king you have very little control over what is actually going on, just who and what has money, sadly the AI that does have control seems to have intelligence similiar to that of a goose. Scratch that, a goose would run away from a 10ft tall monster. Builders are completly suicidal, and will rush into anything to get a job done. Wall needs repairing because of a horde of monsters? They're there. Catapult needs reloading behind enemy lines? They will try. You started a construction project and they took to long to get there and now the sun is setting and certain doom is lurking around the corner? These hammer weilding lil ♥♥♥♥♥ don't even hesitate. On to archers. Perhaps a blood moon night wiped out a couple layer of defenses? Well any open spots in turrets will soon be filled even if it is miles away from your nearest wall. They also tend to come back to base the last possible second before nightfall if they are hunting, and I have lost many a soul to a monster blitz before my poor dense villagers got back. Honestly though my favorite are the farmers. If you upgrade a farm to tier two they treat it like a rally point that is safe, even if you havn't put up the walls yet. RIP farmers. Guess they got to water their crops with blood. I'm sure all of this sounds infuriating and not at all worth it, but honestly it is a quite enjoyable game. As of right now most the stupid AI kinks can be worked around by building the right things at the right times and knowing what can go wrong if you screw up. Almost like an unintended difficulty bonus perhaps? I don't know. I do know however that I will be keeping my eye on this in hopes of AI improvements, or perhaps the ability to set nightitme rally points for villagers / mark towers as not to be used / mark build projects to be delayed. Those simple fixes alone will make this game easily 9/10 to me as a fun light game to play.

reviewText:
Awesome game so far.
I'm really loving the art style.
My only gripe so far is with the AI but, that just adds to the challenge.
I would love to see more unit and different structures in the future, even one time use itmes.
For all those complaining about the horse stamina; It's part of the strategy. You can't just hold run all the time because it will tire your horse out and you have to wait for ages to recharge, use it in small bursts or tapping run, your horse will let you know when it's about to run out of stamina because it wil let a short burst of air from it's nose. If you do this you can basically run across the entire map.

reviewText:
So I've never done a review before, but from reading what others have written and taking into account my own expericence, I have a few things to say about this game.

1. The music in this game is amazing, never has music in a game effected about how I feel about my current situation with said game so much. Whether it was when I realized by the sound that a blood moon was near, or when I had heard the sweet sound of those bells signifying I had made it to another day.

2. The 2D side scrolling element keeps you engaged. It keeps you constantly moving or aware of your surroundings. Your kingdom is literally dependent on you, where you go and what you do in a spot will effect your game heavily. With regards to the mighty steed your given, it's just a horse. Horses can't run forever and to expect so is, isn't reasonable in this game. I know it took me by surprise for a second, but it challenged me to think about if I needed to run or not sometimes. My only complaint is that the walking horse movement is way less awesome than the running horses. Seriously, cape flying in the wind, hugged up against your mighty steedy, seems way cooler than trotting along.

3. A lot of people seem to be complaining about the lack of explanation going on during the game itself. I will admit, the game doesn't offer much help besides a miniscule tutorial and a few simple instructions. But, I think that's the point of it. You are a monarch trying build (or rebuild?) a kingdom and there's no guidebook to doing so. This game won't hold your hand, it'll toss you out of the nest. It's up to you whether you fly or not. It took me three playthroughs to have SOME understanding of this complex and beautiful game. But that's what I loved about it, I found out how I can lose and came back bigger and stronger each subsquent play through. So if you don't like being thrown out into a world without much help, this game isn't for you.

4. The AI of this game is at best, simple minded. Archers=shoot, Builders=build, farmers= farm etc. This is a pro and a con. Pro because it's easy to understand and work with, con because there's no way to change it up once you make the decision to purchase your choice of simpelton. What I appreciated about it though is that it forces you to consider what your future goals and manage your time. Do you need those archers to hold your wooden wall? Or should you focus on reinforcing those walls instead of having more men to guard them? As previously mentioned, it took me a few tries to understand how much my early game truly effected my gameplay later on.

4A. By managing time I meant how you chose to use ithe simpelton AI. It challenges you to decide what to build, when to build, and where to build. Having walls is nice, but if night time comes and they aren't done, well you're gonna have a bad time. This isn't just for walls as well, there's recruiting, exploration and much more. But t I don't want to spoil too muchmore I know I already have given away a lot.

5. The enemies at times are overwhelming, but sometimes you won't even notice they attacked. It's seemingly arbitrary, and I love that. It keeps you on your toes when considering what is to come the next night. But sometimes, no amount of archer or steady wall is good enough to fend off your foes. They break threw, they beat your people, they pillage, they destroy and they leave. You can't do much about that sometimes. What you can do though, is wipe of the blood and dirt and get back up. Is it going to be easy? Most likely not, unless you have a healthy amount of gold or are lucky enough to find a chest or a merchant. But nothing worth having is easy to get. Sure, it would be nice to have an easy way out and recover everything with one simple click or whatever, but it would for sure not feel the same. I was frustrated, horrified and downright vengeful when I saw those monsters breakthrough. But it didn't stop me, it only motivated me to keep going. Sure I lost in the end, but next time I'll be more prepared to face those devilish raiders. This game isn't forgving, it would be way worse if it was. It is very rewarding though, to feel the sense of victory after fending off a wave, or recovering ground after a devastating loss, I haven't gotten that from a game in a long time.

Sorry for the wall of text, didn't really know how else to put it. If there's only one real thing you want to consider before you buy this game, it's whether or not you're ready for a challenge. A very rewarding challenge at that.

reviewText:
Kingdom is delightful to play, but it's short and has a game-breaking issue.

Positive
++Beautiful graphics nicely themed by the music. It's quite simply well made.
+Simple controls, yet not a simple game. You can play it with one hand, but if you don't spend your gold wisely you will quickly see your kingdom fall.

Negative
-Once you start clustering up large amounts of archers, the game start lagging on the strongest of computers. At the same time, not having large clusters of archers in the late part of the game would lead to your defeat.
-It's relatively short and lack replay value.

reviewText:
This game is utterly fantastic.

Despite it's simple mechanics, it's amazingly rich in strategy and keeps you on your toes the entire time with no chances to rest past the first few days.

Case in point:  I had made it to somewhere around day 30 or so, and destroyed both portals on one side. I had an extensive kingdom, with plentiful citizens in good ratios, making more money then I could ever use, and I was extending towards the other side's portals. I started to get arrogant and impatient, and destroyed the second camp on that side to push forward faster, thinking I had PLENTY of guys to handle the next portal. WRONG. My defenses and citizens started to get slowly picked away at, and the only other camp was on the other side of the map. I limped my way to day 60 or so, trying to recoup my losses night after night, but ultimately failed. I lost because of my hubris, and nothing else.

If you like thoughtful strategy games (with beautiful soundtracks) this is the one for you.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I have, at the time of writing this, played 8 hours of Kingdom, and have finally managed to beat the game. It took me around 6 tries I think.

Art:
Kingdom is gorgeous, in a way I didn't think Pixel-Art games could be. The most beautiful thing in Kingdom is the river, which actually reflects on the surface, and is by far the most beautiful Pixel-Style piece of work I've ever seen!

Sound:
Kingdom's soundtrack is beautiful, sometimes calming, sometimes haunting, always setting a good mood to the game.
The SFX is subtle, simple, sometimes abstract, but very fitting, and very easy on the ears.

Gameplay:
The only way for the player to interact with the world is by moving coins around, giving them to people to recruit them, putting them to use for constructing defenses or farms, or buying tools. [there are some more uses, but I will refrain from spoiling the experience ;) ]

I noticed minimal lags on assaults in the very late game, when I had lots and lots of archers, but apart from that the game is very well optimized.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well, I normally dont write an actual legit review. This time though I need too. I have a mere 22 hours of game play which is a drop in most games. Also 10$ might be a bit steep considering the game.

Even with all that said. It was very worth the money. It took around 4 tries to finally get a victory. It took about 4 real life days of casual play to play the game winning win on day 88 I think. It was so awarding you can't help, but sit back and enjoy the absolute feeling of victory. It's not fast. It's like a 2D RTS in my mind. Back when APM was not the winning factor.

For that, it gets a +1 for me. I recommend it to any one.

reviewText: Enjoyable, fun and beautiful game, but unfortunately very short lived and leaves you wanting much more. After the first few hours in, once you start to win the game, the game pretty much becomes over at this point. Trying to destroy the last portals is just incredibly tedious, at that point you realize that the concept of the game is very interesting, but it feels much more like an incomplete prototype with a single, short, and ridiculously tedious level to complete.\n\nI'm giving it a thumbs up just because im always on the lookout for original and interesting concepts, and i would say give it a try if you are like me, but don't expect this game to be fun for more than a few hours.

reviewText:
There are a few things that bother me in-game, like:

- Lazy villagers (can't they run?).
- Dumb villagers (srsly why all the workers walk together?).
- Can't command our soldiers, for example: I had 6 archers on the right wall and on the left wall 0, we can't give them orders, that's pretty anoying since we are the king, doesn't make sense.
- The fact that your villagers can't run, it's really anoying.
- After some time the village gets bigger, and you spend one day just to get to the other side.
- Can't select wich villagers it's going to take a role, they just pick the first role they find.

Except for those things, I love the game, the pixel art is amazing and the controls are simple, the difficulty makes you wanna play more and more. I recommend it.


btw, pixel art 10/10 xD
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Between the ease of discovery; the fantastic, minecraft-esque soundtrack, and the absolutely gorgeous visuals, this is definitely something I'd recommend picking up.

Many of the negative reviews raise points I think are entirely valid, but seem to put more emphasis on those negative aspects than I did, hence my recommendation. I would say that if you can't get down with RNGeesus Christ as your run's lord and savior (or tormentor), you might not enjoy this as much.

As it stands, I have been recommending the game to all my friends, and would love to see the developer address some of the few mechanical shortcomings, but I'll likely be playing it again shortly after this review goes up.

reviewText:
Very interesting concept with a tons of potential. I must admit the game is very challenging and it takes several tries to understand the game mechanisms and refine the optimal strategy, and it can be a bit repetitive at times. However once you understand how the AI behaves and the core gameplay mechanisms then it becomes a fun challenge to destroy the enemy portals in as little time as possible.

Pros:
The game is very simple and it is easy for new players to understand what the game is about.
It is challenging and the player must stay focused at all times, or risk falling behind.
Cons:
It is not possible to fall back to previously saved games after you lose your game. So even if you do one silly mistake in an otherwise perfect game you must start over. It would be nice touch to allow players to fall back to the last time they saved.
The game is too unforgiving for new players. Allowing the player to adjust the difficulty could be nice.

If you like resource management/optimization games then this game is definitely worth the $10 price tag.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is THE game for strategists. If you have played games such as Convoy and FTL, this game is kinda the same, but just more toned down. It relies heavily on money, your ability to quickly think and strategies, and, most of all, on you panicking. It also tries you're patience... to the absolute limit. I love how you are forced to explore and think for yourself, not be babysat by the tutorial throughout your first 20 minutes of playing. It's stylistic design and sounds/ music is also a great part of the game, as it can either make you relaxed or tensed at the perfect moments in time, (such as, when there is a blood moon, the sound gets very tense and the night feels darker. When the sun rises, sometimes calming music plays and the scenery erupts into sunlit beauty, mixed with the safe sound of the bells, marking your survival of another day).

The game allows the character to do what they want, essentially, and doesn't force them to do certain tasks before going on to discover the world the player is in. The game does however make it very irritating when expanding, as you put a lot of your resources at risk. The AI of the characters are irritating at best, however it does make you have to think about when and where you do projects as it may create difficulties.

What I would like to see added is just some sort of extra speed mechanic so it doesn't take 5 years to travel from one place to another, and the blood moons are fewer and more spaced out in timing, so new players can easily get engrossed in the game's aspects instead of worrying, OMG
hoursPlayed: I love the game and how it has turned out! Many thanks to the developers for making this game. it has been a real experience trying to learn how to play it
voteText: and I adore it to death."

reviewText:
I have, at the time of writing this, played 8 hours of Kingdom, and have finally managed to beat the game. It took me around 6 tries I think.

Art:
Kingdom is gorgeous, in a way I didn't think Pixel-Art games could be. The most beautiful thing in Kingdom is the river, which actually reflects on the surface, and is by far the most beautiful Pixel-Style piece of work I've ever seen!

Sound:
Kingdom's soundtrack is beautiful, sometimes calming, sometimes haunting, always setting a good mood to the game.
The SFX is subtle, simple, sometimes abstract, but very fitting, and very easy on the ears.

Gameplay:
The only way for the player to interact with the world is by moving coins around, giving them to people to recruit them, putting them to use for constructing defenses or farms, or buying tools. [there are some more uses, but I will refrain from spoiling the experience ;) ]

I noticed minimal lags on assaults in the very late game, when I had lots and lots of archers, but apart from that the game is very well optimized.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well, I normally dont write an actual legit review. This time though I need too. I have a mere 22 hours of game play which is a drop in most games. Also 10$ might be a bit steep considering the game.

Even with all that said. It was very worth the money. It took around 4 tries to finally get a victory. It took about 4 real life days of casual play to play the game winning win on day 88 I think. It was so awarding you can't help, but sit back and enjoy the absolute feeling of victory. It's not fast. It's like a 2D RTS in my mind. Back when APM was not the winning factor.

For that, it gets a +1 for me. I recommend it to any one.

reviewText: Enjoyable, fun and beautiful game, but unfortunately very short lived and leaves you wanting much more. After the first few hours in, once you start to win the game, the game pretty much becomes over at this point. Trying to destroy the last portals is just incredibly tedious, at that point you realize that the concept of the game is very interesting, but it feels much more like an incomplete prototype with a single, short, and ridiculously tedious level to complete.\n\nI'm giving it a thumbs up just because im always on the lookout for original and interesting concepts, and i would say give it a try if you are like me, but don't expect this game to be fun for more than a few hours.

reviewText:
There are a few things that bother me in-game, like:

- Lazy villagers (can't they run?).
- Dumb villagers (srsly why all the workers walk together?).
- Can't command our soldiers, for example: I had 6 archers on the right wall and on the left wall 0, we can't give them orders, that's pretty anoying since we are the king, doesn't make sense.
- The fact that your villagers can't run, it's really anoying.
- After some time the village gets bigger, and you spend one day just to get to the other side.
- Can't select wich villagers it's going to take a role, they just pick the first role they find.

Except for those things, I love the game, the pixel art is amazing and the controls are simple, the difficulty makes you wanna play more and more. I recommend it.


btw, pixel art 10/10 xD

reviewText:
Between the ease of discovery; the fantastic, minecraft-esque soundtrack, and the absolutely gorgeous visuals, this is definitely something I'd recommend picking up.

Many of the negative reviews raise points I think are entirely valid, but seem to put more emphasis on those negative aspects than I did, hence my recommendation. I would say that if you can't get down with RNGeesus Christ as your run's lord and savior (or tormentor), you might not enjoy this as much.

As it stands, I have been recommending the game to all my friends, and would love to see the developer address some of the few mechanical shortcomings, but I'll likely be playing it again shortly after this review goes up.
