reviewText:
In this game, you're the King or the Queen. Your job is to gather gold and pay for the constructions and recruits. That's basically it. You need recruits to have builders, archers, farmers and knights. You need builders to build walls, catapults, farms and portals. You need archers to defend your walls and hunt which gives you gold. Knights will help you defend your otter walls and if you pay them, they'll attack the gates from which your ennemis spawn from. Finally, you need farmers to get more gold to build and upgrade everything everything.

You need these 3 things:

- You need to find the building upgrades to build your walls, towers to level 3 and 4, and to upgrade your town so you can have knights.
- You need to find the archer statue: It costs 5 gold if you want your archers not to shoot like they're blind in one eye and have cataract in the other. You can spend up to 15 gold if you want that buff to last for 3 days.
- You need to find the builder statue to make your walls stronger against enemies attack. It costs 6 gold per day for up to 3 days.

Once you found the 2 statues, your job is to keep on recruiting people to replace those who got their ♥♥♥ kicked, run after those who gor their ♥♥♥ kicked to recruit them back before you lose them, pay for their hammers, bows, scicle or shield, depend on what you want them to do and run from a statue to another to get your buffs. By then, you'll have so much gold that it's going to fall out of your purse. It's either going to fall on the ground or in the water.

Doesn't sound fun anymore? Wait! There's more!

- You can't choose where you send anyone.
- Your troops go where ever the hell they want.
- You can have 5 archers protecting one side of your city while no one is watching the other side.
- If you build a catapult, it takes up to 2 builders to move it around and to reset it after a shot. Once it's in place, it stays there even if the outter wall is destroyed. The catapult will move to the farthest wall from the town center, so if your outter wall is level 1 it's going to move there whether you like it or not even if you have a wall level closer to your town center. Once your builders are around the catapult, sometimes, they'll help you build something, sometimes they won't.
- If you build a tower for your archers, the archers will stay there until something pushes them out of the tower. They will also stop hunting rabbits and they won't go towards the outter wall to the other towers.
- Sometimes, builders and hunters will go outside the outter wall and stay there until you have a wave of monsters instead of getting behind a wall. Then they get killed...

There is something positive about this game. If you feel like playing a game and you're braindead and all you have on your smashed keyboard is the the left, right and down arrow, this game is for you.

reviewText:
+Looks nice, the art style works well.
+Pretty interesting concept, even if it isn't new.

-There is no depth. Gameplay was exactly the same 45 minutes in as it was 5 minutes in, I mean *exactly*. Because you can't directly (or even indirectly in the case of archers) command any units, you'll simply spend most of the time running back and forth checking to see if anyone drops money for you to use. When you include the fact that your horse can only run so long, and this amount is not shown anywhere, gameplay becomes repetitive very quickly.

-AI is incredibly bad. I'm not sure why some other reviews say this adds to the game." Artificially increasing difficulty is not a good thing. Expect to spend a good amount of time watching your archers move to one side and shoot your own defenses as the rest of your land is overrun. Maybe if your archers could shoot through your own defenses or at least fire faster this wouldn't be such a big problem
date: but ultimately it feels like surviving or dying is out of your control entirely."

reviewText: Wow... Just wow. I've played a decent amount of small title indie games and a fair amount of triple A's and nothing even comes close to the level of atmosphere that this game brings to the table. The animals and the trees, the feeling of just wondering away from your little homestead is accelerating. Slowly building more farms and towers, and the music! its astonishingly good. The feelings that you develop for your town's people are powerful and everytime I lose one its a substantial blow. Granted, the game requires more content but its early acces, so im sure more is on the way. I would love to see a requirement to build houses for your town people that the non combat units hide away in during the night. Keep up The good work guys! can't wait for the next content update. :D
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I found this game through a popular lets-player. The game looked fun and the art-style was beautiful for a pixel-based game. I always do enjoy these type of resource games. This game is simple which is great as I hate when games want you to memorise so many things.

Pros:
- Lovely graphics
- Simple game-play mechanics
- Beautiful music

Cons:
- Not warned about Blood-moon (funny for reaction videos though)
- Lag (Past 50+ days)

The game is lovely, it can be short if you learn what to do however the main part of the game is to see how long you can survive for, there is your challenge.
However the game will get laggy past day 50+ due to the hoard, even if you make one side safe the hoard will still lag you. This can make it hard and annoying to play specially on Blood-moons that late in.

I would recomend this game, the devs do listen to what is wrong with the game and are trying to improve them as well as listen to some ideas we have.
Even in the current state the game is still addicting to play and I am happy to come back and re-try to survive those 100 days or beat my record of the fastest time I have made my kingdom safe. In a way this reminds me of pikmin in the survival mechanic, something which I love. I expect my 22 hours to raise in the coming weeks no matter how hard I rage at those moons.

reviewText:
Kingdom is a great side-scrolling town defense game. It has very easy yet still interesting game mechanics and is also distinguished by its visual appeal. It took me around 20 hours to get all achievements which seems completely adequate for its relatively small price.

What I probably enjoyed the most about Kingdom is the unique atmosphere it creates as well as the beautiful pixel art. I also liked the fundamental game idea that has been refreshingly different from similar titles. The only drop of bitterness for me is that the game tends to perform badly when the player controls large amounts of archers, which unfortunately is a necessity in late game.

Overall, I would recommend Kingdom to all friends of the genre (8/10).

reviewText: Great little game.  Yes the AI is simple, but not bad.  A few tips.  Don't expand beyond your ability to defend.  Recruit 4 peasants every single day if possible.  Don't start construction projects outside of the walls late in the day.  Don't upgrade your farms to t2 until you have them behind a well fortified wall.  Get stone WALLS as soon as you can.  And finally, don't upgrade to a stone KEEP until you are ready to defend against the hulks and the flying aliens and conquering a portal is your next step.

reviewText:
Overflowing with beautiful graphics. (And monsters.)

Kingdom is one of the most perfect games to show that you don't need 1080p at 60 fps to have a beautiful art style. The simplistic, yet striking graphics immidiately caught my eye and still surprise me while I play, even eleven hours in. The magiacal, story illustration feel of this game adds a level of depth, and creates a gorgeous world in which to build your very own kindom.

Graphics aside, this game seems to have a simplistic gameplay at first, where the tutorial seems to tell you to throw all of your money to peasants and build a few cool little walls. The final words; Build
recommended: Defend" send you on your way to creating your own kingdom. The game does not tell you any strategies

reviewText: In one word, elegant. The sound and graphics are beautiful and the gameplay is enjoyable. It may seem overly simple at first. However, building on your stratergies from one failed playthrough to another is immensely satisfying. The complexity is created in this learning process as you work out the hidden intricacies of the various game mechanics. Also, there is an interesting balance between calming and intense moments. Finally, a lot of the late game frustration voiced in other reviews has been fixed in the latest update. An enjoyable experience, I can't wait to see where the developers take the game next.

reviewText:
Hey Jack you need to buy this game.

For those of you that are not Jack let me spell out my thoughts on Kingdom.
The game offers a tense struggle as you try to expand your kingdom whislt holding back the never ending horde of enemies. It is this that gives the game a tense feeling as you fight not just to survive, but thrive. Thats what i probably love most about it. its not just holdong out for an amount of days until you die, there is an actual end game where you defeat your enemies. The game is also rather beautiful (im not a huge fan of pixel are) and feels nostalgic like it could have been a sega game 20 years ago.

Ill be interested to see where the devs take this game and while at this stage it does feel complete, there is just to much potential for them to stop now.

The main downfall of this game is that it may get boring over time but for the price id say you are likely to get your moneys worth.

In summary regardless of your name you should probably buy this game.

reviewText: Kingdom is a neat game with a neat concept and a neat art style. Despite all this I can't really recommend the game. There is no direction for the players. The 30 second tutorial shows you exactly what you can do (move and build) and then explains nothing else leaving it to the player to flounder around in hopes of discovering what they need to do. You will lose your first game, and your second game and your fifth game and so forth until you finally stumble upon the one way the game can be played. There is very little gameplay to it; run left, build things, run right, build things, wait until you have enough money to do it again. Some of your decisions are meaningful, most of them are not. You cant control anything directly and there's no way to know how your kingdom is actually doing unless you walk a mile back and forth to check. The end was also extremely unsatisfying, I just won randomly one day.\n\nI wanted to enjoy Kingdom but it's simply more frustrating than fun.

reviewText:
Really like the aesthetic, really like the idea, but unfortunately, cannot recommend the game at all in its present state.

First of all, it is very shallow. Nevermind that there are almost no instructions, you will learn most of the mechanics in a couple of hours. There are a couple of features that are less than evident, but there is so little to learn at all, you probably won't miss anything in a playthrough.

Second, it's way too easy to win if you go at it the right way. The difficulty fluctuates, but if you don't make many silly mistakes it's  really hard to lose. Just keep doing the same resource-gathering loop and you're golden. The enemies are more frustrating than dangerous. Some of them can't really be defeated and will take their share of your resources and go away, some are trivial.

Third, there is just too little content. The map is randomized a bit, but in the end, each time it's just a couple of guaranteed features in a slightly different order. The number of buildings you can build is tiny. You don't get to make any tactical decisions apart from ordering an attack. Nothing exciting happens. Sure, sometimes monsters overpower you frontline defense and wreck some part of your kingdom, but it's a temporary setback at worst, often you can rebuild in a day.

And the last one, a big one. Ninety-five percent of your time you just gallop left to right, left to right, gathering coins, renewing enhancements, ordering more bows. It's not fun, you can't screw it up, it's just pointless busywork.

All in all, if you really like the idea, try it, but I'd recommend waiting. The idea is fun, but there's not much game around it right now.

reviewText:
I really love the potential in this game, along with the art style. However, after playing for a couple hours it's easy to see the flaws in it. World generation can be incredibly unfair at times, but it's mostly the AI which will have you feeling stressed out. There is simply not enough time to prepare after a certain point, which is not helped by the AI characters being incredibly slow to get anywhere (c'mon, can't you go a little faster when you're under attack?), or they prioritise certain actions to the point of detriment. Engineers, for example, will not bother to retrieve a catapult from a destroyed wall until there's an attack (which will inevitably get them knocked off). Knights will run away like cowards when a wall gets torn down and their stand-by point moves as a result. They turn their backs and end up getting decimated.

Having people wander off as a result of getting hit and their tools stolen is far too punishing. Chasing after and re-hiring your people is tedious, especially considering how slow they are. And if you've had a bunch of monsters drop items they tried to take off with, such as hammers, you'll end up with an influx of builders you didn't want when you needed archers instead simply because those tools were in the AI's way first.

I think the game needs a lot more rebalancing before it can be considered challenging rather than frustrating.

reviewText:
This game is addictive, beatiful, has an amazing soundtrack and it's great to watch your kingdom grow, which is why it's such a massive letdown when everthing falls apart lategame.

You can play this game in three ways:

1. Rush the portals and finish in an hour or two.

2. Build a big empire and try to last as long as you can.

3. Try to do both and pull your hair out in frustration as bugs and flawed AI messes with you.

Early this game is great fun, tho the lack of propper information will lead you to several wipes. Your first playtroughs will be ended because you did something you shouldn't, something you had never done before, something you had no information about and something that is irreversible.

Lategame this game suffers immensivly and becomes a test of patience and anger management.
Unless you are attemting to play the game in way 2 (see above) you will suffer and will spend more time wrestling with your own citizens than the enemy.

Just expanded safely and need to hold the new wall? Too bad 70% of your archers just ditched you and started walking aimlessly in the wrong direction.

Just got a ton of reinforcements to hold the line? Well unless you walk them there, most of them won't make it that far.

Lost some ground? So sad, you left your catapult and level 2 farm behind. Now half of your famers and builders will kill themselves.

Cleared some forest getting ready to expand or lost deforested land? Your archers just wandered into the hearth of the enemy and got themselves killed. Walk past 3-8 previous walls? No problem.


So in conclusion. Unless you are playing the game in way 1 or 2 (see above) don't even think about it.
Your blood pressuer will thank me later.

reviewText:
What a wonderful game!

It's so simple: only thing you do is collect gold and spend it to upgrade your forteress and its surroundings. You can literally play with 4 buttons (left, right, run and spent/throw gold). Yet, it's a wonderful game with charming old-school pixel graphics and the mechanics are very fun and engrossing.

You need to carefully expand and explore.
Explore too far, you'll have bag surprises.
Expand too fast and you'll get cruch on the next Red Moon!

Do yourself a favor and don't wiki this game. Learn by experimenting, like we used to back in the days and you'll improve your experience tenfold.

I can't wait for a mobile version of this game!

reviewText:
I will mostly talk about the bad stuff in the game, so don't get me wrong that this game sucks ****, cause it doesn't. Kingdom is a fun and nice game that lacks replayability and some other stuff I will soon get into.

Going around building up a kingdom and defending it is always nice. And who doesn't love to have some peasants all do the stuff for you?
Just that all peasants are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Archers seriously need some freaking training, like building a traning camp or something like that. They are probably made to be this way but that doesn't change the fact that it annoys me. It is frustrating watching two archers needing 10 shots to shoot down one enemy. The warriors you get in the end are tanky but don't seem to know how to use their equipment and just watch most fights. And all of these peasants are SOOOOOO SLOOOOOOOOW, laziest peasants in the universe, and you don't even have a whip to to make them go faster :). And they aint the only ones that are slow, the king or queens horse must have a broken leg or something, but that speed is endurable for me. So well, for you and your peasants it takes a while to get somewhere. Something that annoys me quite a lot is how I can't attack :''(, the king/queen should start out with a little bow that can be upgraded to balance up those pathetic archers. But that's simply one of my ideas and hopes.

The information that you get feels like nothing.  I got totally wrecked my first games cause I didn't know you could make farms. I even thought the farmers were pikemen until I realized they sucked in combat :(. And when I got through that problem and was going to upgrade my town hall I coulden't. It seems like you had to go to some building and spend some money, information that I didn't get from the game or the internet.
And if you have gotten to day 15 or whatever it is, those Hulk Smashers just wreck your place no matter your defense or army, or maybe I simply haven't gotten any info about that either...
Though ofcourse it should be taken into consideration that this game is about learning yourself and just starting over game after game to get more knowledge about what to do, it might be that this game just isn't for everyone. Especially people like me who directly looks up on the internet whenever I need to know something...

Before I got the game I thought I could place my defense and build all the stuff wherever I wanted, but appareantly not! These dumbass random spots with dirt or stone for defenses is just annoying and don't let you build and get your imagination on, cause it is already premade how everything must look, lame.
So with every castle looking the same, you doing the same stuff without any exploring this game just lacks the replayability cause it's going to turn out the same everytime you play, atleast from my short game time.

Great idea though, and I'm sure if the dev's care about the game that they can make it into something awesome, until then, with the price it has, this is going to be a negative review.

reviewText:
Kingdom has an incredible ambiance. Music and visuals are impeccable. Graphics almost seem like a throw back to the Commodore 64 and Amiga days but well polished. All is well with this game... except.

Kingdom goes by a day system. The first five or so days will allow you to build up and see what opposition you will be facing. Days six to ten allow you to upgrade your defenses and recruit more subjects. Day ten/eleven... You lose.

That's how the game first went for me at least.

The enemies in this game go from easy > Normal > Dangerous > Cheap > Insta-Death > ... ?
(Hoards of these. Cheap and all)

My second try I got to day 30. Seeing what I faced that night. I don't think I would've survived regardles of what I did to prepare. And for some reason I could not upgrade my walls to stone either. I could before. Weird.

Is it whining? Maybe. But Kingdom's quick and unforgiving difficulty spikes are too much for me to enjoy this game.

reviewText:
This game is Excellent for the 1st 2 or so hours while you figure out the basics and get your 1st good run going.  The graphics are excellent, the music and sound fit the atmosphere, and figuring out the games mechanics is a joy.  After that point however, the game is fatally flawed and an absolute chore to play.

1. The game has a huge lack of content.  I had every building built and fully upgraded along with every unit by about day 20 - 25.  I had seen every enemy type by that point as well.  Future days (I am currently on 48) have just had more enemy numbers.

2.  The game requires you to cheese it in order to progress.  For example - I had too many farmers and not enough archers, I was generating 3x as much gold as I could spend per day on replacement soldiers.  There is no way to reasign those farmers, so I had to let the enemy hit them so they would go back to neutral, rehire them, and then give them a bow to make them soldiers.

3.  The game is VERY buggy.  Graphics glitches, animation glitches, AI problems (such as toolless peasants refusing to pick any up making them useless).  Knights only work a part of the time.  Workers will not man catapults at night half the time and so on.  The game also lags noticibly at times past about night 40.

4. Difficulty is not balanced.  In my current game for example I make 3 times the gold I can spend in one day but due to the way the map was layed out I could not expand without leaving myself with almost no way to generate population.  So I cant lose as I can rehire every damanged unit and rebuild every building every day but cant win due to a lack of units.  I am on night 48 and have not made any progress since night 26, no new buildings/upgrades etc to help me win but the AI also cannot do anything due to my ability to rebuild every single day,

TL;DR - Great 1st impression - 3/10 after that - I would strongly advise against buying this game.

reviewText:
This game has pleasing pixel art, sound and general aesthetic. However, there is very little depth to the game beyond the first 30 min - 1 hour. Game mechanics that at first seem novel quickly become tedious busy work.

You control an ever expanding city but the game mechanics are inadequate to properly manage the growing city size. As you expand your city, you will spend more and more time running from one side of it to the other. Your coin pouch doesn't expand which means that you'll have to keep running back and forth from the front line constructions to your farmers to collect and spend coins.

There is also no variety or strategy in building placement and unit types. There are 4 types of units: Builders, Farmers, Archers, and Knights (you can only have 4 Knights at most). There are 3 types of buildings that you can place in predetermined locations: Walls, Towers, and Farms. The buildings all have linear upgrades.

The only character you can control is yourself. It would be nice to be able to instantly swap from one side of the map to the other. Perhaps they could have added Commander" or "Messenger" units to the game to help send orders and collect money without needing to walk and do everything in person.

A king needs to be able to delegate tasks. As the kingdom expands
date: more tasks need to be delegated. Although this game has good art and concept
recommended: until the developers add better city management features. I don't recommend playing this game."

reviewText: When I first played this game a few times it was pretty good about lagging, only lagging a bit during the nights when I got around day 30 or more. But this time when I played and got to day 50 all the way to 94, the game started lagging so much that I would be sitting there for five minutes at a time, stuck. This has caused me to be unable to recruit people, give jobs and upgrade my walls and shrines. Also, it would be a good idea to maybe make some of the walls a little closer due to right now, I am trying to defeat my 4th portal and I am unable to due to the fact that the walls are so far apart, unable to protect all my archers and since the last wall is right next to the portal, the monsters can destroy it more easily whilst taking out all my archers since the wall before that is so far away. But the worst part is the lag. It is keeping me from advancing any farther and it happens during day and night. It seems to get worse when people start dropping gold, but I am suprised since that always happens. It may also be a good idea to do something with the horse or the speed or travel time. Once the kingdom starts to really expand, it get's harder and harder to just travel the kingdom. I haven't been able to check the entire left side of my kingdom at all since around day 80 due to the fact that it takes about an entire day to do so, but that prevents me from upgrading and recruiting. I've heard someone talking about a horse shrine; something like that. Except the lag, the wall difficulties, and the speed it takes to get around the kingdom, this game is awesome and I hope it get's updated soon.

reviewText:
Beautiful art, fantastic sound, awful gameplay. I hate to rate this game poorly since it started out so promising, but its core systems are at odds with each other.

The game is an empire builder that limits your interaction to a slow moving character who can only pick up and spend money at different locations. What starts out as a fun and exploratory adventure of running back and forth across the map, upgrading buildings, and discovering new advancements, quickly becomes a nightmare of managing a kingdom that is too large to cross in a single day. Honestly this game would have been much better if the physical size of your kingdom didn't grow so large, or the player was given tools to manage at a larger scale. It seems as though the devs wanted to use two incompatible mechanics, but couldn't let go of either one.

Like many other reviews have said, the AI is horribly flawed. If you want to limit player interaction so severely, you need the game to manage itself flawlessly. Anything less is just going to lead to frustration, and believe me this game provides frustration in spades.

From playing the game and then reading the developers' community interaction, it seems that the idea of learning the rules through trial and error is core to their design. They insist that everything functions very precisely according to the rules of the game, and that includes the awful AI as well. However this seems like an excuse to explain away some poorly designed systems, and a failure to communicate those systems through the course of gameplay.

Overall I think this game could have been great, but the designers were unwilling to either let go of the game's main gimmick or design the mid to late game experience around that gimmick. They wanted their cake and their kingdom too.

reviewText: There's a reason why this beat out over 40 other titles and won Best of Indie Arena 2015.  It is fun!  I started playing, thinking I would just play half an hour or so.  The next thing I knew, hours had gone by.  I really suggest that you try playing the game at first without reading a tutorial.  A lot of the fun is just reacting to the game, and figuring out how to do things.  Once you have played through a dozen times, you will probably have a few questions about how to overcome and issue, and then I would suggest reading a walkthrough.  I like the story about having to re-establish your kingdom in a new area, and building everything up from scratch.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I got a review key from the developers.

Kingdom is an interesting game. The controls are simple, the game is easy to pick up but hard to master.
You are the ruler of a newly founded kingdom, and need to expand it. Explore the lands and bribe people to join your kingdom. But there's a catch: There are four Portals connecting the lands to another realm, inhabited by strange, greedy creatures. You will have to destroy all the portals to secure your newfound lands.

The game mainly focuses on proper ressource management and timing your actions right. Upgrading a wall at the wrong time and you can potentially use half of your forces! To make things worse, get your crown stolen and you lose the game, because without a crown, there cannot be a ruler. And without a ruler, there cannot be a kingdom!
There are many subtle elements in the world, especially in the deep forest areas, hinting at what kinds of buildings you'll be able to build once you clear the forest - Or clearings in the woods, potentially allowing you to include camps where you can recruit peasants into the safety of your kingdom.

The pixel art is lovely and the soundtrack really adds to the game - Too bad you don't get to hear it all the time..

reviewText: Fantastic resource management game. It's packed full of little jems. I really enjoy the art style as well as the soundtrack. It gives off a kind of nostalgia for me. When I was growing up one of my favorite games was/is Civilization. I'm not saying this game is  in anyway near as big. Civilization is all about making the right moves to build your settlement to a Dynasty that could last for centuries. Kingdom scratches that building itch. However its not about keeping your kingdom its about taking down the nasty creatures that come every night attacking your home. In fact the game encourages that you live longer if you manage really well at the start. Exploration in your realm is necessary as well as taking risks. There is a time factor in this as well so your decision making has to be on point or your could lose big time and not recover. I believe this game is meant to be played again and again because each restart gives you a different layout. There are few irritating things that are really nit picking. For instance sometimes when my builders chop down trees sometimes coins come out however when I walk over it with my horse sometimes it picks it up right away other times I have to go back and forth several times. In this game time matters so me spending my time trying to pick up one coin can be frustrating. I'm sure the developers can easily fix this issue along with some other glitches.\nThis game gets a 9/10.

reviewText:
It's a really REALLY fun game, but I don't recommend trying to speed run it yet. You see, to be able to win, you have to destroy four portals, two in each direction, and to do that, you have to send out knights with archers.

You can only do this during the day, though, as they need to be standing by the standard outside your outer walls for you to send them out. They only LEAVE the walls after the bells that anounce the day has rung, and there's some type of bug where those bells sometimes don't ring until it's ♥♥♥♥ing midday!

The reason it's so important to send them out  as the sun goes up is that if you don't, you'll have to expand for them to reach the outer portal before the night attack arrives and woops the asses of your knights with pure numbers! As long as they start attacking the portal, you're golden, the enemies won't come until the portal explodes, upon which it floods out like some kind of tidal wave, even if it turns night or not.

I tried to do a speed run, got a GOLDEN start, wiped the asses of the portals to the left and the first to the right before the 15th day had passed, and then all hell broke loose. Each time it would turn day, the bellringer was taking a ♥♥♥♥ing nap or something, because the crackpots wouldn't ring until a few minutes into the day!! Considering that the day is like 5 min, that's quite alot. Each time I was able to, I sent out my knights, but as they're slower than a snail, they where barely getting close to the portal each time, before it turned night, and a wave of monsters or trolls I don't ♥♥♥♥ing care, came and wooped their ♥♥♥!!

This went on until day 30, where I rage quit, because day 30 was the day I beat it on the time when I didn't rush, and expanded all the ♥♥♥♥ing way to the portals!!

Also, once you defeat the game, there's no way of doing anything at all! The camera zips through the world, from your character, to the left- or rightmost camp, depending on which side you beat first, and then zips right back to you, whereupon it stops, with the controls inactive. The game seems to still be running, but you can't do anything but awkwardly stare at your avatar, noticing details you didn't notice during the entire game, waiting for something to happen. In the end, I had to alt+f4 to close the stupid game!

7/10 great game, but wait for the bug fixes if you want to speed run...

reviewText:
In case anyone doesn't know this, the game is a Unity version remade from the Flash version that is available for free on the dev's website. If you're unsure, just try it out before buying!

Pros/Cons:
+ Simple, yet pretty looking graphics.
+ Relaxing music.
+ The game is quite addicting, if you love this type of game.
+/- Challenging gameplay. Strugling to destroy all portals was a fun experience for me. Then, the update 1.0.1 came and I can easily beat the game, maybe too easily.
+/- Random map allow different play styles to start with. But it is no longer matter once you get used to the game, and the gameplay became repetitive.
- Incredibly bad performance when your large army battling against large flock of monsters, notably when the archers drop their bows.

All in all, the game hasn't been built up to the level it was targeted for. But it still is a good and enjoyable game. I like it a lot and can play it all night long.

Suggestion:
> There should be a difficulty option to choose when starting the game.
> Optimize the performance during the battle.

reviewText:
A game with captivating atmosphere and a minimalist soul. Kingdom may become addicting if you are not careful. The pixel art and the soundtrack are right on the spot for the theme. It has some random elements, so you have to change at least part of your strategy every playthrough.

Worth buying if you'd like to play a strategy game that is easy to understand but hard to master.

/

Um jogo com uma atmosfera cativante e uma alma minimalista. Kingdom pode tornar-se viciante, se você não for cuidadoso. A arte do pixel e a trilha sonora são perfeitas para o tema. Ele tem alguns elementos aleatórios, então você tem que mudar, pelo menos, parte de sua estratégia a cada jogada.

Vale a pena comprar se você quer jogar um jogo de estratégia que é fácil de entender, mas difícil de dominar.

reviewText: This is the most amazing game I have ever played. If you only buy one game, it should be this one! I have never been so addicted to a single-player game in my life since Civ (the original) and Ultima III/IV and NetHack. I'm 12 hours in on my third day, and I still can't stop myself from playing.\n\nI am deeply in love with this game. Sure, it has it's issues (almost exclusively with AI of your subjects), but the dev really loves their game and is listening to the community and is dedicated to improving it. They are also offering all DLC, aside from the OST, for free, for those who purchase the game before it is available. Not only is the gameplay addictive, but the design aesthetic is so lush and the music so wonderful and fitting to what's happening in the game at any moment, and the sound-effects are all pleasing and fitting, as well.

reviewText: Fantastic resource management game. It's packed full of little jems. I really enjoy the art style as well as the soundtrack. It gives off a kind of nostalgia for me. When I was growing up one of my favorite games was/is Civilization. I'm not saying this game is  in anyway near as big. Civilization is all about making the right moves to build your settlement to a Dynasty that could last for centuries. Kingdom scratches that building itch. However its not about keeping your kingdom its about taking down the nasty creatures that come every night attacking your home. In fact the game encourages that you live longer if you manage really well at the start. Exploration in your realm is necessary as well as taking risks. There is a time factor in this as well so your decision making has to be on point or your could lose big time and not recover. I believe this game is meant to be played again and again because each restart gives you a different layout. There are few irritating things that are really nit picking. For instance sometimes when my builders chop down trees sometimes coins come out however when I walk over it with my horse sometimes it picks it up right away other times I have to go back and forth several times. In this game time matters so me spending my time trying to pick up one coin can be frustrating. I'm sure the developers can easily fix this issue along with some other glitches.\nThis game gets a 9/10.

reviewText:
It's a really REALLY fun game, but I don't recommend trying to speed run it yet. You see, to be able to win, you have to destroy four portals, two in each direction, and to do that, you have to send out knights with archers.

You can only do this during the day, though, as they need to be standing by the standard outside your outer walls for you to send them out. They only LEAVE the walls after the bells that anounce the day has rung, and there's some type of bug where those bells sometimes don't ring until it's ♥♥♥♥ing midday!

The reason it's so important to send them out  as the sun goes up is that if you don't, you'll have to expand for them to reach the outer portal before the night attack arrives and woops the asses of your knights with pure numbers! As long as they start attacking the portal, you're golden, the enemies won't come until the portal explodes, upon which it floods out like some kind of tidal wave, even if it turns night or not.

I tried to do a speed run, got a GOLDEN start, wiped the asses of the portals to the left and the first to the right before the 15th day had passed, and then all hell broke loose. Each time it would turn day, the bellringer was taking a ♥♥♥♥ing nap or something, because the crackpots wouldn't ring until a few minutes into the day!! Considering that the day is like 5 min, that's quite alot. Each time I was able to, I sent out my knights, but as they're slower than a snail, they where barely getting close to the portal each time, before it turned night, and a wave of monsters or trolls I don't ♥♥♥♥ing care, came and wooped their ♥♥♥!!

This went on until day 30, where I rage quit, because day 30 was the day I beat it on the time when I didn't rush, and expanded all the ♥♥♥♥ing way to the portals!!

Also, once you defeat the game, there's no way of doing anything at all! The camera zips through the world, from your character, to the left- or rightmost camp, depending on which side you beat first, and then zips right back to you, whereupon it stops, with the controls inactive. The game seems to still be running, but you can't do anything but awkwardly stare at your avatar, noticing details you didn't notice during the entire game, waiting for something to happen. In the end, I had to alt+f4 to close the stupid game!

7/10 great game, but wait for the bug fixes if you want to speed run...

reviewText:
In case anyone doesn't know this, the game is a Unity version remade from the Flash version that is available for free on the dev's website. If you're unsure, just try it out before buying!

Pros/Cons:
+ Simple, yet pretty looking graphics.
+ Relaxing music.
+ The game is quite addicting, if you love this type of game.
+/- Challenging gameplay. Strugling to destroy all portals was a fun experience for me. Then, the update 1.0.1 came and I can easily beat the game, maybe too easily.
+/- Random map allow different play styles to start with. But it is no longer matter once you get used to the game, and the gameplay became repetitive.
- Incredibly bad performance when your large army battling against large flock of monsters, notably when the archers drop their bows.

All in all, the game hasn't been built up to the level it was targeted for. But it still is a good and enjoyable game. I like it a lot and can play it all night long.

Suggestion:
> There should be a difficulty option to choose when starting the game.
> Optimize the performance during the battle.

reviewText:
Absolutely amazing game. Don't understand all these negative reviews. It's Rogue-Like and builder and action and adventure. Exploration and defeat and then you come back and do it all over again hoping you will destroy all the troll caves this time around. The soundtrack is amazing, the visuals for an 8 bit game are stunning and you can play it so many ways.
The enemies. Trolls are your standard enemy, the fliers who eat your friends are Squids and the giant ape guys who throw thousands of bows into a river are Ogres. All of them love you and want your precious crown. Don't let them get it.

I would literally only add cosmetics to this game. (Birds flying around, maybe sitting on your towers and outposts, and maybe some fish swimming and jumping in the water with a random mermaid who comes randomly every so blue moon and gives you a little gold love. xD Oh and Endless Mode.

But I can't stop playing, it is just so fun. :D

10/10 my horse loves grass

reviewText:
Beautiful art, fantastic sound, awful gameplay. I hate to rate this game poorly since it started out so promising, but its core systems are at odds with each other.

The game is an empire builder that limits your interaction to a slow moving character who can only pick up and spend money at different locations. What starts out as a fun and exploratory adventure of running back and forth across the map, upgrading buildings, and discovering new advancements, quickly becomes a nightmare of managing a kingdom that is too large to cross in a single day. Honestly this game would have been much better if the physical size of your kingdom didn't grow so large, or the player was given tools to manage at a larger scale. It seems as though the devs wanted to use two incompatible mechanics, but couldn't let go of either one.

Like many other reviews have said, the AI is horribly flawed. If you want to limit player interaction so severely, you need the game to manage itself flawlessly. Anything less is just going to lead to frustration, and believe me this game provides frustration in spades.

From playing the game and then reading the developers' community interaction, it seems that the idea of learning the rules through trial and error is core to their design. They insist that everything functions very precisely according to the rules of the game, and that includes the awful AI as well. However this seems like an excuse to explain away some poorly designed systems, and a failure to communicate those systems through the course of gameplay.

Overall I think this game could have been great, but the designers were unwilling to either let go of the game's main gimmick or design the mid to late game experience around that gimmick. They wanted their cake and their kingdom too.

reviewText: Excellent visuals and audio, surprisingly deep and engaging gameplay for such a minimal mechanic.  I kept noticing new details every time I played that caused me to update my strategy for the next game.  I'd recommend not spoiling the game by watching too many let's plays unless you really get stuck; it's more rewarding when you figure out strategies by yourself.  The game doesn't really tell you anything so you have to pay attention.  I finally won the beta after 15 hours and I've probably noticed most of what the game has to offer, but I'll probably play through again soon just because I enjoy the mechanics and ambience.

reviewText:
This game is amazing.  It's an extremely refreshing game after playing other titles that have same premises as a lot of titles.  However, Kingdom is unique.  If you are careful and don't spoil yourself about the contents, there is a lot of cool stuff to be surprised about.  Plenty of things to buy exist in this title, and there are also a few different types of baddies (if you manage to make it far enough; I've made it to day 26).

The soundtrack is amazing as well, with a nice range of stringed instruments.  For me, music is quite possible the 2nd most important part of a game.

For all of you wondering about this title, I highly recommend getting it.  Even if it's not on a sale, it's absolutely worth the money.

reviewText: The artificial intelligence in this game, which plays an absolutely central role in the gameplay, is infuriatingly dumb. Certain mechanics are there just to screw you over, for example the catapult that kills all your units, repeatedly, until it's the only unit remaining on the field, and get swarmed by the enemies, which it didn't kill. Or the workers that go out during the night, just to be killed 3 seconds later. Or the orders that cannot be canceled, be it constructions, recruitments or wood cutting. Or the absolutely dreadful aim of the archers (your main and only weapon). At least, if the player was something more than a peasant walking on a horse, it could offset some of the problems of the AI. But alas, as it stands, you just walk back and forth trough your kingdom"
date: which actually feels more like a long grassland
recommended: hoping for the AI to do it's job.\n\nHuge waste of a great concept
hoursPlayed: some great graphics and an outstanding soundtrack."

reviewText: Kingdom is an exercise in minimalist design that is ultimately undermined by it's own limitations or rather the lack of information it directly provides the player.  How far will my horse gallop?  How much can I expand before I can no longer recruit guys?  What things are actually effective?  How do I get to the options menu when I am stuck watching the intro?  Best of luck!  I made it rather far simply by spending loads of money on all the things.  A strategy that worked well until my own catapults destroyed my own walls and then I found out I could no longer recruit more guys because I expanded too far.  Sucks to be me.  Based on my criticisms you might assume the fix would be to just reveal all the information, but I suspect that would reveal a rather barren game.  The only real roadblocks on the road to an insta-win are some light stratergery and having everything obfuscated by some pleasant art direction.  Not a bad game, but one that does not really earn the investment it asks of the player.

reviewText: Unfortunately, the current state of this game makes it so I can't recommend it. Currently the game only lasts for a couple hours before it becomes completely reparative. The randomness to where things spawn and the fact that you can't control your troops takes most of the strategy out of this game. In fact the only type of late game strategy is running to camps during the day to get more troops and dropping coins on the ground during the night so your defenses won’t get overrun (some enemies will take the coins and run back to the spawner instead of attacking).\n\nHalf the time walls and watch towers will spawn so far apart there's no way for you to guard them without relying on the AI to wander over there. Coupled with that your archers are terrible shots, it sometimes takes 5 archers multiple shots to take out one enemy. This can be solved if you get lucky enough to have an archer shrine spawn by your base, which makes them great shots, however by that time your kingdom is usually so spread out you still have to rely on the terrible AI grouping up enough to fend off the hordes of enemies. Right now it's a game of running from point A to point B over and over again, while hoping you can recruit enough people to win before days 20/30 when the enemies vastly outscale your army and it becomes very hard to win. I think this game has a lot of potential and I look forward to any updates the developers put out, however right now the game is just way too shallow to be entertaining for more than a couple hours.

reviewText:
The gameplay balance is all over the place. Rather by your tactics the way the map and avaiable terrain is genrated, and luck what the AI decides to do in any given moment will make the difference if you win or loose.

You can have the strongest walls and the most archers and catapults, you have no real infulence over making real tactical decisions. There is also not really any worth in building multiple walls since when the enemy has taken down your outer most defence, where most of your soldiers will accumulate if it makes sense or not, you will not have enough in the inside to stop the onslaught. That WILL send you on a inevitable and tiresome way to a loss you may as well just start new.

As if the minor influence you really have on this isn't enough he later the game the more unbalanced the game gets. In later stages you get flying enemys that simply will swoop down and right out wat all your units.
Since there is no real stacked defences, because all soldiers accumulate more or les in one spot on the outer walls, and your soldiers miss more then hit anything, there is no way you can stop them and get them back, leading you AGAIN on an inevitable path down.

I have no problems with games that are hard and where an early decision can cost you a game later on. The things is that ususlaly such a game gives you tools to work against that, But in Kingdome everything is set up in a way that there is simply no way you can catch up or at least recover from a beating.

AGain the games balance is rubbish, so it doesn't sadly help that the game is utterly gorgeous in effects and animations and has an really wonderfull soundtrack.

reviewText:
I first saw Kingdom at the Indie Megabooth at PAX Prime. After putting in about 3 sessions now, I've enjoyed my time with the game quite a lot. And I should mention that I'm not typically someone that enjoys the rogue like formula. (where you play until you die, then start over)

As other reviews have mentioned, there are issues with the AI. Archers often stand right next to money spawning rabbits and pay them no attention. When they do notice them their aim is quite a bit worse than i'd like it to be. There are also issues with the overall pacing of the game. A bit too much downtime for my tastes. I also wish the horse could would pick up money much easier. If one lands on the ground where your horse stands, you have to walk away from it then back over to it.

I take the time to list the above issues because I care about this game enough to point out its small flaws in the hopes that the devs will improve them. Even with these issues, the game is more than compelling enough to keep me coming back.

The art and audio in this game are absolutlely incredible. On top of that the $10 price point is more than fair. Give this one a shot you won't regret it.

reviewText:
TL;DR  If your builders would move with even the smallest sense of urgency, and if your archers could manage to hit enemies more than once every ten shots, this game wouldn't be so bad. Agreeing with a lot of the reviews I've seen, the AI for your allies is abysmal at best. This makes the game honestly not very fun. The art style is beautiful, and the soundtrack can keep my attention the whole time, but as it stands there too many issues to merit a recommendation.


Your Character

You start out as either a king or queen, which is random at the start. You ride on horseback at all times, dole out tasks to your followers, and carry a torch at night. That is literally everything there is for your character to do. You have no offense, no defense an can only take if I remember correctly, two or three hits. Once you've been hit a few times, your crown falls off and you have to race to retrieve it before the enemies do. If they manage to get to it before you, you have no way of getting it back unless by some miracle your archers manage to kill them while they run away. Since your archers miss nine times out of ten, you can be sure that that's the end of the game and you must start over. This can happen on day one if you stray too far from camp, without warning.


Gameplay

The game has a day and night system that passes rather quickly, maybe even too quickly, giving you a sense of time management and making you feel like you need to rush just to survive.

During the day your builders do what they can to complete the tasks you've given them, and archers wander around and hunt, gathering gold. Farmers will wander out to farm, collecting gold as well. Every morning there is also a chest of gold next to the fire in the center of camp. Gold is essential for literally everything you do, because without it you cannot give orders. Every task costs a certain amount of gold, and every upgrade to a fortification costs more than the last.

At night your allies  should  return to camp and get ready to defend what they've built. However, this is not always what happens. You have no control over where your allies go or how they prioritize tasks. Because of this, all too often your archers stay outside the camp walls, leaving themselves in the open for a  100% chance to die.  Your builders do seem to stay within the walls most of the time, but when those walls are attacked they saunter over to repair them with such indifference that the walls are usually destroyed before they get there. Other times they will wander outside the walls to do god knows what, and die immediately by the enemy's hand. Farmers either cower in fear, or continue to farm outside the walls and, of course, die. By night five your camp is attacked by so many enemies at once that if you haven't set up camp just perfectly, or if your archers decide they don't want to kill anyone, the moment one wall is broken you can guarantee you've just lost and will have to start over entirely.

To give that some perspective, I reached night five in about 15-20 minutes. Some might say that is enough time to understand the basic mechanics of any game, and I would agree if not for the fact that this game throws new things at you every few minutes without any hint as to what they are. New fortification options pop into existence and cost on average five gold. At any given time I usually had a maximum of ten gold, so I always felt a bit hesitant to waste gold on something when I didn't know its purpose. I understand that the game is supposed to feel minimalist and rogue-like, but if you're not going to give a blatant tutorial for new objects, you then need to integrate their tutorial or at least some hint on their function into the gameplay in some way without forcing the player to waste precious resources just to learn their function.

As an example, two large arrow signs popped up in a section of my camp, one pointing left and the other pointing right. Next to them was a ladder and a stack of what looked like lumber and bricks. They each cost six gold to build whatever mystery object they represent. I was hesitant to build them at first, because you don't get very much gold each day. I eventually caved and bought one, wasting most of the gold I had gathered. It ended up being a catapult with which my builders could use to miss every single shot against the enemies outside the walls.

Seriously, they never hit a  single  enemy with them.

I found myself distracted with yelling in my head at the NPC's to actually do their jobs, and because of that was unfortunately not even remotely impressed by what aesthetically is a very beautiful and relaxing game. It is gorgeous, the animation is very smooth and peaceful to look at. However such glaring flaws as little to no freedom, terrible AI, and a king/queen who without any explanation has zero ability to defend themselves, really detract from the atmosphere that the art style portrays.

If you don't mind playing as a useless and defenseless two-hit hero doling out tasks to a seemingly indifferent band of recruits, fighting enemies that move so quickly compared to your allies you would swear they were agents from the Matrix, then you might enjoy this game. If you also don't mind having no clue what each new thing that pops up does, and having to waste gold on things you don't need just learn their function, you might enjoy this game even more. Now, if having to die a number of times to learn what each different things does is what rogue-like means, then consider my review invalid. If that is what this game is supposed to be then I understand. That doesn't mean I'll change my mind, but I get it. Even taking that thought into consideration, there are too many huge problems with the gameplay mechanics.


Final Thoughts

My recommendation to the developers would be to make some serious fixes to the ally AI and movement speeds, and to at least put in a slightly transparent title over new fortifications. Perhaps the titles could appear only if you stand next to their build spots for a few seconds, or even have the title appear only for a few seconds the first time you encounter them. Or give us the freedom to place defenses where we want to place them using a simple menu system. Add gold reward systems for doing things a king or queen would actually do and take away the necessity to micromanage every piece of the kingdom.

These are just my thoughts and opinions, feel free to tell me to go to hell. I've never made a game so I can't say I know how difficult it is.

reviewText: This would be a fantastic game if the AI of your peasants wasn't fighting you the entire time.  I watched an archer miss a rabbit 9 times in a row and another archer stand behind a wall shooting it instead of monsters for a minute strait.  The game could be amazing but I am left with a bitter irritating experience of watching the AI ♥♥♥♥ the bed the entire time.\n\nOn top of this the prevalence of blood moon nights is absurdly high.  I feel a sense of progression whenever it is a normal moon, we get attacked, we take losses, we rebuild.  When a blood moon comes through you get an insane amount of monsters that kill everyone and destroy everything in their path.  There is no defensive option for this besides running and blowing all your gold the next day to get back a portion of what you lost.  When this happens every 5 or so nights the game quickly loses its appeal.

reviewText: I really really enjoyed this game up until the point I found what many other negative posters stated: Kingdom's current game design is broken. It plays like a 2D side-scrolling real-time strategy / tower defense game... except you can't control where your forces go or where your buildings are placed. The result is an incredibly slow grind for resources, increasingly brutal waves of enemies, and impossible to manage AI.\n\nGame after game I've accumulated an unspendable amount of gold, maxed out all my buildings / buffs, and recruited as much as possible while expanding towards the edges of the map. When allies become unreplenishable against endless waves of enemies, defeat comes predictably and painfully slow.

reviewText: This is the most amazing game I have ever played. If you only buy one game, it should be this one! I have never been so addicted to a single-player game in my life since Civ (the original) and Ultima III/IV and NetHack. I'm 12 hours in on my third day, and I still can't stop myself from playing.\n\nI am deeply in love with this game. Sure, it has it's issues (almost exclusively with AI of your subjects), but the dev really loves their game and is listening to the community and is dedicated to improving it. They are also offering all DLC, aside from the OST, for free, for those who purchase the game before it is available. Not only is the gameplay addictive, but the design aesthetic is so lush and the music so wonderful and fitting to what's happening in the game at any moment, and the sound-effects are all pleasing and fitting, as well.

reviewText:
This game is beyond beautiful, simple yet complex to understand without time put into it and exploring new options each game! I did struggle at first, it was a little frustrating without further guidance apart from the simple tutorial at start but it has very intricate design, EXTREMELY well-designed mechanics yet once again simple, I could make a simple walk through if i wanted to about this game as i just beat my first game after failing 5 more before, but that's the fun of this particular game!

It has engrossed me in the environment and gameplay for hours on end, i feel that if they got a strong, dedicated team together they could build onto this into a finely tuned and detailed 3D like-minded game with much more to do! But sadly its simple side-scrolling and graphics holds it behind as well to expand on, they have pretty much come to what would seem their limit to expand on this simple game but I had a massive blast!

To those who thumb down this game and feel it's too hard to play, it's not as hard as you think! First step would be to build up a STRONG military force, keep your builders on a small amount until you have built up a huge force of archers, expand your camp but dont go too fast outwards! If you move too fast you can summon very strong hordes too fast for you to handle, and it's fine if you have TOO MUCH money, but your main key in the late game is PEOPLE PEOPLE PEOPLE as you progress you will lose your troops and people quite fast if not careful, explore how the farming works too, (only upgrade farms to the next level if the farm is behind defendable walls and forces, your farmers will stay there after the day is done, so you may see how this is bad outside of your walls!) Anyways I want to make a full video tutorial on how to win at this game and explore its aspects for those who do not understand, it does take some common sense and lots of exploration to figure out a lot past the tutorial!

reviewText:
Gameplay video + my thoughts below:

https://youtu.be/STmxjZ0pzpU

Kingdom has surprised me greatly and seems to keep doing so. The 2d pixel based art style works great and I keep finidng myself struck by the visuals which I did not expect.
I'm find this game has much more depth than first meets the eye. I'm not particularly far in the game but each time I die and start again I feel like I've learnt something which makes me progress that bit frther the time after.
The game keeps things very minimal, you don't get much information to work with so it's often about trail and error.
You start with a few coins and pay some locals to begin serving you as archers or builders. Slowly you expand outwards and upgrade buildings to better protect the kingdom. Exploration is often rewarded though sometimes it will get you killed. I'm still very much learning all the aspects of the game but so far I have no doubt in recommending this game. It's a game you will soon lose hours in and still be wanting more.
I'm looking forward to diving more into this game & I'll update my thoughts so far if I run into anything I feel should be mentioned.

reviewText:
Introduction

Kingdom is a 2D, side-scrolling strategy game where you take on the role of king or queen of a kingdom (I’ll just refer to your character as king from now on for simplicity). As king it’s your job to help your kingdom grow as well as protect said kingdom from the evil forces lurking deep in the forest. All you have is your crown and an empty coin sack. Collect coins throughout the world and spend them on upgrades for you kingdom, don’t be afraid to use them all but be aware, the loss of your crown means the loss of everything.

Presentation

Kingdom has a truly beautiful pixel art style throughout. There’s really not much to say here other than it really does look fantastic. The only UI elements in the game is the coin sack (visible when collecting or spending coins) and the empty coin slots that appear when you’re next to something that can be purchased to show you how much it costs.

Gameplay

I’d just briefly like to say I won’t cover much past what you discover in the first half an hour or so in this section of my review. One of Kingdom’s main ‘selling-points’ is that you’re given next to no information about the game and so it’s very much about discovering how to do different things by yourself.

You walk through your kingdom while mounted on a horse, collecting coins from your people and then using those coins to bring more workers to your kingdom or to build/upgrade structures. You then have to defend your kingdom from attacking enemies. That is, effectively, the entire game. Of course it’s not quite so straightforward.

In the early days of a game there’s very little threat to your kingdom from what I like to call the dark forces lurking in the forest (we’ll call them monsters from now on). Without much threat from the monsters this really is the best time to get a solid foundation for your kingdom laid down. While you won’t have the resources to build the more advanced structures you’ll be able to build basic guard towers and basic wooden walls to keep the monstrous onslaught at bay. But what good are defences if you have no one to build them or man them? Well I’m glad you asked! To the left and right of your kingdom’s main building you’ll find many things including small encampments with people. These people will come work for you in your kingdom for the small fee of one gold coin. Returning to your kingdom you’ll want to buy the necessary tools for them to do the job you desire. Need more builders? Buy some hammers from the vendor in your village. Need more archers? Buy some bows from the vendor in your village! You get the idea.

Now things aren’t going to be this easy forever. The game gets progressively more difficult with the passing of each day and after just a couple of days you’ll be facing monsters looking to steal whatever they can get their horrible little hands on!

As I eluded to, there is a fair bit more in the game but I wouldn’t want to spoil it for prospective players but fear not, there is more to the game than I’ve already mentioned.

You can probably guess from how I’ve written about the gameplay that I’ve enjoyed playing the game, and I have. However, Kingdom did start to feel quite monotonous to me later in the game. Sure the difficulty is ramped up so there’s more pressure on you to build a village capable of fighting off the monsters and protecting the kingdom as a whole but Kingdom effectively descends into you doing the exact same thing each and every day. Perhaps I’m expecting too much from a game with a pretty simple premised and I imagine a lot of people will disagree with me on this but I don’t want to spend each in game day doing the same route to collect money from my people and then spending that money in the exact same way.

Audio

Kingdom’s audio department is truly fantastic. The sound effects throughout the game are all fantastic but what really makes this game’s audio shine is the fantastic soundtrack, some of which can be found on ToyTree Music’s YouTube channel. They really nailed the soundtrack for this one.

Verdict

Worth Purchasing.

Kingdom is a great 2D, side-scrolling strategy game with a fantastic pixel art style, fun gameplay and lots to discover. While I don’t think it has bucket-loads of replayability it’s certainly enjoyable for several hours and is well worth your time and money.

reviewText:
$13 bucks for a full game is what I dropped on this title. At first the music dlc ticked me off. But the full experience was well worth the price. 25 hours later and I have every achievement and am awaiting to see if they tackle the late game lag that ensues around day 90+. No crashes, not an early access title and last the developers are actually still working on adding content to their finished product + bug patching.

Only downside is the lag you will get if you manage to get past day 90 ( It drops 1-2fps when combat happens). And as a minor note, some may get bored by it's simplistic design and may want more. For me it is a good marathon type game. Build, defend and hire. Real simple may turn people away. But over all nice time sink / time burn.

+Pixel graphics are done pretty good along with the reflection from water.
+Music adds a soothing enjoyable run.
+Simple design, Build, defend, hire and collect coins.
+Developers adding new features/content. Plus bug patching.
-/+Rogue like, you have but one life. May turn people away.
-/+ Odd DLC but in my opinion was worth it. May turn you away.
-/+Maybe too shallow for some. I find it just right.
-Late game lag can slow down to single digits. This one kills me as I like to see how long I can hold out.

It is a breath of fresh air to have bought something that is finished and enjoyable. Game lends a hand the first five minutes. There after you are on your own to trial and error until you figure out the workings. Keeping an eye on these developers Noio and Licorice. Here's to hopping they come out with some more games.

reviewText:
DO buy Kingdom if you like the sound of a side-scrolling, medieval, tower-defence-type game (that can be beaten) with atmospheric audio and beautiful pixel-art, a minimalist user interface, simple controls, and you like to experiment to find out how things work.

DON'T buy Kingdom if you like micro-managing lots of different types of units with sophisticated AIs, want HUDs or mini-maps or complex overlays, don't like single player games, or expect the game to hand everything to you on a silver platter.

After several hours of play you will either embrace the simplicity of the game and enjoy the Zen-like flow of night and day whilst fending off the relentless attacks of the enemy, or you'll be wishing there were more units, that the AI was more human, that your purse could hold more gold, or that the river was full of sharks with frickin' laser beams attached to their heads!
Well, maybe not that last one, but you'll be wishing there was... more...

Whilst you'll probably get over your initial dash with the game relatively quickly, there's a good chance you'll come back for more each time an update is released to try out and enjoy the new developments.  Kingdom feels like one of those diamonds in the rough that polishes up nicely over time.  Well worth the asking price.

reviewText:
I really want to love this game, but the frustrating makes me hate it.

Graphics, sounds and music are fantastic. The minimalist game style is also relaxing and makes it a unique experience. Game mechanic is simple and probably creative.

Then why am I not recommending the game? It's the damn archers I keep hiring and losing. As you play early on in the game, the archer is the only defense you can own. They are really slow and they will never manage to kill a monster unless they stay behind a wall or on a tower. They also MISS a lot of shots. Once a red moon rise, I quickly lose all men, tools and walls. Monsters are way too fast and the archer AI can do no ♥♥♥♥ if there are no walls.

I will take another shot at the game and perhaps I will watch a YouTube guide to see if my playstyle is correct or not. For the time being I will not recommend this game because I think the game own rules are highly unfair and frustrating.

reviewText:
This game is fun to a point, but at its core it doesn't quite seem like it knows what it wants to be. Is it a rougelike or a kingdom builder? There are elements of both, but unfortunately neither succeed. While the game is difficult at first, that's mainly because of the near total lack of tutorial. A quick look at a wiki or subreddit will give you a good grasp of the basics, and from there it's merely a game of optimization.

But here is where the balance between rougelike and kingdom builder runs into trouble. If this was more like a rougelike, and you died more, it would be fun to work on optimizing your build, strategizing and trying new things in order to reach the end game. But once you're over the initial difficulty curve, it isn't difficult to survive to the mid-late game. But even when you reach the end game, there isn't really anything to do. I quickly ran out of a goals besides expanding more, which quickly becomes a dull grind with no end in sight.

Admittedly, part of the allure of the game lies in the discovery aspect, and the devs seem committed to building out the endgame. And the game is beautiful. Extremely simple but well animated ever changing weather makes the experience great. For $5 (on sale when I purchased it), you could certainly do a lot worse. But as of now, it doesn't quite scratch the itch I was hoping for.

Beat it, got the credits while my horse continued in the last direction I held and then sat at the bridge unable to do anything. Had to force close the game.

Too much of a run and drop coins game. Not enough strategy, planning.

reviewText:
Ugh....I really hate to give this one a negative review. I wish Steam gave me something more than just a binary.

First off this game is lovely...stunningly lovely. Color usage, style, animation is all there. And the sound is just as fantastic from the plink of the arrows to the ambient mood music. Everything is balanced perfectly. It's a true work of art.

It even has really engrossing gameplay...for about an hour before it gets tedious. Sadly there just isn't much there beyond a solid foundation concept. If you stay away from guides and figure eveything out for yourself you can get a few solid hours out of it.

So yeah, this is the first negative review I am going to give that I feel guilty about.

reviewText:
It's not bad, but nothing special.

One of the first things you'll probably notice, is the almost complete lack of direction the game gives you. This wouldn't necessarily be a problem, as often you can intuit the function of something from the game. This is not the case for Kingdom. There are many buildings and upgrades that you only buy to try and guess - most of which are absolutely crucial to your success.

Somewhat counter-intuitively, the game punishes expansion by removing your source of new peasants, and adding only one relatively late game option for traveling quickly across your vast kingdom, making the bulk of the game a Manage the Horse's Stamina Simulator". This is offset by the massive amount of income that expansion can bring. Income that - after a point - becomes needlessly excessive (example: If the player chooses to expand vastly in one direction
date: the entire farmer class becomes unnecessary
recommended: due to the prevalence of rabbits
hoursPlayed: which net 1 gold each).\n\nTo top it off
voteText: the game is short. VERY short. And it offers little in the way of replay value.\n\nIn summary: I might pay $2 for this as a mobile game. Definitely not $10

reviewText: I wanted to love this game. I liked the nostalgia of pixel graphics, amazing game soundtrack, and a simple, interesting idea to play with. I first really enjoyed it and when I died learned from my mistakes and would just restarted my Kingdom. But slowly, I came to realize that this game is much like the modern equivalent of the Sisyphus. If you know your Greek mythology, he is the poor guy that had to roll a large boulder uphill everyday just to have it roll all the way back down.
