reviewText:
The good stuff first: the art style's pretty cool (imo), there are great little touches like arrows missing and sometimes going off the side into the water, and your money pouch can be full and overflow out onto the ground. The way you use the money to build everything up is great and seems pretty balanced. The music never really stood out to me, though....

This game has no difficulty curve, it instead has a difficulty slight incline leading to a difficulty vertical brick wall. You gallop around the countryside, never too fast on your apparently arthritic horse, using nothing but money to do everything. There are enemies you cannot fight or keep up with, which you must rely on your hired help to dispatch. The  AI's aim (which only matters for your side) is terrible.

I wanted to like this game, and it was cool for the first maybe 20 minutes. At night (just like in minecraft) the monsters come, and usually they're not really a problem, but they can steal money and tools if they get to you or your people. However, on (I believe) the 4th day, there's a standard minecraft-inspired blood moon type event. The only way I can rationalize this in my head is with the excuse that the programmer of the game somehow set the number of enemies to spawn as far too high but somehow didn't notice. The only way to survive is to do what feels like exploiting the game; I tried several different strategies before happening upon this one mere seconds before being overrun. I rushed the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything, played this (what I assumed was a) casual relaxing game like an RTS so that by the blood moon night, my pouch was literally overflowing with gold. I stood out in front of my town, between the advancing mass of jumpy red and green, and dumped all my money on the ground. This is the only thing I tried that actually got me through that night. I spent the next three days rebuilding and then the 4th night (8 total unless my count is off) another blood moon happened, and this time it brought flying jellyfish arm monsters which my defenses could do nothing against in addition to the phalanx of enemies blasting my way.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game on a whim, sucked in by its art style and a scrap of gameplay I saw on a stream.

4 hours later I regreted ever buying it, as I have already seen all that it has to offer. Is it because I sped through it with a wiki or a walkthrough? No. It's because Kingdom has little to no content, and its gameplay provides almost no agency over what's happening. Imagine an online 'one side' defence games, the ones where you recruit units to go towards the enemy, who is on the other side of the screen, while raising your own defenses; only in Kingdom, you have only one type of combat unit (for the majority of the game), who is very ineffective in what he's doing, and you can't direct the unit at all. It's completely autonomous. Even units in Peter Molyneaux's games could've been interacted with more.

In Kingdom you play as a King or Queen, who have to rebuild their dominion from scratch. You do this by collecting and spending gold coins - pay a wild man a coin and he will join your camp. Pay at a tool stand and the peasant will pick up the hammer and become a builder. Throw money at a stone, it will be adapted to a tower for your archers, etc. etc.

During the night you're being attacked by some monsters, who will steal your gold, knock it out of your people, knock their tools and weapons away, and then run with them. You prevent that by raising stockades and watchtowers and populating those with archers. Sounds easy and fun, right? Too bad it's tedious and plain boring after the first 15 minutes.

First of all, the game only explains the most basic mechanics tou you, so how to throw gold at people and how to spend it at structures. The rest should be self-explanatory right? Well it isn't, and there are a lot of minor details to the game's mechanics that make it really frustrating, not only on the first, clueless playthrough.

You can't change the professions of your subjects, once they have picked up the tools (so at first either hammer or bow).
You can't decide which tool they will pick up - they tend to go for the one that's closer to them, or the one that was available earlier, so keep that in mind.
You will not learn from anywhere, but own trial and error, that upgrading your main camp will, at a certain level, upgrade the nearest stockades for free, saving you gold. You will learn the hard way that the upgraded farm makes the peasants stay at it for the night, even if the farm is outside the city's walls - meaning all of those guys will lose their tools and their gold, and will be changed to king-less folk, whom you need to bribe with gold again.
You will be furious to learn, that upgrading your camp to the maximum basically takes away your tribute chest. This chest appears every morning, yielding a lot of gold pieces. But after the camp being changed into a small castle, you get only one gold piece, but you need a lot of cash to fuel your kingdom. Hell, if I knew, I'd never upgrade!

Those are just some of the pesky little things, that would be forgivable, if it wasn't for one thing. Kingdom doesn't have much more to offer. You run from left to right, managing the slowly growing Kingdom, learning across multiple playthroughs how to do it with maximum efficency, and soon enough you figure out that there's not much depth to all of it. There is no unit progression, the enemies grow up in strength at unfair rates, you play against the AI of your own subjects, because it tries to do the most stupid things.

Playing the Kingdom was fun at first and it certainly can suck you in for hours, but for 10 Euros it's not worth it and I can't recommend it, because it got boring and tedious in 4 hours.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I would really love to like this game, but I just can't. The idea is fantastic, and it's fun up to a point. After a while though, you just end up too frustrated with the mechanics of it. Every day having to run in one direction to recruit villagers becomes a chore, especially since you have to spend most of the time at an insanely annoying crawl; your gallop runs out fairly fast, leaving you slowly meandering away from the lightning fast enemies that are at least twice as fast as your horse. And you better hope you have camps to recruit from; the random placement of items in the world generation produces unwinnable worlds quite regularly. Money becomes a non-issue fairly quickly, with farms especially generating so much money that a walk through your farm will overflow and empty coinpurse. Walking past a group of archers throws up so many coins it'ss take you ten minutes to escape the lag.

Speaking of which, the lag. I have what I feel to be a respectable PC (GTX 970, FX 6350, 8gb RAM) yet the lag as soon as day 20ish onwards renders the game nigh unplayable. Every night lasts much longer than it should due to the immense lag that constantly occurs.

And lastly, a pet annoyance. You lose if your crown falls off. Seriously. Your entire kingdom gives up and goes home if you don't have flashy enough headgear, despite having so much gold from those farms you could probably build your walls from it. My latest game ended on the cusp of victory, almost 50 days in and about to destroy the final portal, because some monsters were out at noon sitting right on the other end of the portal I jumped through. My legions of super-laggy archers just gave up apparently.

Overall, the game has a fantastic concept, but the execution is just not up to par.

reviewText:
There's barely anything here. Once you've sunk 3-5 hours into this game it's over, and it's a very unsatisfying end. It feels, at first, like something that might keep opening up as you progress, but there are only 3-4 tiers per building, and only four buildings and only three monster types. Once you have a smallish kingdom going the game just breaks. They never anticipated that you'd do well, it seems, and the game basically just beats itself. This is very, very bad design.

I honestly have no idea how some of these reviewers have more than 10 hours put into this game. Ther content just is not there. I only have 7 because I kept going in the hope that there might be more content to unlock once you [MINOR SPOILER] destroy all of the portals [/minor spoiler]. There isn't.

This game is way, way too simplistic for something on the PC. It starts out really well, but it ends up being little more than an Armor Games flash game. You can play things almost exactly like this for free. Unless the devs add like AT LEAST five times the content this just isn't worth ten dollars.

tl;dr cute concept, great graphics, but god-awful design overall. definitely pass this up unless it's on sale at ~75% off.

reviewText:
The way this game works is very basic. You're a king or queen founding a kingdom. You use coins to recruit people to your kingdom, build structures and defenses and train your people, and you get coins through hunting, farming, and chests you sometimes get. There are 4 portals, 2 on each side of your settlement, that spawn enemies at night that attack your camp, and your archers and walls must hold them off. The goal is to grow your kingdom and eventually destroy the portals.

When I first got this, I played it for a while and couldn't stop throughout my whole first run. I lasted 20-something days, and even though I knew I should be going to bed, it kept me playing. It was a lot of fun! But eventually, I grew my kingdom too large too fast, I tried to destroy some portals too early and my kingdom was destroyed. OK, I thought. It's my first run. I'll do better next time.

And I did. But that's where the game lost me. Because after the basics, the game doesn't get any more complex. You build some walls, train some archers, rince, repeat. You do some other stuff too, but it's all the same thing, really. And all that would be OK and I would play through the game a couple of times and be satisfied since it's so cheap, but you get into the issue of awful controls. Well, I can't say awful." Let's just say

reviewText:
Beautiful pixel graphics, simple three button controls (literally just left, right, and down keys, or ASD). I do not recommend this game on account of both bugs, and late game gameplay issues.

The concept is fun. This game is a small scale, 2d, city builder somewhat similar in vein to age of empires with obvious tweaks to the formula.

The game is played as follows: Run back and and forth collecting gold from your peasants (who are either archers, builders, farmers, or knights), selectively upgrading your town (town hall, walls, garrisons, water wheels, and late game portals), and running into the woods to buy more peasants.

The above can be surprisingly fun and rewarding, however there are some late game issues that really kill the game:

When you hit around the half way point of the game, it takes your character literally a full day just to run back and forth to each end of your camp. It takes unarmed peasants even longer. This turns into a logistics" problem where you constantly find yourself running from side to side to restock troops and balance building out further (which in turn makes you run further). This becomes not fun pretty fast
date: gold becomes a non issue at this point as well
recommended:
as you constantly race against the clock to run insurmountable distances to repeat mundane tasks.

In terms of bugs: Sometimes end of game doesn't register. Sometimes archers will endlessly walk to their death instead of returning to town at night (this is somewhat game breaking early game).

The graphics are really great. The gameplay is novel. I can't endorse full price. I just can't. Pick this up on sale so you don't get upset when the charm quickly wares away."

reviewText:
This game starts off really strong, and shows a lot of promise.  It gets you going with a very simple premise, get money, recruit villagers, upgrade your town.  Buy hammers to turn villagers into builders, buy bows to turn them into hunters.  Then they introduce farmers, catapults, and lastly knights.  And this all takes place in the format of a side scroller.  It's really unique.

And you get to build up your town, which is fun at first.  You unlock a new building every other day or so.  It's exciting when your towers and walls get higher and higher.

The challenge of the enemies which assault your town ramps up as well, with a massive wave every 5 days.  At first it's a ton of fun trying to build up enough to meet the challenge.

But very quickly you realize it's rather shallow.  In fact, it's repetitive and shallow.  After a certain point all you do anymore is build walls and towers, and try to replenish your archers from the scant recruits you need to venture deeper and deeper into the forest to find.  After day 10 there is only one more thing to see.  After day 20 there is nothing.

And the challenge quickly escalates to something that feels unfair.  You need lots of archers to defend your walls.  But then the quantity and toughness of enemies increases, and you need catapults.  Then the floating demons show up which fly over your walls and just pluck people up and eat them.  But that's still manageable, if you have a large enough mass of archers behind your walls.  Then the trolls show up, and they destroy walls and throw your catapult rocks back at you, decimating your archers beyond recovery.  But they are slow, so you need to build towers a ways out to weaken them as they approach your town.  Except any archers you put in your towers just get eaten by the floating demons.  It's a game of rock, paper, scissors where at the end of the day, you aren't allowed to throw rock.

But to make matters even worse, the gameplay is rather passive as well.  When the action gets started, you mostly just get to watch.  Really you don't even need to be there.  Except there is nowhere else to be, since to leave the safety of your town results in disaster anyways.  So you sit and do nothing while your archers fend off the enemy, and you wait for the sun to come up.  Another aspect of this game which is novel at first, but gets old fast.

Who knows, maybe they'll flesh this game out a bit more.  Right now it feels like a proof of concept from a gamejam without the depth or scope of content a full game requires.  For a game which has achievements going out to surviving 100 days, the amount of content is surprisingly sparse.

If they flesh out the content more I'd change my opinion.  The game needs a longer path of escalation.  Give the player more tools to mitigate the limits of the early game, but then throw bigger challenges at them which force them to rush further up a tech tree to mitigate those.  Add something to ward off the flying demons, but then add another enemy which counters that.  Upgrade the players horse to run farther and faster since you have to cover a lot more ground in the late game.  Give the player something to do at night except just watch the action.  These are the challenges the Kingdom dev team needs to overcome before I consider this anything more than a tech demo or a proof of concept.

reviewText:
Beautiful pixel graphics, simple three button controls (literally just left, right, and down keys, or ASD). I do not recommend this game on account of both bugs, and late game gameplay issues.

The concept is fun. This game is a small scale, 2d, city builder somewhat similar in vein to age of empires with obvious tweaks to the formula.

The game is played as follows: Run back and and forth collecting gold from your peasants (who are either archers, builders, farmers, or knights), selectively upgrading your town (town hall, walls, garrisons, water wheels, and late game portals), and running into the woods to buy more peasants.

The above can be surprisingly fun and rewarding, however there are some late game issues that really kill the game:

When you hit around the half way point of the game, it takes your character literally a full day just to run back and forth to each end of your camp. It takes unarmed peasants even longer. This turns into a logistics" problem where you constantly find yourself running from side to side to restock troops and balance building out further (which in turn makes you run further). This becomes not fun pretty fast
date: gold becomes a non issue at this point as well
recommended:
as you constantly race against the clock to run insurmountable distances to repeat mundane tasks.

In terms of bugs: Sometimes end of game doesn't register. Sometimes archers will endlessly walk to their death instead of returning to town at night (this is somewhat game breaking early game).

The graphics are really great. The gameplay is novel. I can't endorse full price. I just can't. Pick this up on sale so you don't get upset when the charm quickly wares away."

reviewText:
This game starts off really strong, and shows a lot of promise.  It gets you going with a very simple premise, get money, recruit villagers, upgrade your town.  Buy hammers to turn villagers into builders, buy bows to turn them into hunters.  Then they introduce farmers, catapults, and lastly knights.  And this all takes place in the format of a side scroller.  It's really unique.

And you get to build up your town, which is fun at first.  You unlock a new building every other day or so.  It's exciting when your towers and walls get higher and higher.

The challenge of the enemies which assault your town ramps up as well, with a massive wave every 5 days.  At first it's a ton of fun trying to build up enough to meet the challenge.

But very quickly you realize it's rather shallow.  In fact, it's repetitive and shallow.  After a certain point all you do anymore is build walls and towers, and try to replenish your archers from the scant recruits you need to venture deeper and deeper into the forest to find.  After day 10 there is only one more thing to see.  After day 20 there is nothing.

And the challenge quickly escalates to something that feels unfair.  You need lots of archers to defend your walls.  But then the quantity and toughness of enemies increases, and you need catapults.  Then the floating demons show up which fly over your walls and just pluck people up and eat them.  But that's still manageable, if you have a large enough mass of archers behind your walls.  Then the trolls show up, and they destroy walls and throw your catapult rocks back at you, decimating your archers beyond recovery.  But they are slow, so you need to build towers a ways out to weaken them as they approach your town.  Except any archers you put in your towers just get eaten by the floating demons.  It's a game of rock, paper, scissors where at the end of the day, you aren't allowed to throw rock.

But to make matters even worse, the gameplay is rather passive as well.  When the action gets started, you mostly just get to watch.  Really you don't even need to be there.  Except there is nowhere else to be, since to leave the safety of your town results in disaster anyways.  So you sit and do nothing while your archers fend off the enemy, and you wait for the sun to come up.  Another aspect of this game which is novel at first, but gets old fast.

Who knows, maybe they'll flesh this game out a bit more.  Right now it feels like a proof of concept from a gamejam without the depth or scope of content a full game requires.  For a game which has achievements going out to surviving 100 days, the amount of content is surprisingly sparse.

If they flesh out the content more I'd change my opinion.  The game needs a longer path of escalation.  Give the player more tools to mitigate the limits of the early game, but then throw bigger challenges at them which force them to rush further up a tech tree to mitigate those.  Add something to ward off the flying demons, but then add another enemy which counters that.  Upgrade the players horse to run farther and faster since you have to cover a lot more ground in the late game.  Give the player something to do at night except just watch the action.  These are the challenges the Kingdom dev team needs to overcome before I consider this anything more than a tech demo or a proof of concept.

reviewText: Some people may call this an RTS but to me it seems more of a time management game, because that's excatly what it is. The structure follows that every ten days a very large wave of monsters will decend upon your town. The most difficult part of this is not so much said monsters but getting around the game's inherent flaws; The sluggish pace of which your workers move, the extremely short time frame for each day, and the lack of being able to defend yourself and instead relying solely upon your defenses. Such defenses require an ideal layout which is random each time on a new game, For example a rock is used to build the first part of a tower (which can then be further upgraded to house more archers), a wheat field that is used for a large source of income may be too far away, etc. This game has a lot of charm, especially if you like retro-style visuals. Bottomline I don't think this game was well thought out. It has a very steep learning curve, almost to the point where the defeat comes so easily one might think the developers were being preachy on the transience of any success.

reviewText:
Ugh....I really hate to give this one a negative review. I wish Steam gave me something more than just a binary.

First off this game is lovely...stunningly lovely. Color usage, style, animation is all there. And the sound is just as fantastic from the plink of the arrows to the ambient mood music. Everything is balanced perfectly. It's a true work of art.

It even has really engrossing gameplay...for about an hour before it gets tedious. Sadly there just isn't much there beyond a solid foundation concept. If you stay away from guides and figure eveything out for yourself you can get a few solid hours out of it.

So yeah, this is the first negative review I am going to give that I feel guilty about.

reviewText:
It's not bad, but nothing special.

One of the first things you'll probably notice, is the almost complete lack of direction the game gives you. This wouldn't necessarily be a problem, as often you can intuit the function of something from the game. This is not the case for Kingdom. There are many buildings and upgrades that you only buy to try and guess - most of which are absolutely crucial to your success.

Somewhat counter-intuitively, the game punishes expansion by removing your source of new peasants, and adding only one relatively late game option for traveling quickly across your vast kingdom, making the bulk of the game a Manage the Horse's Stamina Simulator". This is offset by the massive amount of income that expansion can bring. Income that - after a point - becomes needlessly excessive (example: If the player chooses to expand vastly in one direction

reviewText:
Kingdom is a procedurally generated, 2D city builder game in where you take control of either a king or a queen, on their quest to build a kingdom that can withstand the relentless creatures that awaken at night. Whether you are a boy or a girl is random though you can roll a new appearance on the loading screen by pressing the S key. You start off with nothing but a few coins and must set up shelter before the dark hits. A small tutorial is given, though pretty soon you will be left to figure things out on your own. This is a trial and error type of game so you will more than likely die your first few times playing. Other than riding around and sprinting on your horse, your only other form of interactivity will be to drop money on people or objects. You have no forms of attack and must rely on your peasants to get you through the night. To recruit more peasants you go searching the wilderness for them and give them a coin to convince them. Why they need to be bribed when you are offering food and shelter from the darkness we may never know.

Giving coins to the stall with a hammer will get you a hammer that a peasant with no profession can pick up to start building walls and maintaining your defenses. The stall with a bow will allow you to buy the equipment necessary for Archers, which will be your main source of income early on as they will hunt the lands and return to you with the profits of poaching animals. Archers are also your only unit capable of attacking for a large portion of the game and are absolutely necessary to surviving the creature filled night. You will need to build a wall so that they stand a chance at winning since your melee units are only recruitable late in game, annoyingly enough. Guard towers will usually be able to be built behind walls and station an archer high above ground to defend your kingdom. That may seem useful but in reality towers are a waste of money in this game due to the Archers never again be able to leave from it. It does not sound that bad, but when you start expanding and you have a bunch of archers stationed in useless positions, while your forces are weak from the previous attack and on the verge of collapsing, it can very easily lead to your doom.

Your doom can still come easily in various cheap feeling ways. Archers have terrible aim and when you have a horde of relentless creatures tearing down your wall, which can easily result in them getting through and wiping out your kingdom due to not being allowed to have melee units yet. So build more walls or upgrade them further you may think. Well what you do in this game doesn't really feel like building, everything is preset for you in certain locations, so you have no say to where or what you build. You can upgrade your walls twice which is not all that durable and to upgrade your wall further you have to go deep into a random part of the forest and offer coins to some kind of shrine. It is fine to have little hand holding but that makes no sense. Tearing down buildings is not possible so be very careful about what you build. Buildings cannot be moved either, so new peasants that arrive when you have a quite a bit of territory will have to go all the way to the center of your kingdom to get a bow or hammer. That is a walk all the way from where you recruit them, down to the center of your kingdom and back to the outskirts of your territory where you actually need them.

Even then your peasants love to wander off and occasionally die a needless death when they are out after dark. It makes sense that your archers may lose track of time when hunting but when they see it is dark out they will very slowly make their way back without a care in the world. The dumb friendly AI and their slow movement speed combine perfectly together to make things far more tedious than they should be. Builders seem to have the worst AI as they will often times be off staring into space somewhere instead of being on the front lines doing their jobs and manning the catapults which only they know how to use. Sadly you are also affected by slow movement speeds and an asthmatic horse than can only run for a few seconds. In a game with no means of controlling anything other than going right up to the object you want to interact with, even if it is on the other side of the map, having a feature that hinders your means to do so is utterly unnecessary. Your horse can sprint a bit longer if you stand still and let it eat some grass though not by much.

Each day you receive taxes from your peasants and these are placed in the center of your kingdom. So imagine you have just withstood a huge attack and most of your peasants didn't make it. That means you have to go to the center of town if you need cash and then all the way to forests, while hoping that your very slow peasants make it before dark. Even if they do they certainly won't make it all the way to the center of the kingdom and back to the front lines to fight. You cannot tell them what profession to be either, they will grab a tool at random and you will not be able to change him into something else. There is no way of telling how many of your peasants don't have a profession and are currently useless unless you stumble upon them. The amount that they ask you to do in such a short day is absurd and quickly starts to feel like a chore. You feel like less of a king and more like an obsessive mother, trying to bribe her rebellious kids into doing what she wants, one that has never heard of a safe and decided to throw into a lake whatever extra money she may have that won't fit in her purse. At the very least they nailed the environments and atmosphere of the game. The mood of this game ranges from creepy to yet another perfect sunny day to good effect. Whatever the case may be the soundtrack definitely adds a lot to the experience.

The starting monsters in this game are greedy little creatures that will steal anything they can get their hands on and over all else want the shiny crown on your head which will result in a game over for you. They are easy to defeat most nights, however when the moon turns red they will attack in a massive horde that will likely be the death of you. Well actually these creatures will not kill you or anyone else but they will steal all your peasant's equipment and cause them to flee from your kingdom until you bribe them to stay. The other two monsters that appear later on will gladly kill all of you however.  Which your blind Archers and lazy Builders seem all too eager to let happen. I don't mean to make Kingdom sound like an awful game, it's just extremely tedious due to poor design. It could have been an amazing game but every positive thing seems to have more negative to it. Sure the world is randomly generated but with buildings being preset for you it all feels the same with no room for experimentation. You are free to explore the cool environments but must micromanage far too many things in person and night is upon you before you know it. Yes you are the king, though it feels more like being the paper boy with no say over anything, that just so happens to have everyone's paycheck in his pouch. With better AI, a real time map of sorts that shows you how many peasants you have as well as their profession, longer days and maybe some sort of NPC that recruits peasants for twice the prize, Kingdom would become a much better game. As it is, I would suggest holding off on buying it and seeing if any improvements are made, if you are interested in what Kingdom offers.

reviewText:
Let me preface this review by saying that I haven't spent much time playing Kingdom but I think I have played to enough to experience most of the game. Also, this is the first time I have reviewed anything so if I seem too vague in my opinions let me know.

TL;DR - This game has SOOO much potential as it has a very unique approach to this genre. The art and music are amazing and create an interesting and enjoyable atmosphere. The early game is quite entertaining as well. However, the lack of content, depth, control and terrible AI results in a tedious and boring experience.
PROS:
- The soundtrack was nice. It built the atmosphere and mood of the environment and situations (battling/night and day/peacefuk).
- Art is pretty spectacular :) I am such a huge fan of pixel graphics and this game delivered tremendously. Everything had a beautiful design, the environment was created perfectly (rain, fog, night, day) and it all felt amazing.
- The beginning of the game is quite exciting. When you start off gathering workers and initially building the village it's great because everything is so close and you are getting use to the game.
CONS:
- To me this game lacks a lot of content. As said before, the beginning is actually very fun because I wasn't aware of the rest of the game. But as I progressed I realised that there wasn't much more to do. The game mainly consists of building and upgrading (which is very simple in its self), managing gold and workers and exploring (with little to find). Maybe if there was upgrade trees to buildings, different classes for warriors, upgrading yourself (the king/queen) so you can fight or move around faster (god damn you move slow).
- Terrible AI. The Ai is very bad in this game. The archers have heaps of trouble hitting things, the knights do absolutely nothing, sometimes the workers walk off into the wild. It really is frustrating.
- Lack of control over game. You can't control where troops are to defend, what occupation your new troops will take on. You can't choose where to build as there are build points throughout the landscape, this coupled with the procedurally generated terrain makes for some very limited and random defensive oppourtunities.
- Everything moves WAY to slow. Workers walk too slow and often get converted back while walking, expecially if they are too far away. Buildings that are on the outskirts can take ages to be built only to be knocked down again at night or not get built in time. The horse needs to move a little faster (or there needs to be teleportation things you unlock) as it takes ages to get to the sides of your kingdom once you progress. Also when your workers get their tools taken away it takes ages for them to get it back because they have to walk all the way to the shop again.
- No HUDs. There could be little indicators to tell you if you are getting attacked, how many archers, warriors or people you have. Also an overview of the map would be useful as you can see where buildings need to be upgraded or where you are getting attacked. You are very much not notified of anything in this game, which I think i quite unfair and punishing to the player.
- Not very resource-gathery. There is only really 2 resources you gather in this game, gold and people. I wish there could be more resources to gather and manage which would in itself open up more content for the game.

I know this game says it has a 'minimalist feel' but I just feel that it is WAY to lacking in content. Either add more content and replayability or lower the price tag. For me, the positives are heavily outweighed by the negatives. Sorry, but I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
Based on my early experience I would recommend this game without a shadow of doubt, not only is it the pixel art that has some effort behind it, the game looks beautiful, and feels eerie and mysterious without blantly throwing magic and sparks at you. the animations are basic, but they are not ugly, or lackling.
It's not your casual game though, let me elaborate as it might not be extremaly hard, if you aren't a person who can figure out games on your own, this may not be the game for you. Kingdom does not hold you by the hand, it throws you in, after showing you how to build your basic shelter, and then you are left on your own.
When the night starts, that's when the badies start to come at you, and they will relentlessly try to take you down so far I'm trying to sruvive the attacks, so can't really tell you what may unfold later in the game.
Music is a worthy addition to the game, it changes according to your actions, and the situation to the world, in an non intrussive but noticable way.
Mechanics so far are simplistic, you get coins, and you pay coins to
1. Get a person to follow you
2. Buy him equipment
3. Build defenses and upgrade you'r land
4. In my last game I stumbled across a merchant.
at least that's what I figured out so far. There are some places in the game where you can use your coins but I wasn't able to figure out what they do so far.

I had not been able to fully experience this game yet, but I will try to add to this review

Some early let's play videos: https://youtu.be/Hw_QBBWefGM

reviewText:
Kindom is a beautiful game and I enjoyed playing it very much at the beginning. But sadly I can't say it is a good game. It's worth about two or three hours of playtime. After that it gets very repetitive and feels like working rather than playing.

+Beautiful style
+Interesting mechanics, basebuilding, monsters

-After one or two hours everything is discovered
-The map is too big / I am too slow
-You can't demolish buildings: alls my archers are spread out and easy pray for the flying maneaters instead of gathering in a big crowd.
-Recruiting is really annoying (even with portals, I still had to ride from one end to my base where the portals were in order to get to a camp on the other side of the map)

Bug: If your border is on a spot with a stream, you can't send your knights to attack. You can only build a farm (which you cannot demolish, and at your frontlines) and send them in afterwards.

If you want to improve things: I think more types of enemies, traps, and other content would make the game more enjoyable for a longer time. Enable the player to make more strategic descisions instead of making the player grind to win the game, like you are now. Or if you don't want to change that much... just make the map smaller!

reviewText:
really good try it out if u want
its one of those games you play on the background while watching netflix /hulu/youtube.

Graphics: pixel, detailed, kinda reminds me of a miazaki movie. its also really calming to look at.

sound: ambient, natural, calm, relaxing to hear. its like if chamomile tea was a sound.

gameplay: slowish paced, day is peacfull and night is dangerouse, kinda a layed back game like i said in the beggining. you get coins and use them to build stuff or expand your place and you buy tool/weapons with them too. the coins are used also to hire campers and stuff wich go back to ur base and work for you by taking the tools/weapons. u have to defend your place from monsters at night.
BEWARE: a kinda big learning curve adventualy for some but its still fun.

just try it out for an hour and if you dont like it get a refund.
if u dont know how to get a refund just search STEAM REFUNDS and it should be the top of the list.

reviewText:
The game has a fresh and demanding touch for the first tries / couple hours. The gameplay is simple but it's hard to capture the right moments to act, because time goes by fast.
With every run and possible defeat you learn more. But after a few rounds, when you come to the lategame, it becomes clear, that the game is not finished, for a lategame is not existent.

I also encountered some severe bugs, which forced me to start over. One time about half of the population wasn't moving anymore and became worthless. Another time I could not send out knights, but only on the left side.

So at this moment, I wouldn't recommend the game, even though I had some fun hours with it. The lack of endgame and the bugs are enough to get a downgrade. After that is fixed, I would recommend it to people who like a challenge in managing a little kingdom.

reviewText: This game's cheerful soundtrack and initially-charming aesthetic serve to charm potential buyers. There is very little actual gameplay; most of your time is spent simply walking back and forth and picking up/dropping coins. Your only reward is continued survival... Which translates to more walking back and forth and picking up/dropping coins. Your kingdom's visuals will change a little, and your people will grow in number. However, these little nuggets of advancement are marred by [honestly] dull visuals, unhelpful AI, and the potential for all of your progress to be lost when you die to a single enemy that was running at you at high speed from off-screen.\n\nI might pick it up again it receives more content or goes on sale, but, for now, I'm content with a refund.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I want to love Kingdom, I really do. The art and sound are both fantastic and it's desire to be a rogue-like city builder is a sound premise but it just isn't a game you'll want to come back to after a couple of hours.

I played a lot of this game at a recent expo and hoped the devs would improve a lot of it from then. Sadly they haven't.

Making a hard game is fine, but there's no progression or randomness in Kingdom. As the player is so relient on AI villagers it's insanely frustrating not to be able to control them, especially as they're so vulnerable. The little people don't run and hide from the enemy and they blindly follow orders you might have issued ages ago as they're so damn slow.

There's no such thing as a good run" or "bad run" to add challenge or variety. You build and every 5 days you get messed up
date: usually unfairly so. There's no positive or negative surprises. The game needs better AI
recommended: more secrets and strangeness and ideally an easier mode so players can sandbox play if they want to learn what works and what doesn't."
hoursPlayed: October 26, 2015

reviewText:
I got Kingdom expecting some sort of FTL or Risk of Rain style rogue-lite. I was sorely disappointed.

In the end there isn't much to the game, there are no unlocks, no advanced buildings, no interesting classes or enemies. Your only real goal is to make sure the enemy doesn't break down one of you walls and to make sure that doesn't happen you upgrade the wall and run back and forth between camps to recuit units. There is very little strategy beyond this. You can't, for instance, order your troops to stay closer to the walls, or to reinforce a different wall.

All you can do when the enemies attack is hope your archer's pitiful accuracy doesn't cost you the game.

TL;DR Kingdom lacks the exploration aspect of FTL and the action aspect of Risk of Rain. It lacks the fun of a good rouge-lite.

reviewText:
Seriously, what the heck is wrong with modern developers?  When video games first got started there were technical limitations that made it really hard to split music and sound effects so that users could balance them as they saw fit.  Those days are GONE.  Stop force-feeding your music track on me!

I personally hate music with my games, but I know other users want to adjust music volume down at least somewhat so they can hear the sound effects more clearly.

Well, you won't be doing that today with Kingdom.  I'm going to struggle to play in spite of the stupid music track and I'll update this review if I change my mind.  I wouldn't hold your breath.

Edit: Nope, all done here.  Too bad, this is an idea with potential.

reviewText:
As others are saying, the units and the vast size of the game are the most frustrating aspects of the game.

To briefly elaborate, you have a center base and need to recruit by venturing out of your center base to get them from fire-and-tent camps.  You normally only get 2 recruits at a time.  These recruits then walk back to center base.  However, as you build farther and farther out, your recruits take longer and longer to get to the center.  If they lose their weapon by being attacked -- or even worse, demoralized, where you have to hire them again or lose them forever -- then they have to walk alllll the way back to the center from battlefront. It's insanely time consuming.

And speaking of having to hire them again if they become demoralized, you have to be there to hire them.  But if they lose their weapons, you have to buy new ones (at the very center of the map).  So with a two-front war, you have to just pick a side to be present on and support, all the while trying to run back and be sure your recruits have the weapons they need so they can get right back to the front.  Meanwhile, if one side gets devastated, you have to spend another day recruiting, running back and forth to the center to equip your new recruits.  *Even if* you buy a bunch of equipment in advance, the too-simple AI just grabs the nearest item.

Do you need archers
recommended: you now have 4 builders!  Guess you gotta recruit more guys!"\n\nYou can't flag or assign new recruits to special roles
hoursPlayed:
or give them gold to go back to the center camp to buy what you tell them to buy.  You need to be there to buy the equipment.

Meanwhile your kingdom gets destroyed.

Come to think of it

reviewText:
this would be a 9/10 indie game if the late-game gameplay wasnt as chaotic, monotone and boring and If the devs tweaked the AI a little bit or added some minimalistic controls to the positioning of the army to compensate for the horrible AI of your soldiers

it starts great.. with nicely done pixel art graphics and good sound effects that together make a great atmosphere
you start collecting coins from your guys, who get them from hunting animals or (later on) from farming. and assign new dutties to those, who dont have any work to do yet by buying new equipment for them (you buy a bow and the nearest peasant without work grabs it and starts hunting rabbits and deers)
during the day you collect money, and spend them on your settlement, new gear, getting new people to come to your village or on other stuff
and when the night comes you have to deffend your little base from monsters that come from forests outside of your village

for the first few days its fun and really great .. but when you get a steady income from farmers (4 is enough to get you through the whole game so its not something hard to get to) youve probably seen everything there is to be seen.. all you will be doing from then on will be: pay for new villagers, buy some bows
and again, and again, and again.. till you have enough of them to send them to the forest to take care of the monster spawn point.. and all without any pop cap or anything.. no strategy involved.. just get more of them .. and then even some more

im sorry but the end-game of this is horribly done .. if you could set the peasants and bows to be bought automatically you wouldnt even have to play it

reviewText:
Love it. The environment is gorgeous and the music is great. I love watching the weather and lighting change. The gameplay is satisfying and elegant.

I'd like to see: some small QoL fixes, more random variation in the level layout, more random things to find in the forest (like the merchants), and a more decisive endgame -- it does tend to stall out.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game: I love the aesthetics of it and love empire building games.\n\nHowever, the novelty of its interface (simply having only one action you can take, which is dropping coins) wears off quickly and the game eventually plays itself. There's very little for the player to do in terms of differentiating one play session from another: you build what the map gives you. The only major strategy is the timing on when" you build certain things
date: and it's such a small amount of agency given to the player that is feels very minimal in terms of satisfaction. Once you get over the endearing graphics and inspired music
recommended: it unfortunately becomes exceptionally tedious having to canter from one side of your kingdom to another on a insanely easily winded horse while you pray your AI minions pick up the right items from your shops and do things in the order that is helpful.\n\nAt first I was seriously hoping it was going to be evocative of the original 1993 game Stronghold by TSR
hoursPlayed: but alas I felt extremely underwhelmed by this. A+ for visuals and theme
voteText: C- for gameplay and overall replayablity."

reviewText:
Inititally it's a pretty game to look at, but the actual gameplay is shallow and frustrating after more than a few hours. Kingdom really left me wanting more, in a bad way. I kept hoping there would be more to it, but all there is in the later game is the challenge of a paper thin tech tree, nonsensical AI, arbitrary and plainly unfun design decisions, and monster waves that never cease in getting more and more difficult.

Survived for 100 days? Sucks to be you, it's impossible to destroy the portals now. You can only summon two knights to a side, the extra knights on the cleared side of a map can't be moved, and even though you have 200 archers roaming around, only a few will wander near the side under attack at any one time. To attack a portal you can only send two knights plus six archers, and they move SLOWLY. Why can't you send your entire 200 man force at the portals and just finish the game? I have no idea.

Later in the game, your minions will have their pockets overflowing with gold, and will heap it at your feet as you ride by. So if five or ten of them are wandering around the archery & farming booths, why can't you have them buy more equipment for you? Why isn't there a standing order to always keep four bows at the ready? I have no clue! You have to gallop your butt all the way back from the front, have your minions throw money at you, and then buy equipment literally a foot away from them.

Perhaps the devs slimmed down the interface & gameplay to preserve the aesthtic they were going for? I can ALMOST get that...but not this way, guys. The game is just frustrating.

reviewText:
A simple yet addicting game that's great fun, but with some painful shortcomings.
Kingdom does a great job of demanding patience and control, careful planning, rationing, etc. My first playthrough, thinking that expansion was the name of the game, I grew out wildly, populating my bowmen sparsely along the watchtowers over my kingdom and leaving my borders relativly defensless. My reckless expansion also pushed out the only camps between my kingdom and the demon-portals, starving me of recruits.

My second playthrough I knew better. Careful expansion outwards, fortifying my borders, constantly recruiting new archers to build my garrison. The blood moons would come, sometimes the enemy would overwhelm my defences, but I always tried to have a healthy stash of coins to rebuild.

Before long I had a farm within my borders, allowing my farmers to stay the night and work throughout the day. I had catapults to deal with hoards, maxed out walls, a large standing force of archers. And then a blood moon came again. This one with flying creatures, ogre-like siege monsters, and a hoard unlike any I had seen. Several maxed stone walls, multiple towers with 3 archers in them! And yet every thing was destroyed. Farmers, builders, archers, and all the peasants themselves lost to me. Probably 100 and change of coins lost in one night.
And here's my problem with the game.

Your daily allowance, a tax" as it were

reviewText:
I really enjoy this game. Once you get a simple pattern down, it's quite easy to play but still fun. Beaten on my 3rd play through, I decided to restart, get to a point where I could just tank anything thrown at me, and walked away from my computer. 2 hours later, it's day 130 and my guys are still going strong. Game was lagging due to the amount of coins on the screen but hey, not the point xD

My advise is this: only build one way first (AFTER getting a large force first. NEVER expand before day 5), always rush stone working ASAP, make sure to have an upgraded farmhouse as close as you can get to your farthest out wall, annnnnd never stop getting those hobos to join. If you go West first, you can get 4-6 of them in a day easily. Slap some bows on those guys and bam, plenty of arrows to murder demons with.

Questions about it? Ask away :) Think the game is too hard after day 40? Git Gud mate ;)

reviewText:
The basic premise works well enough; build a basic Kingdom and defend it using towers and wall. The building of your community is fun and I got a distinct Act Raiser feel to watching your itty bitty people work. The world is randomly generated which is great for a fresh challenge every time, but works against the game because sometimes you start with plots for either just towers or just walls (if you can't stop the bad guys how can you kill them??). You can find random little goodies out in the woods like shrines to boost your peoples and some weird temple that allows you to advance to the next tech level. Again these goodies could be ANYWHERE and if you never find that tech temple it'll be game over real quick.

Now to the reason I have to select NO for this game; this game wasn't developed properly. They made their game half-Civ and half-tower defense with no tower defense gameplay at all. Your soldiers randomly decide what they are doing and where they are defending and you're just going to have to deal with it. I've had archers out beyond the wall during Red Moon nights (Boss time), builders charging through hordes to chop down a tree I scheduled two days earlier to be chopped, and don't even get me started on the catapults. The monsters generally only attack one side at a time, but you can't tell your soldiers where to go so you'll have one side with six soldiers falling asleep while the other has a horde barreling through. Your defenses are useless from behind so all you do is watch your kingdom fall.

Quickly about catapults. They destroy massive hordes of enemies at once, but only if a builder is loading it. They also ALWAYS go to the furthest wall, nevermind that perfect choak-point you've got that's just asking for some heavy weapons. Catapults would be more functional if you could assign a builder to it permanently but too bad for you!!!

Now for the part of the review that should be everyone's favorite GENDER POLITICS!!!! So you have no say on who your avatar could be; could be a black Queen in purple, blonde King in green, or any other combination. This is garbage liberal crap that has no place in video games just for the sole reason that, in our reality, people can self identify to be whatever the Hell they want. They can undergo surgery to become a man or choose to use the womans bathrooom for no other reason besides the fact that they feel like nothing should limit them. Why can't I choose my avatar?? This is honestly a missed opportunity to customize your banner, horse, colors, crown, whatever you want but NOPE all that's predetermined. Even though everything is supposed to be random I've been the same damn Queen with brown hair and a green dress 4 times, and when I've played about 7 rounds of this game you start to feel like it's not so random.

So you are so forward thinking when to comes to forced player characters, but why are the lowly, dirty, peasents men?? You're going to force me to play as a woman because you think I should but you aren't even going to include women in the working class of the Kingdom?? Is it because you're lazy and couldn't be bothered to animate another model (honestly the serfs are the same model with different hair and skin colors)?? Or is it because you think women are our betters and should be commanding men?? I just don't understand how you can force genders on your players but not include a mixup of npcs, it's lazy and if the shoe was on the other foot the developers would be ripped to pieces for their intolerance.

I'm probably going to try this game two more times and be done with it. For $10 I'd say I got my money's worth out of this, but if the development team got their heads out of their asses and put as much work into combat as they did with cultivation then I would have picked the Yes button. Between having no authority over your subjects (huh kinda funny for a game called Kingdom) and their garbage gender politics of a 5 year old imma recommend you take your time elsewhere.

reviewText:
One hour.

That's how long it took me to realize that this game is very much a wonderful and horrible game.

It looks nice, it sounds nice.  The overall atmosphere is good.

It also has a bit of a harshness to it in that you have to figure out most of the stuff on your own.  Exactly what does upgrading this do?  What does that do?  It somewhat harkens back to the old days of gaming when you weren't told anything and had to figure it out on your own.


However after Day 25 the game becomes a vicious, nigh unbeatable game.  Not only that but the back and forth you have to do, running to and fro, proves unbelievabely tedious as your Kingdom becomes larger and larger.  Your citizens in turn also take forever, and half the time they don't do what you want them to do.
If there's a way to forcefully control them then I failed to figure it out.

It's almost like a Lemmings Kingdom Builder game.  Sooner or later your guys are going to fall off the cliff to their death and there's only frustration when it happens.

This is a game that is great for people who want an extreme challenge.

I've had archers out beyond the wall during Red Moon nights (Boss time), builders charging through hordes to chop down a tree I scheduled two days earlier to be chopped, and don't even get me started on the catapults. The monsters generally only attack one side at a time, but you can't tell your soldiers where to go so you'll have one side with six soldiers falling asleep while the other has a horde barreling through. Your defenses are useless from behind so all you do is watch your kingdom fall.

Quickly about catapults. They destroy massive hordes of enemies at once, but only if a builder is loading it. They also ALWAYS go to the furthest wall, nevermind that perfect choak-point you've got that's just asking for some heavy weapons. Catapults would be more functional if you could assign a builder to it permanently but too bad for you!!!

Now for the part of the review that should be everyone's favorite GENDER POLITICS!!!! So you have no say on who your avatar could be; could be a black Queen in purple, blonde King in green, or any other combination. This is garbage liberal crap that has no place in video games just for the sole reason that, in our reality, people can self identify to be whatever the Hell they want. They can undergo surgery to become a man or choose to use the womans bathrooom for no other reason besides the fact that they feel like nothing should limit them. Why can't I choose my avatar?? This is honestly a missed opportunity to customize your banner, horse, colors, crown, whatever you want but NOPE all that's predetermined. Even though everything is supposed to be random I've been the same damn Queen with brown hair and a green dress 4 times, and when I've played about 7 rounds of this game you start to feel like it's not so random.

So you are so forward thinking when to comes to forced player characters, but why are the lowly, dirty, peasents men?? You're going to force me to play as a woman because you think I should but you aren't even going to include women in the working class of the Kingdom?? Is it because you're lazy and couldn't be bothered to animate another model (honestly the serfs are the same model with different hair and skin colors)?? Or is it because you think women are our betters and should be commanding men?? I just don't understand how you can force genders on your players but not include a mixup of npcs, it's lazy and if the shoe was on the other foot the developers would be ripped to pieces for their intolerance.

I'm probably going to try this game two more times and be done with it. For $10 I'd say I got my money's worth out of this, but if the development team got their heads out of their asses and put as much work into combat as they did with cultivation then I would have picked the Yes button. Between having no authority over your subjects (huh kinda funny for a game called Kingdom) and their garbage gender politics of a 5 year old imma recommend you take your time elsewhere.

reviewText:
Got this game and loved it!
Challenging if played incorrectly, but amazingly fun if you get the hang of it and play it well. The graphics are amazing and eerie in some areas. If you love charming, pixel games, then this is definitely a game for you. I haven't played for long and I've already fallen for this game. It's a castle sim but you're much more involved in the game. The graphics of the water is amazing, it makes the game feel realistic while feeling distinctively 8-bit. I can't express how much I love the hybrid combination of realism and pixels.

So far I've found no problems, but I have an improvement: when standing near an area where you can interact, please show what you will build, I had to experiment way too much with what I was building and I died multiple times because what I purchased was not something I needed.

All in all, a great game with lots of potential. I hope to see more added to the game; a level editor would be fun. Great work, developers. This has quickly become one of my favourite games.

reviewText:
Honest Review
I am going to try to list the qualities of this game that I feel might help you make the decision if this game is for you. If you like the following, you will most likely enjoy playing Kingdom. (This is my first review of a game on Steam, so sorry if this is not too helpful, I will try to be as descriptive as I can).

If you like/appreciate pixel art, you might like this game.
If you like tower defense games, you will most likely enjoy this game. (Side Note: Watching your defenses fight back is enjoyable).
If you like survival games, gathering resources, and each wave slightly increasing in difficulty, you will most likely enjoy this game.
This game does require you to micromanage carefully.
Game allows you freedom in what you choose to either build/expand/defend" next. Basically this game reacts accordingly based on your actions.
Even if you lose the game
date:
don't think of it as a bad thing but rather the game's way of trying to tell you what happen and what you might be able to do to prepare yourself the next time around. (Side Note: Game has great replay value!)
Ambience:
Now im going to try to describe the surrealism this game provides (honestly this is probably my most favorite quality of the game):

Kingdom is very relaxing to play
recommended: it does this so strangely because you know your preparing for an attack but the ambiance/theme of the entire game is just so well done. Day times make you feel like your on a warm field and feeling the bliss of the sun and its welcoming embrace. Even during the day
hoursPlayed: if you venture deep into the forest you can see the sun trying to peak through the tree tops and shine into the dark ominous forest. Night times really make you feel a sense of danger is approaching

helpfulPercent: no more sounds

column16: rain
column17: sun
column18:
and moon this game does an amazing job with the ambience energy. The soundtrack/music of this game does an outstanding job with the day & night cycle and only adds more to the surreal factor. Overall the day & night cycle is very well implemented within the game. I love how during the dawn and dusk cycles you are able to feel/see them arrive and leave.

Final Thoughts:
Overall

column20: casual

reviewText:
Good     Beautiful
Original Gameplay ideas
Nice feel
Bad     The camera is bound to a player that only acts to limit movement via the horse stamina
Player has NO options to interact in a fight or in general
Useless AI
You can not command your soldiers despite the useless AI
Buildings can often not be upgraded because some condition is not fulfilled, but game does not tell you which one
Moon does not change shape to hint to when the next blood moon will be
Extreme amount of mysterious money sinks: Temple, Church, Trader...
No money left every evening, boring phase of idling since going to the forest in the evening WILL kill you
In summary, buy this only if you absolutely need to see beautiful pixel water reflection, or alternatively like a game that forces you to figure out every little thing by starting over every time something goes wrong.

reviewText:
(04/10) - Fun but missing Content

I think the premise and the idea of this game is really cool. You build up your base and recruit more and more citizens while expanding. And all of that in a 2D sidescrolling where you yourself can´t interact with the enemies or your troops.

Starting the game feels great. Seeing the first coins slip into your purse is very satisfying to look at, building your first buildings gives you a sense of accomplishment and surviving your first red moon really keeps you going.
The game looks and feels great but sadly it can´t hold that for long.

It took me about 30 minutes until i saw everything there is to see. There are 4 buildings and 3 units. That´s it.
Sure it´s fun at the start, but building walls and towers can´t keep you going for long. And it´s nearly all you can build. Same with your units. Sure, recruiting your first archers is nice, but when it´s nearly the only thing you can recruit for the entire game, there is no sense of progress.
The game runs it´s content down way too quickly so after about 5-8 nights (ingame), you´ll have seen it all.
I know that the game keeps expanding as you can go to more than 90 nights, but why would you bother if there is nothing new coming your way?

I got tired really quickly by this and just can´t reccommend it to anyone...

reviewText:
Kingdom is a horizontal tower defense game with a unique style, stunning pixel graphics and an excellent soundtrack.
I have my gripes about this one though.  Running from one end to the other can be tiresome, even with the addition of portals.  There’s not much to spend money on in the end and my farmers/hunters were constantly “making it rain” as I rode by on my horse with no pocket space.  It does seem odd I have a limit to how much money the king/queen can carry, but at least the citizens don’t seem to have this problem?
I’m not sure it’s worth the current price on the steam store, but it was fun for me.

reviewText:
Although I play this game for hours at a time, I do have some issues with it.

-Coins:
Coins are so plentiful at the beginning, but when the days go on and the attacks become more fatal, the coins start to disappear. This is both fustraiting and stressful. Trying to keep those slow, bad-aiming, dummies alive is hard when there's little income.

-Enimies/TownsFolks:
Seriously, reading these reviews all seem to say the same thing, so I'll say it again;
Why. Are. The. People. So. Stinkin'. Slow?
The little mosters are so fast, the horse can barely outrun it, let alone the townspeople. It's so sad to watch them all get trampled.
And whats with the flying death-doom thingys? They're terrifying. They just come in out of no where and eat up your little people, and they don't even try to defend themselves.

All in all I love this game. Love. It. It's beautiful and fun. The good outweighs the bad, but still...

reviewText:
Kingdom, what a unique game, for this age of gaming.. EXCELLENT

It has great Pixelated Art, the gameplay is VERY simple, yet the game is so unique, it just berly gives you a tutorial, (trust me you almost dont need it).
You starts out as a Queen in the middle of a forest, who has come to build her own kingdom. I am pretty positive every 5 nights the Blood Moon(BM) will arrive, and you must have your village prepared to be attacked by many sorts of monsters, every new BM will have more and more monsters. It makes for a really interesting gameplay, because not only do you have a bunch of monsters that continue to build up every BM they only attack one side. Sound Easy right? Sometimes its not so easy, one side will be nice and ready and next thing you know your being attacked on the opposite side and almost loose your crown.
It seems easy peasy at first until you realise, your bag can only hold so many gold coins, and you only have so much time to build(should only be building during the day, nightimes pretty risky), and you're constantly in a cat n mouse chase with those gold coins, you can never have enough, or you have way too much and cannot spend anything..
You almost never want to pause to take a break because there is ALWAYS something in need of support, or you're in need of more villagers.

This game is certainly unique in its own way, I couldn't be happier with it. Very basic, but very strategic when it comes to building and managing both sides of the village. Makes for an interesting gameplay everytime!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros + :

Beautiful atmosphere in the game. Haven't seen anything quite like it. Also the soundtrack is so beautiful.
You think everything is going well in your Kingdom. Then something dramatic happens, or you run out of archers/people to employ. Keeps the game interesting, and you really need to think about where your resources are going.
Addictive. You will want to play this one until you beat it (no matter how repetitive).
Cons - :

Personally found the game too short. I just wish there was more is all ):. Only had to restart 2-3 times before I got the hang of things, and then completed the game under 20 hours.
Instructions may be confusing for some people. As there practically is none. But I guess thats what you get for a trial and error game.
Conclusion
Fun game for the price. You will spend hours playing it, and get fustrated until you win.

reviewText:
This game is actually very good. It is a very detailed game in terms of graphics, but in terms of gameplay, I think there were decisions the developers made, that should not have been made. Still a great game overall though

PROBLEMS
-Archer's accuracy
Although I think making the archers miss is a good concept, but they miss way to much.
-Blood moons
I think the blood moons are a good concept as well, but they come to early, and to hard. Every blood moon that occurs, by entire kingdom is destroyed. I'm just lucky to have enough money to build it back up.
-Time cycles
The days pass by to quickly. I barely have enough time to prepare before the night comes and I'm attacked.
-Speed
The AI's speed is extremely slow. In the morning I had a builder fix a wooden wall. He started coming back in the evening.
-Stone
While I was writing this review I learned that you apparently need to throw a ton of money at an altar to get stone tier defenses. I've never even seen that altar before which means its very hard to find.

So while this is a great game, I think they made some decisions that take away from the game. Still great though

reviewText:
Build, plan, and defend your way!

Kingdom is a very nice pixel tower defense with a dash of medieval. It first I was assumed that this wouldn't be worth my time. After playing through 14 stress full short days, my mind set was changed and this game is probably my new favorite pixel city builder, since I'm a $lut for both. This game has a beautiful soundtrack that perfectly balances the therpuetic atmosphere, only at day time that is...


+Pros:
-Fun, stressful gameplay
-Very atmospheric
-Very depth, yet simple
-Throws you right into the game
-Unique game over system (DONT LOSE YOUR CROWN!)
-Simple mechanics for upgrading buildings
-AI Archer accuracy is garbage = STRESS INDUCED RAGE

-Cons:
-Very few monster
-AI Archers dont produce gold that fast
-If workers get attacked they have to get recruited again
-Same gold amount after each level
-Thief enemies (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥S)
-Gold seems to drain quickly
-If youre being chased with no help = automatic game over
- No jump mechanic to escape quickly

Kingdom may have its flaws but it will continue to draw me in for its unique 2 sided tower defense, atmosphere, gameplay system, and the horrible aim archers!

This game is worth the money and definitely worth your time!

10/10 would lose crown again

reviewText:
I have over 150 games in my inventory, and Kingdom has provided me with some of the most enjoyment I've had in quite a while. The game really surprised me with its pixel art style; usually I tend to stay away from more retro games; however they did a really great job with the visual style (changing weather, clouds, etc.) as well as the music; both combine to form a really great atmosphere as well as a sense of discovery early on in the game.

Despite what some of the negative reviews state, it is possible to beat Kingdom; it might require a bit of trial and error though (as in most games, you learn from your mistakes). There are many different ways to go about it, which offers additional replayability as well as an added level of strategy.

Overall, I think Kingdom is a great game, and I'd definately recommend it.

reviewText:
I enjoyed figuring out how this game worked - building a kingdom, testing out theories, making discoveries and blunders that would set me to try again.  Trying to build my kingdom again and again to make it better and more efficient is what this game is about.  It puzzled and surprised me enough to keep me going until I beat it.  The music was nice, and the emergent objectives the game presented kept me occupied and entertained.

It is relatively short - I think I saw everything the game has to offer, and feel no real desire to replay it again (which is almost a shame since that is the main skill the game has you develop).  The game got repetitive toward the end, with your character tracking back and forth across the map to the same objects and objectives.

If you like puzzling out mechanics and objectives, testing your theories and the feeling of Next time I'll do better"

reviewText:
I have a love/hate relationship with this game. On the one side its a very charming game with a really good set up to it. Its very minimal and yet requires a lot of thought. On the other hand its such an unforgiving game. I find there is really only one way to even play this game and to me thats somewhat of a problem. You can scour the internet yourself but the bottom line is if you dont have a many MANY archers on either side of your base you will lose. It is also extraodinarily hard to come back from, especially late game when you cannot count on your town chest for gold.

Pros
-Can be quite relaxing, your just sitting around or riding your horse back and forth no cares in the world.
-Easier to understand than others would let on. This game has a very quick tutorial that does not cover quite a few things such as farming or later game military units. However I find that just adds to it. Its all about figuring stuff out. People dont seem to want to do that anymore
-graphics seem pretty basic however some are just amazing. The water is my favorite
-For both casual and the hardcore. You can easily lose hours to this game OR hop in for a quick day or two which is only about 15 minutes.

Cons
-Very VERY unforgiving. If one side falls your base falls. Even if you manage to fight the wave back it is impossible to recover due to you having to spend a ton of gold just to get your villagers to come back to your side, not to mention the cost of re equiping AND wall repairs.
-A good run requires a very strong start. You pretty much need a farm stream close by, good hunting grounds on either if not both sides AND village hovels that are not to to far apart. Can be frustrating trying to get all those things in one map. And then one small mistake or miscalculation with your defences and you just sit to and watch it burn down.
-AI is a real hassle at times. Archers some times wander to far out and cannot make it back in time before they get murdered by the haunts at night. Or farmers insiting on staying out. I would love to see a system put into effect such as a recall bell or something like that so you can manually call the troops and villagers into town.

I recommend this game solely because it's charming and a great play. It has its faults like many others (My big problem being why do you get less money the bigger your Kingdom gets when really you should be receiving more), and AI can give you a headache. It is unforgiving but that also leads you to learn things and become a better King/Queen for your next play through.

reviewText: As many have said, Kingdom is a lovely looking game dripping with atmosphere.  Despite some other reviews to the contrary though, it is also game full of strategy and subtlety.  The challenge lies in the fact that you do not have full control over your subjects or the landscape.  You must make your choices as they have lasting effects:  create too many builders too early and you might run out of money; too many archers and you won't be able to fortify your defenses.  Build your walls too close and have no room to farm;  build them too far out and get overrun.  And what if you don't have the quarry to build your watch tower where you need it?  Do you hire extra archers or do you just push your borders?  It's different, and a joy, every time.\n\nAbove all, be sure that you're prepared for each blood moon; they're coming for your crown.

reviewText:
I really enjoy this game but I'm leaving this review because it won't be for everyone.

Kingdom is a game where you have to manage your defences, make money and destroy the enemy. This is primarily done through the use of only one resource; gold. This really helps sometimes as you don't have to worry about if you have enough food, if you have enough arrows, if you have enough water, etc. Drop gold to hire people, buy bows and buy hammers for your people to use, and build up your defences.

The difficulty is something that I found really weird. During regular nights, very few monsters will spawn and they will easily be killed by youor archers. But about every five nights, there is a blood moon. Similar to Terraria, during a blood moon, lots of difficult enemies will spawn and it is often on these nights that you will have to restart. The difficulty is cranked up to eleven and even if the monsters don't get all the way to your campfire, you will probably lose a few archers, maybe a catapult and a wall, which spends most of the the next days money repairing.

One thing that will annoy quite a lot of people is that the locations for certain buildings are in fixed locations; you have no way to choose where to build your walls or towers. While I did quite like not having to worry about this, many people would like to have that freedom.

Another issue is that some statues and camps that you desperately need to use to survive are hidden deep into the forest and it takes the entire day just to go there and get what you need. This can sometimes make the game end quite quickly because if your horse is out of stamina and can't gallop in time to get back to safety, monsters will spawn and take away your crown.

A deeper tutorial would be nice as the only help you get is press down to throw money to recruit people, hold down to buy, hold down to build. One time, after reaching day 18, I expanded and had a knight group form. This would've been amazing if I knew what they did. I walked over to them and saw the option to pay for something. I thought, I can upgrade them! I needed something to do with my money!" They walked off into the jungle to defeat the enemy portal. That night
date: with a significant number of my army gone
recommended: I was overrun. Which wouldn't be so bad if I didn't have to go through all 18 days again.\n\nA final issue I have is that though your can hire archers and build catapults
hoursPlayed: your character has no defense. Even one monster can kill you as you have no bow or sword and even though this pushes the concept that you need to defend your kingdom
voteText: it does feel a little unfair sometimes as your defences are breached and you can do nothing about it.\n\nIn closing
helpfulPercent: although I have said a lot of negative things about this game
votesHelpful: it is still an enjoyable and addicting game. Even after frustration
votesTotal: I always come back to try again. There's always another way you can try
votesFunny: and the game goes on for a long time; one of the achievements is to survive 100 days. Even through the vey simple resource gathering and spending mechanic
commentsCount: there is still a lot of depth and strategy in the game."
