reviewText:
My time for playing games has dropped dramatically these days, so anytime I spend more than an hour with a game it's a glowing endorsement. That stands true with Kingdom. I plan to play many more hours (when I can). It's one of those games where the mechanics are incredibly simple and straightforward, but require skill and a developed understanding of how build up your Kingdom.

The game seems deceptively easy at first, but once you experience your first Blood Moon you'll understand how difficult it can be to last any longer than a few days. It's a war of attrition and the enemies supply of bodies is limitless and your ability to build and defend your Kingdom is limited by your currency, the speed of your horse, and the number of villagers you can recruit.

Give this game a shot. Once you become remotely adept at it you'll become hooked.

reviewText:
It's hard to recommend this game. I enjoy a lot about it. But there are some fundamental flaws that make it unplayable past a certain point.

- Because of its sidescrolling nature as you expand your kingdom your walls (where all the action takes place) become further and further away from your main camp (where all your weapons come from) and of course the other side of your kingdom. At a certain point you have to spend all your time just riding back and forth on a horse that will only run half of the time. It's very unfulfilling. This could be softened by other tasks to perform while on your way back and forth.

- The NPC AI is crap. I see a lot of people complaining about how they're too slow and not a good shot with a bow. I actually don't have a problem with that. I think that they're balanced well enough against the enemy. However, they don't have a good sense about where the enemy is or which direction they're coming from. If the enemy horde breaks through all your walls from one direction and crosses your main camp all your troops still face the other way and allow the enemy to just come up from behind and slaughter them. If they just knew that the enemy was coming from the other direction and stood at the opposite wall it would be much more balanced.

- Another AI issue is this: when you recruit troops they will automatically split their numbers between both sides of your camp. BUT they will all clump at the most outward wall on either side. As you expand your kingdom you end up with many walls in layers going outward. But those walls don't do any good if there aren’t any troops standing behind them to shoot the enemy. If they would just split their numbers between each wall then you would have a much better fortified defense.

- ALSO when you build towers the troops prioritize filling those first. Even if it's far outside your wall or right at your main camp where they will sit and do nothing because all the action is at the farthest wall. They should prioritize only the towers nearest to your most outward wall.

- And finally, at a certain point it becomes literally impossible to recruit more troops. Troops come from camps in the woods. You can recruit 3-4 a day if you're diligent. But as you expand your kingdom you take over these camps and there is nowhere for new recruits to spawn. This wouldn't necessarily be a problem because when your troops die" they actually just lose loyalty and walk away. You can just catch them and pay them to come back. BUT during the later days more and more flyers come and take your troops away. I went from about 60 troops to maybe 15 in the course of 10 days (2 blood moons). And I literally couldn't recruit any more. Either the flyers should not be taking your troops or there should be a more reliable way to recruit more.

All that being said
date: I actually did really enjoy playing it. It's absolutely beautiful and the music is on point. And the first few times you play it it's totally fun. But when you're on day 80 everything just feels arduous and hopeless. It needs a lot more late game support.\n\nBuy it on sale."

reviewText:
Kingdom is a side-scroller, strategy game that incorprates a survival element with a one-life system where you have to restart if your crown is stolen. Using gold obtained through your townsfolk, you can purchase tools to give them roles such as farming, hunting and even becoming one of your knights to defend against monsters. So what is good about the game?

Pros:

+ Gorgeous pixel art
+ Building your own kingdom from scratch and investing in it however you wish.
+ The game does not hold your hand by giving you in-depth tutorials. It gives you controls and basic  mechanics, but that is it.
+ Easy to pick up.
+ A one-life system, though frustrating at times, really puts pressure on your decision making when outside your walls.

Cons:

- Losing your crown to monsters when you run out of money in the wilderness. Time to restart.
- Losing your crown to monsters after your horse runs out of stamina. Time to restart.
- Having a large kingdom can make it take a while (up to half a day cycle) to get from one end of the map to the other.
- Later on in the game, it can get fairly laggy with a large mass of monsters assaulting your walls.
- Slow moving units make it difficult for them to get anything done when your kingdom gets very large.
- A little bare, but this could be solved with some additions in future.

Nevertheless, I recommend picking it up if it has a sale, it'd be well worth the money. If most of the glaring issues such as the slow units and fair lack of content are fixed, then this game would be well worth the price.

reviewText:
Ok.. it's not a bad game... with nice pixel art and an awesome sound track, and the pricetag is spot on, so I have to recommend it..

HOWEVER I would rather pay $40 (or more) for the same concept, but with a bit more meat and refinement.

Replayability disappears after 15 hours or so...
It doesn't take much to learn how to beat the game (and how to manipulate the dumb AI) and it becomes too easy... and therefore BORING.

It's a little disappointing because it's nearly perfect

What it needs:
1/ basic control over soldiers - OR smarter AI
- What's the point in upgrading towers? When I later expand, they can't move to the front line...
- After clearing the portals on one side, the army just sits there and it still recieves new archers.
- catapults... omg - There's NEVER an engineer there to reload - and it's NEVER in the right position.

2/ Difficulty - wayyy too easy
3/ Too much money late game with nothing to spend it on..
4/ MORE upgrades (magic? swordsman? bigger towers? More castle upgrades? a better horse?)
5/ Minimap - so I know where I fricking am
6/ Merchant - not be give random tools..
7/ King / Queen should have a melee attach, or battlecry or something.
8/ The horse... I get why it gets tired, but it's hard work pacing the damn thing

reviewText:
At the moment, I've tried to beat the game only 3 times. And that was kind of experience!

The game mechanics is simple. Invest coins in people / buildings (at pre-defined locations). Take more coins as an output of these investments. Build defences. Learn game rules by trying new things.

However the gameplay turns out to be really challenging and intence. You have to invest in proper things, take investments timely, defend and build wisely. Even the time of the day matters much. And after the kingdom is lost (and you'll loose because of your mistakes), try again and make it at least for 5 days longer.

The pixel-style is great! Music is also nice.

P.S. for devs.
Wish there would be more decorations / map styles later (sands? winter?).
Also I'd prefer to take items from the ground and drop them in the city. That could add some new mechanics and simplify the aftermatch" rebuilding."

reviewText:
It is disappointing to see a game get bad reviews from players not because of its graphics, sound or story but because the player found the game too difficult. This is not a difficult game to master. It requires clever strategies, quick decision-making and time management skills but once you understand its mechanics you enjoy the challenge of seeing how long you can last.

Kingdom has received a few patches since I purchased it on day one and they have improved the gameplay significantly. It is still lacking some end-game content which I'm sure they will add in future patches but so far I have been hooked for about 30 hours which is not bad for a $10 game.

Highly recommended.
